IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The rate of endometrial cancer deaths is increasing and current treatments cause serious side effects. This project will study a new drug, called SHetA2, that has shown no significant toxicities to date and is targeted at specific molecular defects that occur in endometrial cancers. The outcome of this research has the potential to optimize SHetA2-based treatments for endometrial cancer patients and identify those patients who will most likely benefit from this therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Adaptation is a fundamental attribute of living systems, allowing organisms to react to their environments on scales ranging from the physiological responses to environmental signals to long-term evolutionary adaptations. The work proposed here aims to provide a quantitative description of the adaptive dynamics of cells by exploring how cells mount responses through rapid changes in molecular conformation, alterations in the proteome through regulated gene expression and evolutionary rewiring of the genome in contexts such as the rise of antibiotic resistance. This work will provide a far-reaching but detailed view of how cells adapt by integrating precise measurements with biophysical theory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative An effective treatment for metastatic osteosarcoma is a critical unmet medical need. Our preclinical data demonstrate that a neutralizing antibody against the canonical Wnt signaling antagonist, DKK-1, slows primary tumor growth, induces nuclear translocation of β-catenin, upregulates markers of differentiation, and abolishes metastasis in a mouse model of osteosarcoma based on patient-derived xenografts. We propose testing a small molecule inhibitor of DKK-1 in a similar model to determine effects on both canonical and noncanonical Wnt signaling, on the growth and differentiation of osteosarcoma patient-derived xenografts, and on osteosarcoma metastasis, as well as validating DKK-1 serum levels as a biomarker of disease burden and response to therapy in patients newly diagnosed with osteosarcoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Studying coordinated cell processes in the 3D tissue context requires precise manipulation of cell behavior in time and space, however this is difficult to achieve in 3D culture using current biomaterials. To address this, our approach leverages innovative 3D biomaterial scaffolds that respond to focused ultrasound, allowing precise genetic manipulation of cellular behavior at specific times and locations. This research program will generate new insights into cellular processes and communication in the 3D context, including chemotaxis, with applications to tissue maturation, regeneration and wound repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE Training young scientists and engineers in translational research in biomaterials facilitates the translation of biomaterials-based technologies to the clinic. Specifically, the Translational Research in Biomaterials (TRB) curriculum enables students to develop the creative, analytical, quantitative, and professional skills they need to make new discoveries that will revolutionize fields ranging from diagnostics and drug delivery to tissue engineering. These advances will improve patient care in multiple areas of medicine and ensure an academic and industrial workforce to meet the challenges of the 21st century.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use disorder leads to a devastatingly diverse set of negative health outcomes, including significantly increased risk of hypertension, stroke, pancreatitis, liver cirrhosis, Alzheimer’s disease, multiple cancers, and multiple types of cognitive dysfunction. Theoretically framed within the Addiction Neuroclinical Assessment with hypothesized mechanisms in core domains (i.e., incentive salience, negative emotionality and cognitive function), and proceeding from a sound scientific premise we will target reduced alcohol use among alcohol use disorder patients in primary care using a carefully designed combination of contingency management (CM, or incentives in exchange for objectively verified evidence of behavior) delivered at thrice-weekly visits during the first 4-weeks of zonisamide treatment to jumpstart reductions in drinking. For the remaining 8-weeks of zonisamide, CM will be delivered at weekly visits in exchange for evidence of 100% or higher medication adherence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Spatially resolved single-cell transcriptomic methods promise a transformative new window into a wide array of biological questions. However, the promise of these techniques—whole-transcriptome expression profiles collected for millions of cells rapidly over large sample regions in any tissue or organism—remain practically out of reach with current implementations. Here we will develop an improved single-cell transcriptomics methodology that dramatically increases the speed, robustness, range of targeted RNAs, and breadth of organisms and tissues that can be routinely measured with such methods, transforming these techniques from bespoke methodologies to ones that can be rapidly and routinely applied broadly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative: The research proposes to develop methods to fabricate magic angle spinning (MAS) NMR rotors and drive tips from single crystal diamond samples using laser micromachining techniques. The reasons for using diamond are (1) that it is stronger than other materials such as ZrO2, (2) it is transparent to microwaves and therefore better for DNP experiments, and (3) has excellent thermal conductivity so that samples will cool more efficiently. The higher strength will enable higher spinning rates and better sensitivity will lead to molecular structures with higher precision and could have a profound impact on structural biology, medical imaging and solid state NMR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Cellular proteins coordinate complex responses to stimuli, including medications, and downstream protein responses are responsible for disease-modifying effects and unintended side-effects. However, we lack an understanding of the general rules governing downstream protein responses created by medications, especially in cases where medicines bind many cellular proteins. This research aims to learn the general rules of how multi-protein stimuli influence downstream protein responses to eventually improve how medications are designed to treat disease symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Musculoskeletal disease is one of the leading causes of disability and health care expenses where an estimated 126.6 million Americans (one in two adults) are affected by a musculoskeletal condition costing an estimated $213 billion each year in treatment and lost wages. With an aging population, this figure is only set to increase and become worse since research is hampered by a low and slow rate of translation of basic discoveries into clinical practice, e.g. only 25% of highly promising biomedical discoveries resulted in a published randomized clinical trial and less than 10% were established in clinical practice within 20 years. This COBRE center implements a new concept for translational research, i.e. Virtual Human Trials, to expedite the process from concept development to new deliverable therapeutics, interventions, and devices for musculoskeletal health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: Major depressive disorder (MDD) is a common disease with high risk of suicide, great social and economic costs, and poor treatment response, where smaller hippocampus, with loss of neurons and astrocytes, have been reported, as well as gene variants potentially implicated in brain function. This project will identify differentially expressed proteins and genes between MDD and non-psychiatric control hippocampus cell clusters, at a regional and single cell level, together with spatial co-mapping of RNA, epigenetic (Assay for Transposase-Accessible Chromatin, ATAC) and protein changes (using DBiT-seq and Visium), and determination of cell fate trajectories based on RNA splicing profiles (RNA velocity). Identified molecular regulators of hippocampus cell viability and function will provide potential druggable targets for new MDD treatments, to be later tested in cellular and animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The Multi-scale Computational Modeling (MCM) Core will continue to provide support for SC-TRIMH investigators toward building a patient-specific and precision-care musculoskeletal system through computer simulations at molecular, cellular, tissue, body, and population levels, with a new addition of Artificial Intelligence/Machine Learning (AI/ML) capacities for big data driven modeling in the COBRE Phase II. This core will take full advantage of the current resources and capabilities at Clemson University, which entails Clemson's powerful supercomputing capability, known as the “Palmetto Cluster” (listed on the TOP500 in the world), the well-established Multiphysics Modeling Studio, the extensive AI research capacity at Clemson, and the large amounts of patient-specific data available for model building at the PRISMA Health System.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a disease that affects the joints that is characterized by immune dysregulation resulting in chronic inflammation that damages cartilage and bone and can lead to permanent joint damage and disability. We are studying how the fibroblast tissue cells in the joint regulate inflammation and drive joint damage in RA. We are determining what drives the abnormal cells in order to find new ways to target treatments for RA.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this study is to not only identify which surgery for treatment of uterovaginal prolapse is objectively better, but how to best identify the correct procedure for each individual patient. This study will merge traditional surgical research trial design with qualitative research methodology, to gain a deep understanding of what is most important to a woman when she is deciding on a treatment option and how it relates to her perception of recovery after surgery and long-term treatment success. We hope that this study will also create an individualized approach for surgical treatment of pelvic organ prolapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol associated liver disease (ALD) caused by chronic alcohol abuse is a major health problem with high economic burden and limited treatment options. Our previous studies have established a pathogenic role for proteostasis mediator HSP90 in ALD. This R01 renewal resubmission application proposes investigation of epigenetic and metabolic pathways in macrophage activation. We will extend our analysis to assessment of HSP90 and metabolic genes in monocytes of alcoholic hepatitis patients. These studies will provide novel mechanisms and extend our horizons to identify new therapeutic avenues for ALD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding how tissues are assembled and organized into complex three dimensional arrangements is a central challenge in the fields of tissue engineering and regenerative medicine. The collective polarization and alignment of cells across a tissue is a phenomenon known as planar cell polarity (PCP) that is conspicuously lacking in vitro organs, yet is absolutely essential for proper organ formation and function. Ultimately, deciphering the mechanisms that establish PCP will help us to understand how misregulation of this pathway causes developmental defects, and bring us closer to developing fully functional organs in vitro.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Differences between males and females is termed sexual dimorphism and causes significant variation in the craniofacial skeleton. These changes between sexes produce functional changes in mandible movement, common conditions that require surgical correction, and distinct prevalence and progression of several diseases. This proposal will directly address how sex generates variation in the shape of the craniofacial skeleton, including developmental origins, genetic risk factors, and the influence of hormones.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Rotator cuff tendon tears account for more than 4.5 million physician visits annually, and multiple risk factors can lead to pre-existing degenerations, putting an estimated 17 million Americans at increased risk for rotator cuff impairment and tearing. This proposal aims to understand how cigarette smoking, an important yet complicated risk factor for rotator cuff injuries, influences the structures within the tendon-bone interface and their biomechanics. A computational modeling framework will be developed to more fully understand the mechanisms of the degenerative effects of smoking on the rotator cuff tendon-bone interface and as a foundation for future work on developing better therapeutics and surgical approaches for repairing the interface.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Ventilated pediatric patients are frequently over-sedated and the majority suffer from delirium, a form of acute brain dysfunction that is an independent predictor of increased risk of dying, length of stay, and costs. Universally prescribed sedative medications—the GABA-ergic benzodiazepines—worsen this brain organ dysfunction and independently prolong duration of ventilation and ICU stay, and the available alternative sedation regimen using dexmedetomidine, an alpha-2 agonist, has been shown to be superior to benzodiazepines in adults, and may mechanistically impact outcomes through positive effects on innate immunity, bacterial clearance, apoptosis, cognition and delirium. The mini-MENDS trial will compare dexmedetomidine and midazolam, and determine the best sedative medication to reduce delirium and improve duration of ventilation, and functional, psychiatric, and cognitive recovery in our most vulnerable patients— survivors of pediatric critical illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Work under this proposal supports development and commercialization of a broad-spectrum coagulometer based on novel technology that promises to enable rapid and precise measurements of the effects of anticoagulants, their reversal agents and thrombolytic drugs on blood clotting and clot lysis processes, respectively, directly at the point-of-care. Initial marketing efforts will focus on use of the coagulometer for monitoring of the direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) and low molecular weight heparins (LMWHs) with a Clotting Time assay. The proposed research will yield clinical clotting time reference ranges for the DOACs, in direct support of initial, future marketing goals, and assessment of the device’s ability to detect and measure inherited or acquired coagulopathies as well as to monitor effects of the novel factor XI/XIa inhibitor abelacimab, in support of future device applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Neovascular age-related macular degeneration is a leading cause of vision loss and blindness. A challenging subtype of this disease develops chorioretinal anastomoses, vascular lesions which unfortunately can be resistant to treatment. Our research aims to understand the developmental and molecular mechanisms driving these lesions to help guide new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Meniscal allograft transplantation (MAT), a medically necessary treatment for patients with symptomatic meniscal loss, has been restricted by the donor-recipient size-matching challenge resulting from ineffective preservation of donor fresh allografts. We propose to overcome the limitations of MAT by developing an ice- free cryopreservation method incorporating special warming technology to preserve cell viability, tissue structure, and biomechanical properties in meniscal allografts during long term storage. This research will lay the foundation for more efficient preservation of various meniscal grafts including human meniscal allografts, tissue-engineered grafts, and xenografts for future treatment of meniscal injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) often responds inadequately to serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SRIs). Given the morbidity and dysfunction OCD imposes on millions of U.S. adults, exploring whether SRI non- responders are helped by adding drugs with different mechanisms of action is urgently needed. Emerging data support ketamine’s rapid and sustained anti-obsessional effects in OCD. The proposed mechanistic trial would be the first to probe the role of ketamine’s opioid properties in modulating fronto-striatal circuitry and bringing about reduction of OCD symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  β-cells derived from human stem cells represent a transformative, unlimited source of insulin-producing cells for the treatment of type 1 diabetes, but translation of these cells is hindered by limited development of mature insulin-producing cells and the lack long-term engraftment and function without chronic immunosuppression. The objective of this project is to develop biomaterials for the transplantation of human stem cell-derived β-cells that promote maturation and function of the cells while also protecting the cells from attack by the immune system without the need for long-term systemic immunosuppression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The absence of a universally accepted, standardized fracture classification system is a critical barrier in the development of research on how best to treat proximal humerus fractures (PHF). A standardized approach for PHF classification can be accomplished with computer assisted image analysis of X-rays, and archived X-rays stored in the medical records of past patients will help inform how to treat current and future patients. The use of computers to classify fractures will not only enable historical patient data to be used for research on PHF treatment effectiveness, but also has the potential to improve the accuracy and efficiency of fracture diagnosis in clinical practice and thereby improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Circadian rhythms, our 24 daily biological rhythms, control nearly all our basic biological functions and are sensitive to the environment. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health as it focuses on developing mathematical algorithms for understanding and tracking the physiological processes and health states related to inflammation, metabolism, fatigue, and interoceptive awareness. As wearable monitoring rises in popularity, and new portable physiological monitoring devices become available for continuous monitoring of physiological signals, the dynamic response to external influences such as surgery, medication, disease, and environmental inputs can be quantified. The multimodal estimators for sensing health proposed here will offer insights into the complexity of interactions between physiological signals, which will significantly improve medical diagnosis and patient outcomes by also considering the medical expertise of physicians, and eventually help inform treatments and interventions to improve the quality of healthcare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Corneal transplantation is the most common form of tissue grafting, and diabetes affects over 10% of the US population, accounting for over 34 million cases. Remarkably, while there is increasing data implicating a history of diabetes among tissue donors as a risk factor for subsequent transplant failure, there is little scientific insight into the mechanisms that underlie this association. This grant proposes to continue our ongoing investigations that suggest a strong link between the diabetic state and activation of resident immune cells in the tissue, a line of investigation that could potentially have major implications for eye banking and corneal transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The lack of understanding of the molecular mechanisms that drive chronic neck pain has hampered the development of effective mechanism-specific therapeutics. We will use RNA sequencing on joint and nerve tissues of patients with chronic and acute neck pain coupled with computational biology methods and careful patient phenotyping to examine how molecules produced in the diseased tissue drive chronic pain. Our work has the potential to reveal new molecular targets for future drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While transfusion of red blood cells (RBCs) represents one of the most common therapeutic interventions in medicine, RBC transfusion is not without risk. Development of alloimmune responses to RBC antigens can lead to adverse clinical reactions and increased mortality. While RBC alloimmunization can become particularly problematic when patients develop alloantibodies against multiple alloantigens, what factors may regulate the development of additional alloantibodies following initial alloimmunization remains largely unknown. These studies will use pre-clinical models to elucidate key initiating factors responsible for RBC alloimmunization in an effort to reduce or eliminate this process in transfusion-dependent individuals. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Impact Statement: Macrophage Determinants of Retinal Regeneration In both zebrafish and humans, an immune response occurs in reaction to retinal damage and death of neurons, but whereas zebrafish regenerate their damaged retinal neurons, humans develop a gliotic response. In addition, responding immune cells (specifically microglia and macrophages) appear to contribute to pathology in humans. This project will investigate contributions of microglia and macrophages to retinal degeneration and regeneration in the zebrafish model system, to provide foundational knowledge that will ultimately inform the design of therapeutic strategies and treatments for human retinal injury and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: We seek to address a gap in the fundamental understanding of mechanisms in two areas of contemporary catalysis – photoredox catalysis and biocatalysis by engineered enzymes. This proposal utilizes a battery of experimental and theoretical mechanistic probes to gain atomistic insight into several fundamental reactions. The outcome of the proposed studies will enable the rational design and development of more powerful chemical transformations for the synthesis of medicinally relevant molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proteinopathy condition of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the leading cause of dementia and the sixth leading cause of death in the United States. Indeed, it is estimated that 13.8 million Americans will be affected by AD by the year 2050 unless effective disease-modifying treatments are developed. We will characterize human neuronal and glial cell genomic and epigenomic signatures and networks that confer vulnerability to AD proteinopathies, such as amyloid-b, Tau or/and TDP-43, in order to identify new mechanistic drug targets and disease-modifying repurposable medicines that we will then evaluate in real-world patient data and in laboratory models of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Shelbi L Russell Project Narrative Microbial symbiosis is ubiquitous among eukaryotes and has enabled many remarkable lifestyles and strategies, however little is known about the cellular mechanisms that maintain these associations. The  Wolbachia  bacterial symbiont of many insect and filarial nematode species, exhibits a range of transmission strategies and is highly tractable in the lab. Here, I propose to use the K99 period of a NIH NIGMS Pathway to Independence Award to develop tools, datasets, and techniques that will enable me to ask deeper and more complex questions about host-symbiont interactions during the R00 phase.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Personalized medicine holds the promise of improving care for patients with severe infections (sepsis). Glucocorticoids (often referred to as steroids) are commonly used in the treatment of septic patients, but it is unclear which patients benefit and which patients may be harmed. We will use datasets and blood samples from several US and international studies with novel machine learning assisted mathematical techniques to develop approaches that will help doctors personalize steroids for septic patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research aims to assess the feasibility and efficacy of adaptive brain-computer interface neurotechnology for a novel pathophysiologically based therapeutic intervention in patients with laryngeal dystonia. The proposed research is relevant to public health because non-invasive neuromodulation of brain abnormalities that are specifically linked to the pathophysiology of laryngeal dystonia is ultimately expected to lead to the establishment of a new direction for the treatment of this debilitating disorder. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to developing and applying fundamental knowledge that will help reduce the burdens of human disability.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative More than 10% of adults over 70, have a somatic mutation in their blood stem cells, a newly identified disease termed ‘Clonal Hematopoiesis of Indeterminate Potential’ (CHIP), which increases blood cancer risk by 10-fold, heart attack risk by 2-fold and risk of death by 1.5-fold. To understand the fundamental causes and disease consequences of CHIP, we will perform human genomic analyses of hundreds of thousands of individuals with and without CHIP. Our work identifying the causes of CHIP may lead to the first treatment for patients with CHIP that would prevent multiple age-associated diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Recent studies have indicated that mechanical cues from the cell's environment are indispensable for key processes such as development and wound healing. Changes in the mechanical properties of tissues are reliable markers of disease – for example tissue density is one of the strongest risk factors in cancer progression, while immune cells exploit mechanical signals to kill cancer cells. How mechanical cues regulate cell function remains poorly understood. The proposed research to develop fundamental understanding of how mechanical stimuli and cell generated forces regulate T cell signaling and killing of tumor cells as well as the dynamics of gene expression will have important implications for the development of new therapeutic avenues for immunotherapies and diagnostic tools for diseases like breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A group of neurodegenerative diseases, termed synucleinopathies, have no existing disease modifying thera- pies, affect over 2 million people in the U.S. and share an underlying pathology—progressive deposition of phos- phorylated α-synuclein protein in the central and peripheral nervous systems. In the proposed study, CND Life Sciences will advance the diagnostic and commercial potential of its Syn-One Test™ that detects phosphorylated α-synuclein in small skin biopsies by focusing on a population of patients diagnosed with idiopathic rapid eye movement disorder (iRBD), >90% of whom will ultimately develop synucleinopathy 10-15 years following iRBD diagnosis. Successful completion of this study will enable the clinicians to utilize the Syn-One Test™ to deter- mine which of the iRBD patients will develop synucleinopathy, which type and how quickly, and aid in the devel- opment of therapies for this group of devastating diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE ROCKY MOUNTAIN CANNABIS RESEARCH CENTER (RM-CRC) Recreational and medical cannabis products that contain varying amounts of tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and cannabidiol (CBD) are now widely available throughout North America. Despite these changes, research on the effects of THC and CBD has been lacking. The central goals of this Research Center of Excellence application are to evaluate, in three research projects that span emerging, middle-aged, and older adults, how CBD affects the use of and subjective response to THC, and whether these effects are mediated by the endocannabinoid system (ECS) and associated lipids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative  Many common and incurable diseases, including Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, and Huntington’s diseases, are characterized by the accumulation and aggregation of misfolded proteins and the activation of cellular stress pathways. This proposal examines the mechanisms by which cells degrade these aggregation-prone proteins, and how stress pathways affect this process through the trafficking of degradative organelles. Understanding these fundamental cellular processes is essential for developing therapeutics that take advantage of the complicated relationships between stress pathways and neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: COAST NARRATIVE If we validate an SLT treatment strategy that extends the duration of medication-free disease control, we move one step closer to the possibility of a drop-free lifetime for our patients. Delaying the need for medications by 3, or 5, or 7 years not only confers all the benefits of medication-freedom during this period (which will be all that many patients would need in their lifetimes)—it also allows time for development of safer and more effective drugs dosed infrequently via sustained-release delivery systems, as well as better surgical options, for patients whose lifespans exceed SLT responsiveness. Thus, a new treatment paradigm consisting of SLT, then sustained-release medications, then surgery, could offer the majority of glaucoma patients the very real possibility of a drop-free lifetime of therapy.

PHR: Project Narrative IRACDA at OHSU is a program that aims to train and support a diverse generation of future faculty, in partnership with Pacific University. IRACDA scholars will receive mentorship in conducting exceptional scientific research at OHSU, training and practice in evidence-based teaching methods at Pacific University, blended together by personalized career development and guidance from dedicated program staff at both institutions. As they grow through the program, IRACDA scholars will not only impact the future of science and education, but also will transform our existing programs and institutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Esophageal cancer is a devastating disease with the majority of patients being diagnosed after the tumor has metastasized, leaving patients with the 5-year relative survival rate of only 5%. The proposed work seeks to better understand the underlying mechanisms of metastasis in esophageal carcinoma, as well as to target the identified pathway in pre-clinical models. Overall, in the long term, this study will introduce more effective and targeted treatments to patients with metastatic esophageal cancer, and potentially other deadly cancers with similar genetic and epigenetic properties.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project narrative Up to 80% of preterm infants experience feeding-related problems, often due to an inability to generate the suction necessary for the acquisition and transport of liquid, yet our understanding of the neuromotor mechanisms governing these behaviors is limited. By varying sensory input through pressure generation and milk viscosity (K99) as well as feeding on a biomimetic nipple (R00), I propose to determine the neuromuscular mechanisms that control feeding in preterm infants. These results will serve as a foundation for the development of evidence-based interventions to ensure that all children have the chance to live healthy and productive lives.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA NEW JERSEY HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Gulf War Veterans (GWVs) with Gulf War Illness (GWI) do not receive the care they should in the Veterans Affairs (VA). Our data show 70% of GWVs with Gulf War Illness (GWI) do not receive treatment recommendations for their GWI and 78% are NOT very satisfied with their care. We must improve the quality of care GWVs receive. VA and DoD have invested hundreds of millions of dollars to develop new treatments for GWVs, without effective delivery methods GWVs will not benefit. This study will be the first study to examine the best model of care to deliver treatments to GWVs with GWI. Determining the best model of care to translate research into practice is a key goal of the VA Gulf War Strategic Plan and a specific aim of this Request for Applications.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative While the COVID‐19 pandemic has highlighted health disparities, Black children have unduly suffered and died from seasonal influenza for decades. Through sustained partnership with Black community stakeholders, novel community‐engaged research methods, and an innovative intervention approach, this proposal will explore, develop, and test a Digital Storytelling intervention to reduce influenza vaccination disparities in Black children aged 6 months to 5 years. This project will advance our understanding of engagement methods and interventions that improve health equity and serve as a model for future work to address vaccination disparities, ensuring all individuals have the chance to fulfill their potential free of preventable diseases.

PHR: Narrative Gastroparesis is a common and serious disorder with complicated pathophysiology and limited treatment options. In this project we will develop and use advanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) technologies to investigate mechanisms of gastroparesis involving various gastric motor functions in both healthy and diabetic animals and humans. The success of this project will lead to an improved understanding of gastroparesis and facilitate development of effective therapies for gastroparesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Broken DNA is particularly problematic when it is present during cell division. We have developed a distinctive model to understand how cells prevent negative outcomes arising from broken DNA during cell division. Given that persistent broken DNA contributes to metastatic cancer, that FancD2 is linked to the childhood disease Fanconi Anemia, and the interest in Pol Theta and CRL4CDT2 as a promising cancer therapy targets, our work promises a significant impact on human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Gastric cancer develops within a carcinogenic cascade from pre-cancerous metaplasia to dysplasia and adenocarcinoma. While the pre-cancerous metaplasia is possibly reversible, a key cell population which is responsible for mucosal recovery or neoplastic progression is to be defined. In this study, we will define mechanisms that control the cell lineage conversion of reparative SPEM cells, which are a major cell component of dysplasia, towards incomplete IM and more cancerous cell lineages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Despite more than half of all cancer patients receiving radiotherapy as part of their treatment, the complex interactions between radiation and the immune system are poorly understood. Our Center will work to improve understanding of radiation effects on the immune system (tested first in pancreas and cervical cancer) and use that knowledge to propose new radiation treatment combinations to improve the outcomes of patients with advanced cancer. We will bring together a diverse group of experts from many fields, while teaching the next generation of researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Distinct epithelial stem/progenitor cell pools and/or their mesenchymal niches repopulate injured tissue depending on the extent and type of injury, and the outcomes of regeneration or fibrosis in response to severe alveolar epithelial injury is dependent in part on the dynamics of cell competition between these cell populations. In tissues harboring a mosaic imbalance in cMyc or Yap protein levels, cells with higher cMyc or nuclear Yap levels become super-competitors and expand at the expense of cells with lower levels, by eliminating them. This grant proposal seeks to manipulate the underlying mechanisms of cell competition to help prevent and treat IPF and ARDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to increase patient activation and facilitate early integration of palliative care among English- and Spanish-speaking Hispanic/Latino patients with metastatic cancer. Using a mixed-methods approach, patient and provider focus groups and usability testing will inform the development and cultural adaptation of a patient activation intervention that is individualized using EHR-integrated symptom monitoring. A pilot randomized controlled trial will evaluate acceptability and preliminary effects of patient activation intervention on proximal outcomes in the early phases of palliative care introduction and referral (e.g., health- related quality of life, patient-provider communication, shared decision-making, beliefs/attitudes regarding palliative care).

PHR: NF2 is a disease in which patients develop tumors originating from cells of the nervous system. These cells, as with virtually all cancer cells, are characterized by the breakdown of mechanisms that in normal cells ensure proliferation only under appropriate conditions. Our goals are to identify these mechanisms and the proteins involved so that these can be targeted therapeutically.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Connecting Veterans to meaningful employment is a goal of VA, which has long recognized the important relationship between work and health by providing vocational rehabilitation to Veterans with disabilities. Many Iraq and Afghanistan war Veterans have experienced polytrauma/traumatic brain injury (PT/TBI) and are unemployed and looking for work. Studies have shown that some individuals with PT/TBI have trouble finding or keeping jobs because of problems with headaches, concentration, memory, planning, and other symptoms resulting from the injury. Supported employment (SE) is an effective program that helps Veterans find work that is meaningful to them, and provides them with unlimited support and job coaching. The Veteran’s SE and treatment teams work together to develop strategies for success in the workplace. This study will provide SE services to Veterans with PT/TBI and measure their employment, health symptoms, and self-esteem over time, and how well the SE and PT/TBI teams work together.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to further our understanding of how bolus intravenous doses of N-acetyl-L-cysteine (L-NAC) to elicit immediate and sustained reversal of the deleterious effects of fentanyl infusion on breathing, arterial blood-gas chemistry and alveolar gas-exchange in rats without affecting fentanyl-induced analgesia. L-NAC is a clinically approved drug and could quickly enter clinical trials to assess its efficacy in human subjects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: GE MEDICAL SYSTEMS INFORMATION TECHNOLOGIES, INC
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE GE Research, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, and Stanford University propose to develop an ultra- efficient 4 MVA gradient driver using new silicon carbide technology that enables higher gradient performance and the accompanying tissue microstructure imaging in clinical whole-body MRI scanners with existing gradient coils, and first demonstrate its efficacy and clinical benefit on the diagnosis and grading of early-stage prostate cancer as a pilot application. This work will provide a widely adoptable pathway to upgrade the gradient performance of any clinical wide-bore whole-body MRI scanner with a higher power gradient driver without extensive and expensive facility electrical service and cooling modifications. Higher gradient performance enables new tissue microstructure imaging methods that provide improved sensitivity and specificity for cancer diagnosis, neuroimaging, and cardiac and vascular imaging in the clinic.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Affecting nearly 800,000 people in the US every year, stroke is a leading cause of long-term disability, and has serious consequences for stroke survivors and their carepartners. Our project uses a scientifically rigorous efficacy study to evaluate a remotely delivered dyadic (couples-based) positive psychology intervention to reduce emotional distress in stroke survivors and their carepartners. If successful, couples may be better emotionally equipped to cope with the sequelae of stroke, and have better rehabilitation outcomes and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The collection of molecules released into the extracellular environment by single cells, termed the single cell secretome, are windows into the complex milieu of proteins, RNA, metabolites, and other macromolecules which regulate cellular function. Up until now, secretome analysis has largely focused on secretions from populations of cells and use bulk measurement techniques that lack sensitivity. As a result, the single cell secretome is a blindspot in modern biology which will be rectified in this proposal using NanoSMS; a nanopore-based solution to secretome analysis and cellular fingerprinting.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Although cannabis use is common among Veterans with chronic pain, the harms (or benefits) of cannabis use among Veterans on long-term opioid therapy is unknown. Reported adverse events associated with use of Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), the active component in cannabis, include sedation, confusion, loss of balance, nausea, vomiting, and hallucination. These side effects suggest that cannabis, when used in combination with opioids—which also cause sedation, confusion, respiratory depression, nausea, vomiting and constipation— may be harmful. On the other hand, several studies suggest that state-based recreational legalization may be associated with a decrease in opioid related deaths. Thus, it is plausible that cannabis use, by reducing the use of opioids, reduces respiratory depression and the risk of overdose. This proposal is directly responsive to research gaps identified by VA practice guidelines on the management of Veterans with chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Public Heath relevance) The results of this investigation will provide a detailed understanding of the mechanisms regulating the motion of the CSF and the transport of all-important molecules along the spinal canal key to the functioning of the Central Nervous System (CNS). It accounts for the patient-specific anatomy and physiological conditions. It will also develop the modeling methodology necessary to optimize Intrathecal Drug Delivery (ITDD) protocols for the administration of potent analgesic agents for the amelioration of severe and chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This follow-up study of the well-characterized CHAP cohort will define the impact of preeclampsia and antihypertensive treatment during pregnancy on long-term risk for maternal cardiovascular outcomes and assess the predictive role of factors included in the ASCVD risk score for women aged <40 years. These results will help identify optimal blood pressure preventive strategies to enhance the long-term health of reproductive-aged women with CHTN.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Human genome engineering has widely anticipated promise as a healthcare strategy, but technologies in development are unlikely to safely or efficiently introduce a gene into the human genome. Starkly missing from transgene introduction strategies is an approach based on what is already quite successful across eukaryotic evolution: gene insertion by synthesis of an RNA-templated complementary DNA (cDNA). The evolutionary success of RNA template-specific, DNA site-specific LINE/non-LTR retroelement insertion begs to be engineered to develop a transgene introduction technology for human gene therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The central goal of this research is to deﬁne genes and principles that convert indolent prostate cancer into lethal metastatic disease. We use three separate approaches towards this goal: in Aim 1, we reveal, isolate, and analyze single pioneer cells in space and time, in Aim 2, we address the PTEN co-mutation impasse and deﬁne genes co-deleted with PTEN, and in Aim 3, we develop two new modeling platforms for more ﬂexible validation of candidate genes and principles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Invasive candidiasis is the most common form of invasive fungal disease. Prospective observational and randomized trials in children and adults have confirmed echinocandins as the antifungal of choice for primary treatment of candidemia. However, while 14 days of therapy is recommended, the optimal duration of therapy for candidemia remains unknown. The primary objective of the proposed randomized trial is to determine if 7 days of therapy is comparable to 14 days for for pediatric uncomplicated candidemia and if a molecular biomarker can provide supportive data for short course therapy.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Yellow fever results in approximately 200,000 cases and 30,000 deaths per year in South-Central America and Sub-Saharan Africa, with increasing potential for spread to Asia, Oceania, North America, and Europe. Death from yellow fever is correlated with liver damage and the development of hemorrhagic disease; however, the mechanisms underlying these disease processes have not been defined. In this study, we will identify key aspects of yellow fever disease progression that culminate in liver damage and hemorrhagic disease, leading to a better understanding of the disease and how it might be treated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative We have recently developed a new non-invasive brain stimulation (NIBS) system, kilohertz transcranial magnetic perturbation (kTMP) that opens up a new experimental space for safely modulating neural excitability in targeted areas of the human brain. This project will characterize the broad parameter space of kTMP in terms of tolerability and efficacy in healthy individuals. The results from this work will set the stage for full-fledged clinical trials in patients with neurological disorders such as stroke or spinal cord injury, two areas in which NIBS methods show promise as tools to facilitate neurorehabilitation.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Stanford Ellison Longitudinal Aging (SELA) cohort is a unique resource offering unprecedented opportunity to understand immune-aging. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many adult organs, including the intestine, grow and shrink repeatedly across an animal’s lifetime to respond to its dynamic functional needs. During physiological shrinkage, live cells are purged out of the tissue (extrusion) and stem cells are culled, yet we know virtually nothing about the mechanisms that underlie these size- controlling behaviors. Here, we will leverage powerful live imaging and analysis methods developed by my lab to address fundamental questions about cell extrusion and stem cell behaviors during intestinal shrinkage; the knowledge we generate will create a conceptual framework that will inform vertebrate and possibly human studies of the intestine in both health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CAR-T cell therapy has induced dramatic responses in hematological malignancies, representing one of the most remarkable therapeutic advances in the past decade, but efficacy in more common solid tumors has been limited by rapid dysfunction and poor persistence of tumor-infiltrating CAR-T cells. Successful tumor responses to immunotherapy are mediated by a subset of Tcf1+ T cells that resides in tumor-draining lymph nodes, where they retain the capacity to self-renew, proliferate, and continually differentiate into short-lived effector cells to sustain tumor killing. In this proposal, we will use a clinically relevant model of human lung cancer to investigate whether CAR-T cell activity is limited by inefficient formation of a Tcf1+ reservoir and whether this defect can be overcome using vaccination to expand lymph node reservoirs of Tcf1+ stem-like CAR-T cells, providing a strategy to enhance CAR-T cell efficacy that can be readily translated to the clinic to improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nitric oxide is a small molecule that is required for cell signaling. Unfortunately, researchers know very little about the concentration and movement of nitric oxide because of a lack of easy-to-use, real-time sensors. This project will use a single walled carbon nanotube sensor to create sensing platforms that can detect nitric oxide in vitro and in vivo as well as utilizing the sensors to investigate nitric oxide’s role in cellular functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE, OVERALL DNA repair structures and mechanisms are an essential component to understanding and treating cancer. Defects in DNA repair pathways, such as mutagenic or genetic deficiencies can predispose cells to initiate cancer. DNA repair can also work antagonistically against cancer treatments that damage DNA, and in such cases, known mutations of DNA repair proteins in specific cancer cells provide opportunities to develop effective treatments. SBDR-5 brings together the top laboratories in DNA repair through multi-disciplinary collaborations to define the complex and dynamic network of DNA repair machines and to develop an actionable, quantitative and mechanistic knowledge of DNA repair machines, pathways and intersections with DNA replication and other DNA-related processes to aid prediction and intervention for cancer biology.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: An estimated 20% or more of Post-9/11 Veterans have had at least one military-related traumatic brain injury (TBI). Veterans with TBI are often co-diagnosed with neurological, mental health, and pain disorders that interfere with daily functioning. The VA’s Polytrauma/TBI System of Care (PSC) is an interdisciplinary program designed to meet the needs of Veterans with TBI and maximize their health and functioning using evidence-based practices. However, since the passage of the Veterans Choice and MISSION Acts, many Veterans with TBI are also receiving services from the VA’s network of Community Care providers. Dual use of services can lead to fragmented care, which may be particularly detrimental to Veterans with complex healthcare needs. This study will describe the use of Community Care (e.g., rates and types of; reliance on) among Post-9/11 Veterans with TBI; estimate associations between their Community Care reliance and health and functioning; and examine their experiences and satisfaction with Community Care.

PHR: NARRATIVE - Project 2: DSBR: Mechanisms of DNA double strand break repair and pathway selection Most cancer patients are treated with DNA double strand break inducing radiation and chemotherapy. Project 2 aims to understand how normal and cancer cells detect and repair DNA double strand breaks by integration of three major cellular pathways, non-homologous end joining, homology-directed repair and alternative end joining, leading to novel insights into mechanism and uncovering new approaches for therapeutic targeting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Fragile X syndrome is the most common form of heritable intellectual disability and autism spectrum disorder. While this disease has been linked to instability and methylation of a short tandem repeat tract at a single gene, FMR1, we have shown that there are several other locations in the genome that are affected by pathologic Megabase-scale H3K9me3 deposition. Using cutting-edge genomics, mass spectrometry, and computational assays, we will investigate the RNA mechanisms driving heterochromatin-mediated gene silencing via inter-chromosomal interactions in fragile X syndrome.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Even young infants use race to categorize people, yet it is unclear how these perceptual tendencies translate to later social prejudice and stereotypes. The current project aims to examine the precursors of social biases across infancy to childhood by investigating infants’ cognitive inferences about racial groups and stranger fear toward people from different races. This work will elucidate the developmental trajectory of racial biases and how early social experience with racial diversity shapes infants’ emerging understanding of race.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project 3 - PARP: PAR-dependent, phase-transitioned protein assemblies and DNA repair PROJECT NARRATIVE Upon DNA damage, Poly-ADP-Ribose Polymerases (PARPs) generate polymers that seed the formation of phase condensates–highly concentrated yet fluid compartments of proteins at DNA damage sites. However, the functions of these specialized compartments in DNA repair is not understood. Understanding how PAR-seeded phase condensates regulate DNA repair pathways is critical because PARP inhibitors are increasingly used as cancer therapeutics. We propose to answer these fundamental questions by investigating the structural basis for the polymers, their effects on phase condensates, and the consequences for DNA repair in human cells. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE  The fungal cell wall is the interface between the cell and its environment. In pathogenic fungi, proper function of the cell wall is important for survival in the host, and drugs targeting cell wall assembly are effective antifungal agents. The spores of baker's yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae are not pathogenic but are surrounded by a complex coat, the spore wall, which includes many of the same components found in the walls of pathogenic fungi. We are using spore wall formation as a model system to unravel the biochemistry and genetics of fungal wall assembly. This application focuses on understanding how a conserved set of proteins localized on lipid droplets promote the formation of a specific structural feature in the cell wall.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Recent studies suggest that in addition to insufficient insulin, abnormal glucagon secretion from pancreatic β-cells may also play a central role in the cause and complications of diabetes. Despite significant progress in our understanding of this important hormone, the cellular and molecular mechanisms that regulate glucagon secretion from β-cells remain largely unknown. Elucidation of these mechanisms will provide new therapeutic targets for the regulation of glucagon secretion that can be used for novel treatment strategies in both Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes.

PHR: Project Narrative This competitive renewal application will continue to train highly skilled scientist scholars from diverse backgrounds who will have a future impact on health care equity, quality, and accessibility for diverse communities. IRACDA NY-CAPS Scholars will benefit from a comprehensive research and teacher training program that will make them competitive in the academic job market; and as faculty, they will be in the best position to generate new scopes of research and transmit cutting-edge developments to a future generation of diverse students in the biomedical sciences. Ultimately, the NY-CAPS program will help to generate a new and diverse workforce of highly talented Americans that are fully engaged in issues of public health and this will bring special attention to issues of health disparities in underserved communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Toward precision medicine and precision disease prevention, the overarching goal of this proposal is to develop innovative statistical methods for accurate risk prediction. We address three challenges that plague studies on the value of new predictors that adds to standard predictors for improving predictive accuracy: lack of independent validation data, lack of statistical methods for developing risk prediction models using individually-matched case-control data, and lack of statistical methods to guide study design beyond standard power calculation for testing predictor-outcome association. We will develop innovative statistical methods to address these challenges. Our methods, accompanied by user-friendly software, are expected to facilitate cost effective and timely biomarker evaluation for predicting binary outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Congenital heart defects are present in 1-2 out of 100 births, and are caused by mutations in genes that may control the 3-dimensional organization of chromosomes. We will use human cellular models and Artificial Intelligence to understand how chromosome organization is controlled during heart development and altered by disease processes. This will reveal fundamental concepts of gene regulation and may lead to a better understanding congenital heart defects towards improving diagnosis and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE - CORE 3: Administrative Core (ADM) The overall goal of this Program Project on “Structural Cell Biology of DNA Repair Machines” (SBDR) is to develop detailed structural and mechanistic understanding of the multi-protein machines that carry out DNA repair processes in human cells. These results will advance cancer intervention through the identification of specific ways to control biological outcomes of cellular responses to DNA damage and to exploit specific cancer cell vulnerabilities. This effort involves experimental cycles between structural and functional studies in four Projects with 18 senior investigators. The ADM Core enables this multi-institutional effort by providing overall management of SBDR, facilitating communications, and fostering Program integration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: The MSK Genomic Data Analysis Center for Tumor Evolution will create a software platform for analysis of DNA mutations in cancer to help researchers and clinicians better understand why cancers often relapse. As cancer is a disease that changes at the cellular level over time, with some cells killed by treatment while others survive, we need to understand which mutations lead to treatment failure in specific patients. We expect that with improved tools that can measure, monitor and interpret changes in disease over time, we will make advances that allow for better management of cancer and prevention of relapse.

PHR: Narrative Women of reproductive age with type 2 diabetes are at greater risk for a number of negative health and reproductive outcomes. We developed the Promoting REproductive Planning And REadiness in Diabetes (PREPARED) strategy to [1] promote medication safety, [2] prompt provider preconception counseling, and [3] deliver patient-friendly educational tools and post-visit text messages to support diabetes self-care. We will test the effectiveness of PREPARED, against usual care, to improve patient knowledge of reproductive risks and recommended self-care activities, engagement in diabetes self-management behaviors, and glycemic control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Allergic reactions to peanuts and tree nuts are a major health problem for which current treatments are inadequate. This project will establish a new intellectual framework regarding allergen/IgE interactions, describe, at least in part, the molecular basis for co-allergies among tree nuts and peanuts, design new diagnostics and move us along the path toward development of an oral, peptide based, treatment for peanut allergy.

PHR: Project Narrative Vitamin A is essential for the development of adaptive immunity in the intestine. This project will define the biochemical, cell biological, and microbiological mechanisms that regulate vitamin A delivery to the intestinal immune system, and will determine how these mechanisms affect the development of adaptive immunity. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE For 25 years, the RCMAR Center for Aging in Diverse Communities (CADC) at the University of California San Francisco has been successfully delivering a robust mentoring and training program and providing a culture of equity and inclusion for early career researchers from diverse backgrounds who will enhance the aging-research workforce. In this renewal, CADC’s multidisciplinary faculty have the experience and expertise to train and mentor this next generation of researchers focused on aging-related health disparities. Through impactful research, CADC Faculty and Scientists will contribute to improving the health status for older adults in diverse populations and achieving health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to develop a new molecular strategy to limit subretinal fibrosis in blinding eye disease. PFKFB3 (6-phosphofructo-2-kinase/fructose-2, 6-bisphosphatase isoform 3) is a critical regulator/activator of glycolysis. The proposed studies are designed to use Pfkfb3 deficient mice and PFKFB3 knockdown/overexpressing RPE cells to investigate the involvement of glycolysis in RPE cells in subretinal fibrosis and to define the underlying mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Obesity is a major public health problem because of its high prevalence and causal relationship with serious medical diseases. Here, we will investigate how the release and function of the neurotransmitter dopamine is altered in the brains of obese mice, and how to rescue these changes to drive weight loss. This work is critical for understanding how obesity changes brain systems that govern feeding, and how to modify these systems to improve weight loss outcomes for people with obesity.

PHR: The project will use a mixed-methods approach to examine the influence of actual and perceived immigration laws on Latinx immigrants' willingness to engage in three central population-level communicable disease management efforts—screening, contact tracing, and treatment. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROGRAM NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health as an urgent medical need exists to develop novel therapeutics to improve post-stroke recovery by mitigating the severity of ischemic brain damage. A unique therapeutic target, mitoNEET, has been identified and a novel tool, NL-1, has been developed to gain a better understanding of how mitoNEET modulation reduces stroke neuropathology and improves functional outcomes in aged male and female rats following MCAO. The proposed research is relevant to the missions of the NIA and NINDS by conducting basic science research aimed at improving the devastating effects caused by acute ischemic stroke and is relevant to the NIH by improving health by developing a library of compounds that can be employed as tools, probes and possibly therapeutics that will improve health through innovative research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Report Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) are major public health problems. More work is needed to understand how to reduce the risk of heart attack and stroke in these patients particularly in people who have the overlap syndrome (OVS) of OSA plus COPD. Our research will help to raise awareness regarding OVS and how best to address OVS in individuals at risk of these complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This exploratory project will use repeated nationally representative data from population-based HIV surveys to develop a cohort model with age-stratified transmission risk to predict the age distribution of HIV prevalence over time and the projected burden of noncommunicable diseases among people living with HIV. The construction of sex stratified one year age group sexual network profiles will enable more accurate transmission risk probabilities for the cohort model as well as allow for analysis of changes in sexual networks over time and factors associated with specific categories of sexual networks. The prediction of noncommunicable disease burden will be critical for resource planning and allocation and provide a foundation to accelerate health system response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Molecular chaperones Hsp70s and Hsp110s form an essential chaperone machinery that plays multiple vital roles in maintaining cellular protein homeostasis, a fundamental cellular process that is inevitably linked to many human diseases including fungal infections. In this proposal, we aim to understand the basic molecular mechanism and function of Hsp110s in the Hsp70s/Hsp110s chaperone machinery using a unique and novel chemical tool that we recently identified, and thereby provide crucial insights into how to target them for treating fungal infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE BioAesthetics seeks to improve outcomes for patients with full-thickness burn wounds by creating a dermal acellular biologic graft with a biocompatible, biodegradable, tunable hydrogel-based drug delivery system that provides sustained, local release of therapeutic agents. Our novel approach simultaneously provides a natural, biologic scaffold for patient-mediated tissue regeneration while countering the onset of complications due to infection during the course of wound healing. This Phase II project focuses on advancing our R&D efforts in a porcine burn model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis is a leading cause of mortality and critical illness worldwide, with recognition that it may lead to a profound and sustained immunosuppression known as immune paralysis (IP). There is a critical need to understand the underlying pathophysiology of sepsis-induced IP, with evidence now emerging that fatty acids (FA) and their metabolites are important immune signaling molecules and regulators of cytokine release. The goal of this proposal is to characterize metabolic and protein biomarkers of sepsis-induced IP by quantifying FA metabolites in circulating leukocytes and evaluating the role of immune paralyzed response proteins in the plasma of septic IP patients, thus identifying modifiable pathways that may be targeted to improve clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite epidemiologic data consistently identifying sleep disruption and sleep disorders as a cardiovascular (CV) risk, rigorous investigation of the inclusion of these parameters in current CV risk prediction models has yet to be performed. We plan to leverage artificial intelligence modeling from a clinic-based cohort of >186,000 multimodal cardiorespiratory and neurologic physiologic signals from sleep studies database to investigate whether sleep-specific phenotypic represent independent risk factors for major adverse cardiovascular events and enhance the standard atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) calculator. Data generated has high potential to be transformative in terms of informing CV risk stratification and design of sleep-specific CV clinical trials, setting the stage for external validation, and providing a basis to effectively harness the rich information contained in the >1.1 million polysomnograms performed annually in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health This project is a pivotal initiative by the American Association for Cancer Research since racial and ethnic minorities remain underrepresented as faculty in the field of cancer research. It is imperative to continue to increase the diversity and visibility of faculty members in the field. One of the most important aims of this award program is to facilitate networking and collaboration opportunities for minority faculty and faculty at Minority-Serving Institutions with the wide range of cancer researchers throughout the world. This is not just a necessity for minority faculty, but also essential for faculty at minority-serving institutions. Beyond the direct benefits to Scholar Awardees, the program has potentially wider implications for the health status of the minority population in general, resulting from the formation of a larger pool of experienced minority basic cancer researchers and clinicians to contribute, thrive, and gain health equity in the field. The enhancement of the MSI faculty member’s research program enriches the experience of the minority students he or she trains. Additionally, minority investigators are more likely to explore the issues relating to minority health disparities, as well as to have a better prospect of recruiting and collaborating with minority study subjects, and a significant increase in the number and visibility of minority cancer researchers might serve as an effective antidote to attitudes of distrust on the part of study participants and help lead to greater trust on the part of minorities in the medical and research institutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Co-use of alcohol and cannabis (using both substances, either simultaneously or concurrently) represents a significant public health concern among young adults (YAs), as co-use is common and can exacerbate negative use-related outcomes, and existing interventions produce small effects. Romantic relationships are important and developmentally-salient influences on YA substance use and represent a potential intervention area that could increase engagement and maximize effects; despite this, there is a paucity of research on the extent to which romantic relationships impact alcohol and cannabis co-use behaviors or intervention outcomes among YAs. The present study seeks to significantly expand our understanding of alcohol and cannabis co- use in the context of YA romantic relationships through collecting daily dyadic quantitative data and qualitative interviews and using this information to develop and pilot an integrated brief intervention to decrease alcohol and cannabis misuse and increase healthy relationships skills among this understudied, high-risk group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Sickle cell disease (SCD), which results from a genetic mutation that allows hemoglobin (Hb) to self-assemble into rigid polymers that cause red blood cells (RBCs) to become malformed (“sickled”), affects approximately 100,000 Americans (and millions worldwide). Our scientific team has spent nearly three decades developing novel drugs that can block Hb polymerization, and consequently, RBC sickling, and our next generation drug candidates are groundbreaking because they have the potential to profoundly modify the natural history of the disease state and transform SCD into a manageable condition. Our team plans to advance two bona fide lead drug candidates into a robust and definitive panel of pre-clinical studies to demonstrate the extraordinary potential of these leads and to select one final lead candidate for human clinical trials.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  The public health relevance of this study relates to the persistent problem of undernutrition among very preterm infants, those born prior to 32 weeks of gestation. The proposed study will examine how the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) diet and patterns of growth during the hospitalization contribute to, or protect against, the development of excess adiposity and cardiometabolic risk during early childhood (ages 2 and 5 years). Results from this study will inform new and more effective strategies for nutritional support, assessment, and monitoring of very preterm infants. The overall goal is for pragmatic, diet-based interventions during a sensitive period in development that support optimal long-term health for the ~63,000 very preterm infants born each year in the U.S. and many more worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The Nuclear Pore Complex (NPC) is a large megadalton cellular assembly composed of ∼550 proteins, that degrades structurally and compositionally with age, causing severe difficulties with cellular processes. The elusive ultrastructural and compositional degradation of NPC and their building components will be imaged using a combination of cryo-Focused Ion Beam milling-Electron Tomography (cryo-FIB-ET) and single-molecule imaging. With training from diverse group of mentors/advisors, this proposal will lay the groundwork for a new research program that will use these cutting-edge imaging modalities to map important ultrastructural/compositional cellular alterations caused by aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This advanced research education program concentrates on a uniquely vulnerable population— pregnant people who abuse substances and their babies who suffer from drug withdrawal and is responsive to PAR-21- 320. “Forefronts in Substance Abuse Disorders during Pregnancy, Postpartum, and Pediatrics (FrSADP3)” requests its first renewal within NIDA’s Research Education Program and the primary rationale is that there are too few underrepresented minority (URM) clinicians and clinical researchers, too few clinical and research programs investigating substance use (SU) and abuse (SA), and especially, substance abuse disorders (SAD) during pregnancy, postpartum, and pediatrics (P3) as well as there being far too few new URM trainees for clinical and clinical research careers within the SADP3 fields. By continuing to educate and mentor clinical researchers and clinicians, especially graduate, medical, dental, nursing, and other advanced students as well as postdoctoral fellows from under-represented minorities exclusively at minority serving institutions, this program will help to advance the research careers of the most promising clinical scientists and clinicians, with sensitivity to ensuring full diversity in the NIDA workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study is distinctive, innovative, and relevant to public health in light of the limited knowledge of sleep deficiency and its relationship to the social and physical environment during incarceration and after release from a correctional facility. The project is relevant to NHLBI’s mission-driven strategic goals to address sleep health disparities, given the disproportionate incarceration of racial and ethnic minoritized groups. This work aims to understand how incarceration uniquely affects sleep health at the individual, environmental and institutional levels, which can become the foundation of future work to decrease sleep and CVD morbidity and mortality for NIH disparity populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transcatheter arterial embolization using calibrated microsphere technology represents a remarkably successful chapter in minimally invasive interventions to treat various conditions ranging from arteriovenous malformations to hypervascular tumors. Although several types of embolic microspheres have been FDA authorized, clinicians have no technology for estimating the trajectory of emboli and as such significant uncertainty exists in embolization. To address the aforementioned issues, we propose to develop a two-way interactive biomaterial- computational platform to generate effective injection map, while also providing physicians insight into success rate for both informed and randomized injection in different vasculature for personalized embolization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE (PUBLIC RELEVANCE) Allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) is a potentially curative therapy for many inherited and malignant diseases whose applicability has been impeded by the development of one of its most serious complication, chronic graft versus host disease (cGVHD). Unfortunately, there is no blood test for predicting response to cGVHD therapies. Strategies that identify and validate predictive biomarkers of cGVHD response to treatment will allow for personalized therapies that will be more efficient if introduced early in the course of the disease in many patients with hematological cancers.
