IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Racial and ethnic disparities impact end-of-life care in nursing homes, including the use of hospice, a government benefit program that provides end-of-life services delivered by an interdisciplinary specialist team. Although hospice decreases illness burden and improves quality of life, there is little information on why it is not used more frequently. By analyzing large national nursing home datasets and examining qualitative data, our study will address this gap and provide evidence needed to promote equitable access to hospice in nursing homes nationwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the United States has a stated goal of reducing new HIV infections by 90% over ten years, efforts are hampered by lack of information on where undiagnosed cases are to be found. Wastewater (sewage) surveillance is proving to be an exciting new public health tool for identifying communities where infectious diseases are circulating. We propose to test the feasibility of detecting HIV in human waste and in wastewater as first steps in establishing a surveillance system that can enhance HIV prevention and control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE—RELEVANCE TO HEALTH  Bystander cardiopulmonary resuscitation (B-CPR) is the most effective treatment for out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA); however, the likelihood of receiving B-CPR and surviving OHCA varies significantly based on neighborhood demographics. Our research is designed to identify modifiable barriers to B-CPR participation in at-risk neighborhoods, and adapt a targeted, culturally sensitive, community-level intervention designed to improve B-CPR participation and OHCA survival in underserved populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Colonic neoplasia, from adenoma to carcinoma exhibits “niche independence” where normal regulatory mechanisms involving Wnt signaling for cell proliferation are unchecked, resulting in tumors. Strategies to inhibit such signaling have not worked therapeutically, however, increasing Wnt signaling even further in tumors has a non-intuitive result where they end up ultimately inhibited. In contrast, normal colonic epithelium has improved growth with increased Wnt signaling. This proposal seeks to leverage this phenomenon to inhibit colon cancer but improve normal colon cell function, which may unlock a new paradigm of colon cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Patients with skeletal dysplasias, including osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), often suffer from congenital respiratory problems that have limited therapeutic opportunities, and increase perinatal and early childhood mortality. With the long-term goal of identifying novel therapeutic approaches to treat the respiratory disease and prevent morbidity and mortality in OI, the specific goals of this proposal are to dissect the contribution of intrinsic lung defects versus extrinsic skeletal defects to impaired lung functions in OI; and to unravel cellular and molecular mechanisms triggered by type I collagen defects leading to abnormal lung development and impaired respiratory function. Collectively, our studies will lead to a better understanding of lung pathogenesis in OI and other skeletal dysplasias, and the role of the extracellular matrix during alveolar formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: This project aims to develop efficient and robust methods for the design and analysis of cardiovascular (CV) clinical trials with complex composite endpoints that combine patient mortality with lesser events like hospitalization. Specifically, it addresses the nonparametric estimation of effect size (overall and subgroup-wise), sample size calculation under both fixed and adaptive designs, semiparametric regression, and risk prediction. The new methods will not only help improve the analyses of recent CV trials like INVESTED, but also in the long run helps to shift the paradigm towards fuller and more meaningful utilization of patient data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a common form of severe lung injury that occurred in 10% of pre- pandemic ICU admissions, results in mortality of 30-45%, and has become a leading cause of death from COVID- 19. This multicenter randomized controlled trial evaluates whether a novel ventilation strategy that individualizes support to minimize lung stress, compared to guided usual care, improves survival and pulmonary recovery in ventilator-dependent patients with ARDS. Results from this trial may establish a personalized approach to ARDS management that reduces morbidity and mortality and, by extension, decreases costs and strain on the healthcare system.

PHR: Over 40,000 women die every year from aggressive therapy-resistant metastatic breast cancer. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE The goal of the Longevity, Equity, and Aging Research Network (L.E.A.R.N) Consortium RCMAR is to advance the health and wellbeing of diverse older Americans by (a) facilitating multi-institutional, trans-disciplinary, collaborative ethnogeriatrics health disparities research that integrates biological, social, behavioral, and cultural aspects using various innovative research methods and (b) diversifying the future workforce in aging research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The central nervous system control of whole-body metabolism has been an appealing area to develop interventions against obesity and related metabolic disorders. Results from the proposed studies will establish an anatomic and mechanistic link between the ventromedial hypothalamus, body weight control, and metabolic homeostasis. It will provide insights into novel therapeutics to treat obesity with limited adverse effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric patients undergoing spinal fusion surgery for the correction of Adolescent Idiopathic Scoliosis are at high risk of both preexisting and surgery-related iron deficiency, yet the means and evidence for optimizing iron status have not been described in this setting. The proposed study is a randomized controlled trial of preoperative oral iron supplementation, to identify whether iron deficiency is a modifiable risk factor for adverse surgical outcomes such as red blood cell transfusion and diminished postoperative cognitive and physical capacity in this vulnerable population of adolescents. Building evidence for patient blood management interventions such as iron supplementation is vital to ensuring high quality care of surgical patients and may reduce unnecessary transfusions amid recent blood shortages.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurodevelopmental disorders affect ~3-18% of children worldwide and are heavily biased towards males early in life. Growing evidence suggests that early-life experiences, such as infection during the perinatal period, can have a profound, life-long impact on brain development and behavior. In this proposal, we will examine how sex differences in brain development increase male vulnerability to such early-life immune perturbations, with promise to provide novel therapeutic targets and preventative interventions for these children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Many individuals infected with COVID-19 report persistent complaints of brain fog (attention and memory problems) and debilitating fatigue weeks/months after recovering from the initial infection, which greatly overlap with typical symptoms of myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS). The proposed work will use brain imaging, electroencephalography (EEG) and immunological analysis to measure and identify inflammation markers and brain activity patterns that underlie brain fog symptoms in individuals with ME/CFS and long COVID. Our study will identify biomarkers underlying patients’ cognitive symptoms and lay the groundwork for potential treatments that can target these biomarkers in future clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  An aberrant immune response to injury is a crucial pathogenic driver of acute lung injury (clinically known as acute respiratory distress syndrome) and fibrotic lung diseases. However, there is currently no clinical technique for non-invasive assessment of lung inflammation, which has challenged the development of a precision medicine approach to acute respiratory distress syndrome and fibrotic lung diseases. This proposal is aimed to validate the role of targeted imaging of chemokine like receptor-1 (CMKLR1, a relatively recently discovered chemokine receptor contributing to leukocyte recruitment) for quantitative monitoring of lung inflammation, risk stratification of the disease, and monitoring the therapeutic response in experimental models of acute lung injury and fibrotic lung diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) is the deadliest and most difficult-to-treat subtype of lung cancer with a standard-of-care that has remained largely unchanged for decades. Arginine deprivation by pegylated arginine deiminase (ADI-PEG20) is the most effective targeted therapy in preclinical studies of MYC-driven SCLC, but tumors eventually become resistant to ADI-PEG20. In accordance with NIH’s mission to advance human health, this study will interrogate mechanisms of ADI-PEG20 resistance to identify therapeutic strategies that prolong the efficacy of ADI-PEG20 and improve survival of patients with SCLC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Macrophages are key orchestrators of inflammatory responses in the lung, and they are important contributors to ARDS and ARDS resolution. MEK1 and MEK2 are protein kinases that regulate important cellular functions, and our data implicate MEK pathways as key factors directing macrophage polarization and ALI duration. This proposal will uncover a novel pathway by which inflammatory diseases in the lung may be modified.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will employ pupillometry to examine the function of the melanopsin-expressing intrinsically photosensitive Retinal Ganglion Cells (ipRGC) that are critical for the normal function of the circadian system. The experiments will provide novel insights into mechanisms of circadian dysregulation across the continuum of PD and the contribution of circadian dysregulation to poor sleep and sleepiness, common and disabling symptoms associated with PD. Results from this study will further explore the eye (retina) and the circadian system as novel therapeutic targets in PD and guide the development of circadian-based treatments to improve the daily lives of patients with PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Fundamental questions for HIV cure research are: how does the size of viral reservoirs impact people with HIV's ability to prevent viral rebound or control virus replication after stopping antiretroviral therapy (ART)? In this study, we use a unique monkey model to determine how progressively smaller viral reservoirs affect the durable control virus replication after discontinuing ART.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer screening efficacy is highly dependent on adherence to recommended guidelines, with annual screening indicated for approximately 90% of all individuals who receive baseline scans. Initial reports of real- world screening implementation show adherence to annual screening guidelines are less than 50%, demonstrating a critical need for improvement to optimize the individual and population health benefits of lung cancer screening. I aim to address the urgent need for low-cost, feasible, and effective interventions focused on facilitating lung cancer screening adherence by developing and implementing a set of clear and engaging reminder messages that target and tailor information specific to lung cancer screening participants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  We develop a cell-based system that is as good as live animal models in evaluating any mutation in major clock genes, which used to be done in live animals. Many human mutations will be precisely evaluated by the system for their pathogenesis and the results will inform affected humans with pathogenic mutations in clock genes identified by the study.

PHR: Many studies have shown that the progression of varies substantially from patient to patient. It is important to identify subpopulations who may benefit from the investigational treatment. Subgroup identification can help clinicians select patients who are most likely to have a positive response to a treatment. It may also inform the development of new therapeutic agents that can improve the treatment of AD. In this proposal, we will use the tree-based and the regression-based methods to select responsive subgroups and characterize individual heterogeneity. Our methods will be illustrated using large amounts of individual level clinical trial data for investigational drugs including donepezil, solanezumab, and gantenerumab.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emphysema is one of the leading causes of morbidity and mortality worldwide, and there are currently no treatments available to reverse the resulting lung damage. This study aims to find new biomarkers that can predict the early onset of emphysema, distinguish between its diverse pathologic patterns and their regional distributions, and provide insights into the underlying pathobiology. A better understanding of emphysema and its subtypes will aid in the development of novel and personalized therapies to improve the health of millions of affected individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The proper function of adipose tissue is essential for metabolic health and depends on close interactions of diverse cell types in the tissue microenvironment. This project will examine how close (micrometer-scale) cellular interactions in adipose tissue regulate the establishment, expansion, and pathophysiological remodeling fat tissues. This analysis will provide new insights into how fat tissue contributes to metabolic heath, and might lead to strategies to combat obesity-related metabolic diseases like diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Physical activity can benefit brain health by reducing the risk of dementia, improving cognition, and enhancing sleep quality in typically developed adults, but less is known about the impact of physical activity on brain health in adults with Down syndrome. The aim of this research is to develop and validate an objective assessment of physical activity in adults with Down syndrome using portable accelerometers before exploring the impact of physical activity on plasma biomarkers associated with Alzheimer’s disease, cognitive function, and sleep quality in adults with Down syndrome. This study will inform future physical activity research focused on preventing, delaying, or slowing the progression of Alzheimer’s disease in adults with Down syndrome and has the potential to be transferable to other health-related outcomes in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project will address a critical gap in knowledge and care for liver transplant recipients with alcohol use disorder. We will develop and pilot test an integrated intervention for liver transplant and alcohol recovery centered around a community health worker providing coordinated care for patients after liver transplantation. The results of this project have the potential to improve access, equity, and long-term outcomes for the growing number of patients suffering from alcohol use disorder and alcohol associated liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Vascular anastomosis – the joining of two blood vessels using stitches – plays a central role in numerous life-saving surgeries, but has serious associated complications and long recovery times. These issues are currently addressed by the application of fibrin glues, but these materials have limited practical application due to cold chain requirements and short work time, and their high-density produces suboptimal healing outcomes. This proposed research will develop a novel colloidal microporous fibrin-based nanoparticle surgical sealant with improved work time and enhanced drug delivery profiles that boasts superior wound healing capabilities compared to traditional fibrin glues, allowing for faster operating times, fewer complications, improved recovery, and more widespread access by removing cold-chain requirements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is a leading cause of adult mortality and health inequity in the United States, with African Americans at the highest risk for CVD and African American youth at the highest risk for CVD risk factors. This research examines the relationship between structural racism (i.e., neighborhood-level racial disparities in the educational, employment, housing, and law enforcement systems) and biobehavioral processes involved in early CVD progression, including metabolic syndrome, endothelial function, and inflammation, and also tests inflammation as a possible mechanism explaining the association between structural racism and cardiometabolic health (i.e., metabolic syndrome and endothelial function) across 2 samples of African American youth and young adults over time. Examining the relationship between structural racism and biobehavioral processes involved in early CVD progression among African American youth has potential to provide significant impacts in terms of the prevention of CVD in future work.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiac arrest survival remains unacceptably poor and currently no drugs exist that improve long-term survival with favorable neurological outcome. Agents such as TAT-PHLPP9c that target metabolic dysfunction may significantly improve outcomes and decrease the circuit flow rate required for successful extracorporeal cardiopulmonary resuscitation (eCPR), thereby broadening the availability of eCPR to wider populations including underserved areas. The main objective of this project is to evaluate the protective mechanism of TAT- PHLPP9c and its ability to improve the efficiency of eCPR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project narrative Sarcopenia is a leading cause of death and disability worldwide in older individuals, and it affects up to 25% of the population aged 70 and over. The ability to non-invasively image the earliest changes in sarcopenia progression is a critical unmet need that will help identify patients who can benefit the most from timely interventions. This work aims to develop a novel Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) approach to study muscle quality as an early marker of sarcopenia progression, to provide new insight into sarcopenia pathogenesis and lead to timely intervention strategies to arrest the onset and progression of sarcopenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative Adolescent girls and young women living with HIV (AGYWLHIV) who have experienced intimate partner violence (IPV) have greater challenges in accessing healthcare for HIV, taking medication for HIV, and they have worse treatment outcomes. Male partner alcohol use directly and indirectly increases IPV risk among AGYWLHIV. This study will develop and pilot test a couples-based intervention to help AGYWLHIV (15-24 years) access HIV care and improve the outcomes of their HIV treatment by targeting male partner alcohol use to reduce IPV risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Pediatric cardiac arrest affects thousands of children each year and for those who survive, many are left with significant neurologic injury. These clinical studies will inform our understanding of how cerebral physiology is impaired after cardiac arrest and identify mechanisms of preventable brain injury. The results will potentially lead to personalized cerebral physiology-targeted clinical trials to improve clinical outcomes from pediatric cardiac arrest.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than 300,000 older Americans are diagnosed with end-stage kidney disease and treated with long-term hemodialysis each year; the hemodialysis vascular access is their lifeline. Thus, identifying the type of dialysis vascular access that offers better patient outcomes is a public health priority. This multicenter randomized clinical trial will compare two vascular access placement interventions (fistula versus graft) in older patients; results will help us understand the relationships between vascular access type and clinical, economic, and patient-reported outcomes in this vulnerable and understudied population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Visual deficits cause morbidity, decrease quality of life and have a significant societal burden. In addition, the visual system is a unique, easily-accessed portal with which to detect, diagnose and monitor many systemic diseases. The University of Rochester’s Center for Visual Science T32 provides interdisciplinary training in advanced optical technology for vision correction and retinal imaging, cell biology and neural mechanisms of both normal and diseased vision, and the role of vision in behavior for graduate students and post-docs of 28 faculty mentors.
PROJECT_TERMS: Training;vision science
PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Vision Science

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a devastating and progressive disease without a cure with an increasing prevlance. Aberrant oxidative neuroinflammation such as that driven by myeloperoxidase is a key early event in the development of Alzheimer's disease (AD). The goal of this proposal is to develop a noninvasive positron emission tomography (PET) imaging method to quantify and monitor myeloperoxidase-mediated oxidative stress in the AD brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Transthyretin Amyloidosis with cardiac myopathy, ATTR-CM, represent a serious healthcare issue. ATTR-CM is involved in 13% of heart failure, 16% of transcatheter aortic-valve replacement, and 5% of individuals with presumed hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The primary challenge is that most patients are undiagnosed or their diagnosis is delayed for multiple years. Atomo, in partnership with PENN Medicine, will develop an AI-based Clinical Decision Support Solution called “PERCEPTION” that will flag probable yet undiagnosed ATTR individuals before they develop CM so they can be clinically evaluated and receive the proper diagnosis and therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal seeks to identify genetic variances in the metabolism abiraterone, an androgen synthesis inhibitor, that can be used to identify abiraterone metabolites that may hasten disease progression. A clinical trial tests the efficacy of inhibiting metabolism of an active metabolite that may worsen outcomes. If positive, this trial of pharmacologic 5 alpha reductase inhibition may prolong the sensitivity to abiraterone in certain patients, delaying progression of the disease, symptoms and death and would validate the targeting of active abiraterone metabolites in this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: This proposed research is relevant to public health because it is expected to identify the mechanism(s) that result in maladaptive lung fibroblast differentiation and extra cellular matrix deposition, which can be found in chronic neonatal lung diseases, such as Bronchopulmonary Dysplasia, and adult-onset fibrotic lung diseases, such as idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. Development of regenerative therapies, leading to restoration of lung structure and function, in chronic lung diseases will need to be guided by insights into the mechanistic underpinnings of defective alveolarization. The proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission pertaining to developing fundamental knowledge that will inform the upstream regulation and downstream function of matrix fibroblasts with the ultimate objective to restore a microenvironment that is permissive for alveolar repair and allow for better engraftment in cell replacement approaches using iPSC derived cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The proposed project aims to address the current absence of a culturally and contextually relevant, and validated tool to measure readiness for change (RFC) among non-specialist health workers (such as community health workers) for the adoption and successful implementation of mental health task-sharing. Such a measurement tool is relevant to public health because it could lead to systematic investigation of strategies to build RFC in this population and enhance their adoption of mental health task-sharing and the fidelity with which they deliver it. This will ultimately help alleviate the challenges brought upon by the dearth of mental health professionals globally, including low-resource settings in the United States, and thus, the proposed research is also relevant to the part of NIMH's strategic plan to build models to scale-up evidence-based practices for use in routine care settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative There are currently no FDA-approved therapies for Type I hyperlipoproteinemia, a rare, autosomal recessive metabolic disorder characterized by extreme hypertriglyceridemia due to a deficiency of lipoprotein lipase or related proteins. Our recent preliminary data in two children and an adult with T1HLP revealed 46-60% reduction in fasting serum triglycerides with Orlistat with only minimal side effects. Therefore, we wish to study the long-term efficacy and safety of orlistat for reducing serum triglyceride levels in patients with T1HLP in a randomized, double- blind, placebo-controlled, cross-over trial with an open-label extension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Public Health Relevance Inhibitory circuits in the auditory tectothalamic pathway critically shape speech and vocalization processing, sound localization and other neural computations that are crucial for hearing. This proposal aims to determine how GABA and NPY signaling, from a distinct class of inferior colliculus (IC) neurons, work in concert to shape sound processing in the IC and auditory thalamus. Furthermore, this proposal will determine how NPY signaling can enhance detection of auditory cues in a mouse model of aging. The results of this proposal will provide important new information about how a defined inhibitory neural circuit contributes to the ability of IC and thalamic neurons to produce selective responses to communication sounds. In addition, this research will provide a mechanistic foundation for the development of therapeutic agents to manipulate inhibitory signaling to improve hearing for those who suffer from age-related hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic infection with hepatitis B virus (HBV) presents a global public health burden affecting 296 million individuals worldwide, who are at high risk of developing severe liver diseases, including cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma, and will die without therapeutic intervention or liver transplantation. Our proposed research seeks to render woodchucks susceptible to HBV infection by modifying either the virus or host. Our project will provide a much-needed animal model for developing new, curative HBV-specific drugs for the treatment of patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Rift Valley fever virus is a mosquito-borne virus present throughout Africa that causes significant disease; infection of the brain is a complication of disease that can lead to death or disability. In this project we will define how the virus travels from the site of infection in the skin to the brain and will identify which cells need to be infected by the virus for entry into the brain to occur. Understanding how the virus gets to the brain is a necessary first step to enable development of therapies to prevent this complication of disease.

There is strong evidence that poor sleep quality accelerates the progression of Alzheimer’s disease. To help slow the advancement of Alzheimer’s disease, we are developing a wearable peripheral neuromodulation device to improve sleep and reduce the burden of this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Nighttime suppression of melatonin production by retinal light exposure poses health risks to nightshift workers like nurses, who are habitually exposed to high nighttime ambient light levels and specific short- wavelength (blue) light emitted by self-luminous computer displays. Our innovative research project proposes an unprecedented combination of two strategies – 1) use of blue-blocking filters, and 2) monocular circadian light exposures, in an attempt to preserve nighttime melatonin levels in night shift working nurses without compromising their visual and operating performance and sleepiness levels.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Filtered eyewear to prevent light-induced melatonin suppression while maintaining visual performance and alertness in night-shift working nurses

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR TOXIC SUBSTANCES AND DISEASE REGISTRY
PHR: Project Narrative This project takes advantage of an existing and growing ALS Natural History Study dataset from the ALS Therapy Development Institute’s (ALS TDI) Precision Medicine Program (PMP). The PMP has been operating since 2014 and has enrolled more than 800 people with ALS during that time. This funding opportunity designed to support investigator initiated research that will identify and evaluate risk factors contributing to ALS provides and excellent opportunity to fund a collaborative research effort assessing the data collected over the past 8 years under the auspices of the IRB approved PMP. Specifically, Funding Option is intended to support ALS risk factor research investigations on environmental, genetic, or other ALS risk factors using our existing, well substantiated evidence base that would benefit greatly from strengthened rigorous evaluation. This proposal brings together ALS researchers from the ALS Therapy Development Institute and Johns Hopkins University to evaluate the existing dataset, clean and quality control the dataset, format and standardize data according to best practices, then assess existing purported ALS risk factors within the dataset, and subsequently assess new possible risk factors. This project has also recruited the ALS Geospatial Hub team, a group of geographical information experts, led by a person with ALS, Pat Dolan, to assess United States- based geographical risk factors. Finally, the project will support the implementation of a web- based portal that will allow external researchers to evaluate data from the PMP to formulate or test new ALS risk-factor or biological hypotheses.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-TS-23-001: Assessment of ALS Risk Factors from ALS TDI's Ongoing Natural History Study (n = 784)

IC_NAME: Center for Global Health
PHR: Project narrative We propose a five-year programme of capacity strengthening and research to (i) strengthen country-based capacity for timely, agile public health research in four countries affected by large protracted crises; (ii) explore novel cross-cutting methods including community-led mortality and epidemic surveillance, and data science applications; and (iii) generate key evidence on different thematic areas including mortality, transmission of SARS-CoV-2 and other epidemic threats, improved hygiene behaviour measures and interventions, measurement of the indirect impacts of the pandemic on sexual and reproductive health among young and adolescent girls, and quantification of impacts on non-communicable diseases and mental health, with evaluation of novel care models for these health problems.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: GH21-004, COVID-19 and related public health threats in populations affected by crises: a multi-disciplinary, collaborative research programme

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Military sexual trauma (MST) is a common duty-related stressor which occurs among one in four female Veterans and is associated with substantial concerns about social isolation and high rates of PTSD. Women with MST also experience numerous person-level barriers to care including the desire to avoid male-dominated VA clinics, transportation difficulties and childcare responsibilities. Treatment programs that address the social and mental health needs of this population and acknowledge barriers to care that disproportionately affect women are lacking. The proposed study will use a hybrid effectiveness-implementation design to evaluate the in-home delivery of a gender-sensitive, evidence-based coping skills program to improve social and role functioning as well as reduce PTSD and will prioritize enrolling rural women in a representative manner. If the program is found to be successful at improving social functioning and PTSD, and in reducing barriers to care, it will provide a tremendous benefit to women Veterans with MST, particularly those in rural areas.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: TBI is often a chronic disorder afflicting many Veterans and is associated with sleep-wake abnormalities and daytime cognitive and behavioral problems. Humans with TBI and rodent models of TBI demonstrate many sleep problems including problems in falling asleep, frequent awakenings, less total sleep, and resultant daytime problems with memory loss and anxiety. We have developed a mouse model of chronic TBI that identifies sleep-wake disturbances by electroencephalogram (EEG). One brain mechanism for these sleep- wake problems in TBI involves the neuropeptide orexin (ORX). We propose to test the treatment effects of an ORX receptor antagonist medication in male and female mice with chronic TBI. This medication, lemborexant, may reverse sleep EEG changes and restore sleep and behavioral functions. Relevance to Veterans Health: Many Veterans with chronic TBI have sleep problems, greater morbidity and poorer quality of life. This pilot proposal can ultimately lead ultimately to trials of these commercially available treatments in Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer risk factors, including pancreatitis and obesogenic high-fat diet, conspire with mutant KRAS to promote PDAC with high penetrance; however, the underlying mechanism remains elusive. The objective of this proposal is to determine if NADPH oxidase is a critical mediator in this context. For this purpose, we will employ novel genetically engineered mouse models expressing pancreatic acinar cell-specific endogenous levels of KRASG12D with or without a critical component of the NADPH oxidase docking subunit p22phhox in the context of these risk factors. Successful completion of this project will provide new insights into preventive and therapeutic strategies against this extraordinarily lethal disease in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genome instability due to accumulation of gross chromosomal rearrangements (GCRs) is a characteristic of many types of inherited and sporadic cancers and acquisition of genome instability is thought to drive the development of these cancers. This project will identify the genes and pathways that suppress genome instability, elucidate the mechanisms that normally suppress accumulation of GCRs and develop assays for GCRs for use in human cells. The resulting insights will facilitate understanding the basis for genome instability in cancer and ultimately lead to improved cancer diagnostics and therapeutics that target genome instability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: 8. Project Narrative The organophosphate (OP) insecticide phorate must be bioactivated to an active metabolite(s) and thus it takes several hours to display toxic signs. Some of our novel oximes have appreciably longer half-lives (several hours) than 2-PAM (about an hour) and they also can reactivate OP-inhibited plasma butyrylcholinesterase, potentially converting it to a pseudo-catalytic scavenger. In this project we expect our oximes to provide greater survival efficacy of lethal doses of phorate than 2-PAM because of their longer plasma presence and their prolonged conversion of plasma butyrylcholinesterase into a pseudo-catalytic detoxication mechanism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Small vessel cerebrovascular disease is common in the elderly, and is a well-known contributor to cognitive decline. A major gap in the field, however, is the ongoing need for reliable and reproducible biologic markers of vascular disease suitable for early detection, disease monitoring, and measuring treatment efficacy. The overarching goal of this proposal is to clinically validate novel neuroimaging and fluid-based biomarkers of cerebrovascular disease selected by the NINDs and developed during the first five years of the MarkVCID consortium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Pemphigus vulgaris (PV) is a life-threatening autoimmune disease that causes severe blistering on the skin and mucous membranes, with no available cure. The present application explores the development of immunotherapeutics to precisely target and deplete anti-desmoglein-3 (Dsg3) autoreactive B cells without impacting normal B cells; Dsg3 is the main autoantigen in the mucosal-dominant type of the disease. The developed method of targeting antigen-specific autoreactive B cells provides a platform for future therapeutics for antigen-specific autoimmune diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed program provides postdoctoral research training in medical genetics with an overall goal to train future academic leaders who will apply this knowledge to an understanding of human genetic disorders. Through rigorous training in the principles of genetics, trainees will exploit recent advances in genetics and genomics to discover the pathogenesis and pathobiology of inherited disease, and to use this information to improve human health. Understanding the etiology of heritable disease will lead to molecular classification, inform risk of recurrence, facilitate development of novel and more effective therapies to reduce illness and disability, and has potential to reduce costs in healthcare through stratification of patients for treatment and management based on the underlying genetic basis of their conditions.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: The 2018 MISSION Act may increase Veterans’ access to healthcare outside of VHA. However, mental health provider shortages in rural communities affect availability of psychological services in these areas. MISSION Act presents a distinct opportunity for VHA to draw upon its relationships with community stakeholders to develop innovative methods to improve access to mental healthcare for rural Veterans. This CDA will engage key stakeholders (e.g., Veterans, MISSION Act providers) to understand the current state of mental health treatment delivered through MISSION Act and develop a program that enhances the ability of community providers to serve rural Veterans. The proposed research will initially focus on rural Veterans with military sexual trauma – a high priority, understudied rural Veteran group. Broad implications of this work include advancements in VHA community care that increase delivery of high-quality healthcare to rural Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Continuous and atomistic descriptions of enzyme mechanisms are crucial to the characterization of protein function and dysfunction—a common cause of disease—but unattainable with current techniques, necessitating novel methods which leverage computational-experimental synergy. The proposed work will investigate improvement of experimental data gathering and deconvolution through computational simulation and modeling as well as improve available tools for molecular dynamics simulations of biochemical events. The resulting methods will produce a more ideal, continuous picture of atomistic protein dynamics, bettering the ability of researchers to probe and describe the biophysical phenomena which often underly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alternative lengthening of telomeres (ALT) is a non-telomerase dependent pathway responsible for 15% of all cancers. Recent studies identified Telomeric repeat-containing RNA (TERRA), a transcript of telomere as a hallmark of ALT. This proposal aims to elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying TERRA mediated activity and cellular function, which could help to pave a new path for treatment of ALT based cancers.

PHR: Relevance How force regulates pluripotent stem cell differentiation and cell fate at the level of chromatin remains largely elusive. We plan to determine and elucidate if and how chromatin deformation regulates pluripotent stem cell differentiation in this project and determine the fundamental differences between normal stem cells and cancer stem cells. The long-term goal is to develop novel approaches and strategies to intervene pathological processes like malignant tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research project is relevant to public health because the elderly represents a growing segment of cannabis users in the US; however, health consequences from cannabis use in this special population are currently unclear. The proposed project is the first to quantify the impact of both age and hepatic impairment or select cytochrome P450 (CYP) genetic variants on cannabinoid disposition. Results are expected to inform consumers, medical professionals, and key stakeholders, including those working in the residential aged-care industry, about the exposure-risk/benefit relationship of cannabinoid use among the elderly, as well as those with hepatic impairment or select CYP genetic variants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Because the COVID-19 pandemic has shown the dire need for more health care professionals on Navajo Nation, we will create pathways for high school and junior high school students to pursue Biomedical Sciences, Public Health, Allied healthcare and related STEM careers. Our approach is entrepreneurial and builds critical thinking and citizenship capacity (aligned with NGSS) by encouraging students to imagine innovative solutions and providing them with the resources to implement and test their hypotheses. Our strategy also includes the near-peer model which pairs Diné College students (mentors) with high school and junior high students from underserved communities, particularly Navajo Nation to build leadership capacity for college students, and create pathways to higher education in Biomedical Sciences/ STEM programs for pre K- K12 students.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Minority Serving Institutions (MSIs) are uniquely positioned to prepare the next generation of cutting-edge researchers from underrepresented minority groups, but faculty at MSIs still face several barriers in securing NIH grant funding for their research. To address this, we formed a partnership with 9 MSIs and created a program called Leading Emerging And Diverse Scholars to success (LEADS), which aimed to launch the research careers of postdoctoral fellows and junior faculty with a one-year fellowship where Scholars received professional skills training. Over the next five years, we will offer a two-year fellowship to Scholars, focusing on innovative new components based on feedback from the Scholars and the literature that includes personalizing the learning and making it experiential, enhancing mentoring, leveraging the benefits of team science to form research teams, and using the LEADS alumni network to serve as leaders and near-peer mentors to help Scholars succeed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Here we study tumor-intrinsic PDL1 signals in early carcinogenesis and progression using a novel autochthonous murine model in which mice develop NrasQ61R-mutant melanomas accelerated by UV exposure that lack PDL1 in the tumor cell-of-origin from initiation, definitively distinguishing biologic PDL1 signals versus compensatory mechanisms that could confound prior genetic PDL1KO studies. Our work defining tumor-intrinsic PDL1 signals in early carcinogenesis and their contribution to tumor progression and the tumor microenvironment provides insights into novel targetable ways in which PDL1 suppresses antitumor immunity. Our data can help improve melanoma treatments or response biomarkers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Modular polyketide synthases are enzymatic assembly lines that naturally synthesize many important human medicines and drug leads. If their synthetic abilities were harnessed, medicines could be developed much more rapidly. Through a new understanding of the polyketide synthase module and new technology developed by our lab, we are able to rapidly engineer highly active synthases and use them in the development of much needed antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer cells rely on the DNA damage sensor kinase ATR to tolerate chemotherapy-induced replication stress. The use of ATR inhibitors in combination with chemical stressors of the DNA replication process has revealed strong therapeutic synergies, but the mechanisms behind these synergies are unclear due to the complexity of the ATR signaling response. By mapping and barcoding cancer- and drug-specific ATR signaling responses using unbiased mass spectrometry techniques, this work will compare molecular signatures and respective cellular outcomes to identify potential mechanisms of clinically relevant chemotherapeutic synergies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Head and neck cancer is one of the most painful malignancies, and is woefully unresponsive to even high doses of opioids. This study will 1) establish the relationship between pain experienced by head and neck cancer patients and specific genes that are silenced by methylation, 2) therapeutically target identified genes using a preclinical model, and 3) provide training to further the career development of the applicant as a surgeon scientist. The study has the potential to lead to a non-opioid treatment for head and neck cancer pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative l Studies of human neurodevelopment and neurodevelopmental disorders suffer due to a lack of adequate model systems. To address this urgent need, my proposed work seeks to identify an engineered biomaterials system that is both permissive and instructive in guiding reproducible neural organoid maturation to develop a robust human stem cell-based neural organoid culture platform. This interdisciplinary approach will facilitate the fusion of organoids representing different brain regions (to form assembloids) to study temporally critical development processes and progenitor migration in a disease model of 22q11.2 deletion syndrome, revealing important fundamental insights into brain development and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over half of the US population consumes more added sugars than is recommended by the 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will identify theory-based interventions with the potential to increase the proportion of dentists involved in the dissemination and implementation of sugar reduction policies and programs for dental caries prevention. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIDCR's mission to improve dental, oral, and craniofacial health through research, research training, and the dissemination of health information.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Accelerated decline in physical function is a common adverse health effect of breast cancer chemotherapy linked to premature frailty, disability, and death. We hypothesize that targeting senescent cells, using exercise and treatments that ablate senescent cells, will improve chemotherapy-induced functional decline. If our hypothesis is correct, the impact on clinical practice would be substantial and will extend far beyond oncology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: A clinical trial is proposed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a senolytic agent (Fisetin) and an anti-fibrotic agent (Losartan), used independently or in combination, to improve the beneficial effect of bone marrow derived stem cells (derived from bone marrow aspirate concentrate) for improving outcomes in patients with knee osteoarthritis. These proposed clinical trials will build upon a currently active clinical trial on orthobiologics at TSC/SPRI for OA treatment at SPRI utilizing the same patient population and outcomes assessments to effectively provide a 6-arm, comprehensive assessment of biological therapies for improving treatment of osteoarthritis.

PHR: C7/8 UO1: Lisa Savage & Ryan Vetreno Recovery of Adolescent Alcohol Disruption of Basal Forebrain-Cortical Projection Circuits Project Narrative Heavy adolescent alcohol consumption is associated with frontal cortical pathology and impaired decision making. This project rescues cholinergic neurons to restore cognitive function in an animal model of adolescent alcohol exposure.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Public Health Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because its findings would contribute to evidence-informed policies regarding family media ecology and be used to tailor interventions to the specific needs of individual families. These findings will also be relevant to ongoing policy debate surrounding the need for regulation of media content and for child-centered design to support healthy developmental trajectories in the digital age. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NICHD’s mission as it pertains to early exposure to digital media and discovering how digital media use affects socio-emotional development in early childhood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Glioblastoma is the most aggressive and common form of primary brain cancer with a median patient survival time of ~ 15 months. Professor Luis Parada at Sloan Kettering Cancer Institute have established the mouse model and faithfully phenocopy the tumor genesis. This proposal will use single cell RNAseq, single cell ATACseq and multi-photon imaging to probe tissue stem cell and cancer initiation cell transcriptional regulation network, heterogeneity and immune privilege.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal of this K01 Career Development Award is to foster Dr. Sunita Desai’s transition to independence, as a health economist with expertise in policy design for vulnerable populations and providers of safety net care. The proposed study, which is the first step in Dr. Desai’s transition, will investigate whether the 340B Drug Pricing Program, an expansive policy that directs financial resources to providers of safety net care, has achieved its goal of improving care quality and medication access for vulnerable populations and/or has had unintended spillover effects on drug spending among privately-insured patients. Findings from this work will yield direct policy implications pertaining to the 340B Drug Pricing Program and useful generalizations regarding the design of policies that intend to give health care providers both the resources and incentives to deliver high-quality and accessible health care for the most vulnerable Americans.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Designing policies to incentivize high-quality health care for vulnerable Americans: Evidence from the 340B Drug Pricing Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative There are currently no drugs that provide neuroprotection after status epilepticus. While calpain has been proposed to participate in the development of epilepsy as well as other neurodegenerative disorders, there are no calpain inhibitors in the clinic. The present studies will test the hypothesis that a selective calpain-2 inhibitor could prevent the occurrence of spontaneous recurring seizures following a seizure episode in two mouse models of epilepsy, in addition to preventing several manifestations of neuropathology. These studies will provide critical information to support the clinical development of a selective calpain-2 inhibitor for the treatment of epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The ability to generalize from past experience is essential to our daily lives as we rarely encounter precisely the same situation twice, but little is known about how the brain generalizes from past experience. An understanding of the neural processes underlying this fundamental cognitive ability could provide important foundational knowledge for understanding how it may be altered in disease. This study investigates neural substrates of generalization from past experience in goal-oriented settings with a focus on the hippocampus and prefrontal cortex, two brain regions important for learning and memory and implicated in a range of psychiatric conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The patients infected with HIV require lifelong treatment with antiretroviral drugs. Tenofovir prodrugs, tenofovir disoproxil fumarate and tenofovir alafenamide fumarate, are an integral part of the first-line therapy for the management of HIV infections, but tenofovir prodrugs have low oral bioavailability. This project will develop novel strategies to improve oral bioavailability of tenofovir prodrugs which will eventually improve their antiviral activity and required therapeutic dose.

ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health as it focuses on extrachromosomal DNA (ecDNA), which is frequently observed in particularly aggressive cancers. These studies will improve our understanding of the molecular mechanisms that drive tumor heterogeneity and treatment resistance in some of the most difficult-to- treat medulloblastoma patients. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to the causes, prevention, and cure of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will develop novel real-time 3D MRI technology, using continuous radial sampling, motion-resolved reconstruction, and deep learning, for MRI-guided adaptive radiotherapy of unresectable pancreatic cancer. Our new approach for real-time 3D MRI, named MR signature matching (MRSIGMA), pre-learns 3D motion states and corresponding signatures during an offline learning phase and then performs fast signature acquisition and matching to one of the pre-learned 3D motion states to minimize latency and offer a real-time solution. The novel real-time MRI technology will unlock the potential of the MR-Linac for pancreatic cancer and enable the use of curative doses rather than palliative doses, with minimal risk in patients who currently do not have a chance for long-term survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative A large investment in time and money is made to support neuroimaging research to understand how brain structure and function develops and ages, and how various disorders affect it. However, much of this research, while very valuable, is performed on a relatively small number of subjects and is reported in a way that makes it difficult to replicate or assess its generalization across the population. ReproNim: A Center for Reproducible Neuroimaging Computation, provides a re-executable framework for capturing data and performing neuroimaging analysis. In this renewal, we seek to improve the efficiency of this framework in support of improving all clinical and research studies using neuroimaging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Early-life antibiotic exposure leads to lasting immune dysregulation that plays a role in high neonatal susceptibility to viral pneumonia, although the role for this antibiotic exposure on tissue- resident CD8+ T cell function is unclear. This proposal aims to define how early-life antibiotic exposure affects the formation and function of tissue-resident CD8+ cells following primary and heterotypic challenge with Influenza A. Fully characterizing the many complex factors that come together to control the cellular behavior of these tissue-resident CD8+ T cells will allow us to design the best vaccines and therapeutic immune support for these at-risk neonates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) provides genome-wide information on gene expression at single-cell resolution, and is revolutionizing the progress of biomedical research. The size and complexity of this data necessitates the development of computational algorithms that can distill critical biological insights from high- dimensional datasets. Here, we propose to develop and test an innovative new class of algorithms that are aimed at reducing the potential for noise and bias in the analysis of scRNA-seq data.

PHR: Project Narrative: PP1 is a ubiquitous ser/thr protein phosphatase, which regulates >70% of all dephosphorylation reactions in higher eukaryotes. Despite decades of research, it has not been established how PP1 is activated in the cell. We have assembled a team of researchers that will be able to overcome this impediment and to allow for novel biological insights to be gained.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR
PHR: Endothelin receptors are proteins that are increased in the eyes with increased pressure as seen in glaucoma. In the current grant application, the process by which endothelin receptors contribute to the damage to the optic nerve will be studied at the level of the nerve cells in the eye. Endothelin receptors blockers will be tested to determine if they could protect nerve cells in the eye from dying due to elevated ocular pressure, and this could aid in the development of a repurposed medication, macitentan, for glaucoma treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The nation continues to witness racially motivated encounters between the Black community and police officers. With 87% to 94% of Black youth reporting at least one event where they were racially discriminated against in the past year, Black justice-involved youth (JIY) are exposed to discrimination more often due to policing, placing them at an increased risk of engaging in alcohol and cannabis use as a means of coping with discrimination distress. In this project, Dr. Bryant aims to 1) examine the impact of racial discrimination on alcohol and other drug use, 2) create a culturally adapted substance use intervention for use with Black JIY, and 3) pilot the culturally adapted substance use intervention to assess changes in alcohol use and discrimination distress among Black JIY.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Even with the most recent therapeutic advances, metastasis remains the leading cause of death in patients with cancer. In virtually all solid tumors, metastasis occurs via the lymphatic circulation; however little is known about the factors that ultimately sculpt this process. Thus, in the current application we will seek to define critical, lymph-derived factors responsible for mediating pre-metastatic niche, immune downregulation in the tumor-draining lymph node in order to identify and develop both prognostic tools and therapeutic counter- measures capable of meaningful clinical impact in patients undergoing primary surgical resection of cutaneous malignant melanoma.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Seventeen United States Veterans die by suicide each day. Nearly three-fourths of those Veterans die from firearm injury or poisoning, and many seek care in VA Emergency Departments (ED) prior to suicide attempts. In 2019, the VA began screening all Veterans seeking ED care for increased suicide risk. Interventions that promote firearm and medication safety are recommended for Veterans identified as at-risk. Our work will develop and test such an intervention for Veterans who seek care in VA EDs. We will interview at-risk Veterans who recently sought VA ED care to identify factors relevant to developing the intervention, and work with Veterans and VA healthcare staff to develop and test the intervention. Our safety intervention for Veterans with increased suicide risk is consistent with the VA 2018-2028 National Suicide Prevention Strategy, priority in preventing Veteran suicides, and focus on delivering Veteran-centered care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: We seek to understand how transthyretin (TTR) aggregates in humans, and which aggregate structures lead to the dysfunction and ultimately the death of post-mitotic tissue in the TTR amyloid diseases that primarily destroy the nervous system and kidneys vs those that compromise heart function. Understanding these aspects and the corresponding structure-proteotoxicity relationships would enable the development of novel therapeutic strategies, the establishment of early diagnostic biomarkers, and establish methods that quantify response to therapy. We will use a new imaging approach to take a fresh look at heart pathology to probe the 3D relationships between the non-native TTR structures, host molecules, and immune cells and we will also use new proteomic methods to characterize changes in the plasma proteome upon the onset of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Adverse events pose a significant challenge to medical interventions (drugs, devices, other), and while there is a clear need for adverse event surveillance, the current methods are time-consuming, unsustainable, and miss most adverse event cases. The widespread adoption of electronic health records (EHRs), capturing medical data for the majority of US patients, presents an opportunity for sustainable adverse event surveillance via automated approaches. Strategies for identifying and characterizing patients experiencing adverse events has the potential to inform risk factor identification, prediction of adverse event development, and prognostication of patient outcomes, as well as lay a crucial stepping-stone for further progression of EHR-based phenotyping in biomedical informatics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the dynamics that govern whether a mutant allele will go extinct or establish and propagate its lineage in a growing population that is competing for nutrition and space is relevant to many biological settings. For example, biofilms in the human oral microbiome and pre-vascular tumors are dense populations of cells that expand spatially in a way that is remarkably similar to range expansions of the genetically-tractable model organism Saccharomyces cerevisiae presented in this work. By elucidating how the physical properties of cells and of microbial populations affect their growth and evolutionary dynamics, this work will shed light on the growth and evolutionary dynamics of dense, expanding cellular populations in general and develop null models that can be used to infer the presence and nature of biological interactions (e.g., mutualism or antagonism) based on observed spatial patterns within these biofilms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite long-standing gender parity in the number of medical students, women remain underrepresented in the senior ranks of the physician-scientist workforce, and research suggests that the mid-career transition is a point at which many careers stall. We propose to test the impact of a novel peer mentorship intervention to promote the careers of women from a national mid-career cohort of biomedical clinician-researchers (recipients of new NIH K08 and K23 awards in 2006-2009) in the EMPOWER trial, which will compare outcomes, including advancement, productivity, and burnout, between women randomized to a control arm provided with curricular materials alone or an intervention arm provided with the same materials but also engaged in peer mentorship teams. This intervention will be modeled on the Leadership Learning Model Framework developed for the Executive Leadership in Academic Medicine Program, which is partnering with us in this work, and will be informed and refined based on the analysis of surveys and interviews to illuminate mechanisms driving gender differences in career outcomes in the post-#metoo era, including the impact of the intersection of gender with other categories of disadvantage such as race or sexual orientation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We have recently associated telomere biology disorders (TBD) and gain-of-function germline RPA1 mutations. The molecular and functional consequences of these mutations on telomere maintenance and hematopoiesis is not understood. The proposed studies will use biochemical methods and iPSC disease model to establish the molecular mechanism by which gain-of-function RPA1 mutations cause telomere dysfunction while using in vivo murine system to determine the functional consequence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research aims to design and apply a novel polymeric artificial antigen presenting cell (aAPC) platform for the in vivo expansion of tumor-specific CD8+ T cells for cancer immunotherapy, circumventing critical hurdles that currently hamper the success of adoptive T cell therapies. Using this particulate platform, we will investigate several significant physicochemical and immunological factors that influence antigen-specific T cell activation. By adapting our technology to both murine and human systems, we will demonstrate the clinical relevance of this technology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rural cancer survivors, particularly those with blood cancers, are at increased risk for cancer related financial hardship that can have a negative impact on quality of life and lead to poor health outcomes. This study aims to explore the experience of cancer related financial hardship for people with Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) who live in the rural Southeast and healthcare team member perceptions of the rural CML patient experience of financial hardship. This study will address a gap in the literature for an at risk population that is challenged by the costs of cancer care while providing evidence that will lead to rural specific intervention development to reduce the risk of financial hardship and improve health outcomes and quality of life for rural cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Alcohol-induced blackouts, a form of amnesia that involves a region of the brain termed hippocampus, frequently occur upon moderate-heavy, acute alcohol consumption disregarding age, alcohol drinking history, biological sex, gender or education, and leads to risky behaviors including vandalism, unprotected and/or unconsented intercourse, and driving an automobile while intoxicated. Despite the damage to individuals and society that alcohol-induced blackouts impose, Medicine has fallen short in understanding the mechanisms of their occurrence and in providing pharmacotherapeutics to counteract them. Departing from all previous work, which focused on mechanisms operating within hippocampal neurons, this study proposes a hippocampal vascular mechanism for the condition and thus, will: (a) identify the molecular target in the brain arteries that facilitates the occurrence of alcohol-induced blackouts, (b) address its likely contribution to the differences in alcohol-induced blackout between biological sexes, and (c) establish the efficacy of endothelium-independent vasodilators newly discovered by our group to selectively affect the vascular target of alcohol and thus counteract alcohol-induced blackouts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the second leading cause of cancer mortality globally and understanding the microbiota contributions to disease development is predicted to lead to new approaches to CRC prevention and therapy. In this proposal, using a murine model, I will define how genetic loss of adenomatous polyposis coli (Apc), a CRC driver mutation present in at least 80% of CRC, modulates the microbiome throughout the time course of colorectal tumor development. I expect my results to provide support in the future for innovation in CRC patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Attentional deficits are present in patients suffering from neurodegenerative diseases and neuropsychological disorders. In fact, these attentional deficits manifest prior to the cardinal symptoms of such conditions, such as dementia, traumatic brain injury, and schizophrenia (Sharma et al., 2016). Thus, developing a framework for studying the systematic underpinning of cognitive processes, such as attention, may serve to improve the detection of cognitive markers for preclinical diagnostics of these neurological conditions (Levy et al., 2016).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Assessment of treatment response for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is often difficult and inaccurate due to treatment-related non-specific changes on imaging tests. The study aims to investigate the performance of novel circulating biomarkers (EV digital score, GALAD score, HCC EV-GALAD digital score) for evaluation of HCC treatment response. These circulating biomarkers will be rapidly translatable and may prevent unnecessary frequent imaging tests by providing an accurate assessment of HCC treatment response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: CENTER OVERVIEW PROJECT NARRATIVE The Pediatric Center of Excellence in Nephrology at the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP PCEN) will continue to facilitate extensive collaborative research around the causes, diagnoses, and treatment of kidney diseases in children and break down barriers to clinical trials implementation. The CHOP PCEN will continue to partner with PEDSnet through the Learning Health System (LHS) Core leveraging the resources of a national interconnected, multi- institutional infrastructure focused on childhood kidney disease and establish a new core, the Molecular Precision Nephrology (MPN) Core to facilitate identification of novel molecular targets to expand therapeutic options for children with kidney disease. The Administrative Core will support the Enrichment Program and Opportunity Pool Pilot and Feasibility Program as well as two Research Projects that apply innovative approaches to the data resources of the LHS Core and NIDDK consortia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Program Narrative The Integrative Cancer Scholars (ICS) training program is an innovative comprehensive plan to prepare the next generation of cancer researchers by emphasizing critical thinking skills, adapting novel technologies and requiring a co-mentoring plan with clinical and basic science faculty mentors. The development of innovative and impactful therapies must integrate information from clinical experience and fundamental discoveries of basic science to understand and act on the abnormal transformations of key molecules or pathways in cancer. ICS trainees are expected to produce original, creative and significant cancer research and have advanced communication skills for dissemination of their discoveries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative: This project will generate connectional diagrams of the monkey and human brain at unprecedented resolutions. These diagrams will be linked both to the neuroanatomic literature and to in vivo neuroimaging techniques, bridging between the rigor of the former and the clinical relevance of the latter. The data to be generated by this project will advance our understanding of brain circuits that are implicated in motor and psychiatric disorders, and that are targeted by deep-brain stimulation to treat these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative: Cochlear implants represent the most successful neuroprosthesis in clinical use, providing direct electrical stimulation to the auditory nerve to restore hearing to deaf patients. However, cochlear implant recipients usually struggle to understand complex auditory signals such as speech in noise and music. These studies seek to develop and understand novel thin film coatings applied to the implant to diminish trauma and scarring in the cochlea, improve the interface of the implant with the cochlear tissues, and enhance the ability of cochlear implants to represent complex auditory signals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative – Overall Despite major advances, the death rate from skin cancer remains unacceptably high. In this proposal 3 Projects address the challenges of immunotherapy in melanoma by identifying predictors of response to therapy, novel combinations of drugs designed to enhance response, new approaches to the timing of therapy administration, and the examination of novel tumor microenvironments and their effect on therapy response. This SPORE’s 3 Cores and Developmental Programs are designed to bring together clinical investigators and basic scientists in highly translational efforts to accelerate the pace of therapy for patients suffering from melanoma and other skin cancers, including cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC), cutaneous T cell lymphoma (CTCL), or Merkel cell carcinoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative – Core A The overall goal of the Administrative Core is to provide the administrative structure for the efficient and fair review and allocation of resources, scientific and regulatory oversight, and to act as a conduit for the rapid execution of SPORE goals. Core A will facilitate the sharing of resources, the communication between the investigators, and provide oversight for the awarding of career enhancement and pilot awards. This Core includes a clinical trials advisory committee, specifically designed to accelerate the pace of translational research, a key objective of this SPORE proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With no cure for older patients afflicted with Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML), this proposal investigates how the loss of a newly identified protein that controls mitochondrial activity will impact the disease. AML depends on the metabolic pathways in mitochondria and our hypothesis is that targeting this single regulator can simultaneously cripple multiple hallmarks of the cancer. Establishing the extent of its control is the critical first step towards being able to target this new protein as a vulnerability for AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The studies described in this research proposal will lead to a broader understanding of the copper biochemistry associated with the oxidation of organic molecules (e.g. hydroxylation of methane). We are particularly interested in understanding the structure, spectroscopy and reactivity of the Cu/O2 species formed in Cu- dependent monooxygenase enzymes. The use of synthetic inorganic complexes that mimic some features of the active centers of these enzymes will allow us to generate metastable LCu/O2 species and evaluate their reactivity towards biologically relevant C-H hydroxylation reactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative – Biospecimen and Pathology Core B This long standing Core has made significant contributions to skin cancer research, providing annotated tumor samples, as well as specialized expertise in mouse models. These samples and the DNA, RNA, proteins, and cells derived from tumors are the foundation of any translational program. This Core collects IRB-consented patient samples and clinical data, distributes the tissues to SPORE researchers, and analyzes tissues using cutting edge technology and innovative and rigorous approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Advanced bladder cancer has a poor prognosis, and only 20-30% of patients respond to immune checkpoint blockade. Response to the immune checkpoint inhibitor αPD-1 can be improved by adding the histone deacetylase inhibitor entinostat, but it is unknown how modulation of M-MDSCs and the neoantigen landscape can be leveraged to augment response. We hypothesize that entinostat-induced changes in M-MDSCs and neoantigen expression drive response to the combination of entinostat and αPD-1, and we seek to improve response through neoantigen vaccination.
