IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Owing to their modularity and broad applicability, transition metal catalyzed cross-coupling reactions have proven a tremendous asset to the discovery of small molecules as medicines. We aim to develop excited-state bond homolysis as a novel key step to generate highly reactive radical centers with Ni-catalysis. Ultimately, the cross- coupling methods developed as a result of this proposal will contribute to the field as a whole through their unique bond forming capabilities and selectivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic infections such as HIV, HCV and HBV affect half a billion people and are significant causes of morbidity and mortality. T cell dysfunction or “exhaustion” is a major immunological defect during these infections as well as in cancer and can be modeled with LCMV infection in mice. The studies proposed will define the role Tox, a key programmer of exhaustion and provide new insights into how to improve immunity during chronic infections and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple Myeloma (MM) is an incurable disease that affects vulnerable elderly adults and minorities, causing morbidity and poor quality of life. We identified the protein CD56 as a key player able to support MM growth and escape from the immune system. We propose to study how CD56 induces signaling changes and affects responses to therapies and block its activity to benefit patients with this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Dental fear negatively affects the health of over 53 million American adults. Standard dental treatment (anti-anxiety medication or anesthesia) is compassionate but maintains the cycle of fear and avoidance; psychological treatments are effective but are rarely available and not easily disseminated. We propose to develop and test a suite of self-administered eHealth tools (neVR Fear the DentistTM) to treat dental fear that can be implemented in private practice dental offices throughout the U.S. and is eminently scalable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic kidney disease occurs in more than 10% of the general population and represents a highly significant disease burden. RIGERR aims to provide substantial public health benefits by generating innovative resources and tools that will empower and accelerate current and future research across a broad range that comprehensively encompasses all kidney disease research involving genetics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative - Project 1 Despite the recent progress in immune checkpoint inhibition (ICI)-based therapies, the patient response rate is low. Rationale-based biomarker development is urgently needed to stratify responders and non-responders, thereby providing decision-enabling information to clinicians and patients. The study of tumor- and macrophage- derived exosomes proposed in this application will unveil novel mechanisms of immune suppression, and help develop a quantitative liquid biopsy-based tool that enables clinicians to predict patient response to ICI-based therapies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: While medication is recognized as the most effective treatment for opioid use disorder (OUD), it remains under-utilized within VA. In 2018, of more than 70,000 VA patients diagnosed with OUD, just 35% received a medication to treat the disorder. Rural patients, who comprise 23% of all VA patients, are particularly underserved. A primary reason for this is that many rural Veterans reside prohibitively far from VA facilities that offer specialty substance use disorder treatment. While primary care services are more readily available to rural Veterans through VA community-based outpatient clinics (CBOCs), within VA, the large majority of prescribing for OUD occurs within the context of specialty substance use disorder treatment settings, rather than primary care. Thus, enhancing rural patients’ access to OUD medication hinges on the extension of prescribing to rural, primary care settings. The over-arching research aim of this career award is to develop a strategy that supports the implementation of buprenorphine treatment in rural VA primary care settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The brain damage incurred by individuals with periventricular leukomalacia (PVL) often leads to visual processing impairments, which may be more severe when the thalamus or thalamo-cortical connections are affected. The studies outlined in this proposal will use a multimodal neuroimaging approach to characterize the morphometry of thalamic nuclei and integrity of visual thalamo-cortical networks to determine how they contribute to the observed visual dysfunctions in individuals with PVL. The results from these studies will advance our understanding of the impact early white matter injury has on the visual thalamo-cortical networks and functional vision in persons with PVL, ultimately providing a set of neuroimaging and behavioral targets that may be used to develop effective habilitation strategies for these individuals in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative – Project 2 We have identified autophagy to be a major mechanism of resistance to melanoma therapy, and an attractive target for new drugs in melanoma and other cancers. This proposal will address a major unanswered question: Can targeting autophagy enhance the effectiveness of immunotherapy in melanoma? Knowledge gleaned from this work will provide a fundamental understanding of how autophagy inhibition can improve the response rate of immunotherapy, and should lead to development of a potentially new treatment regimen for advanced melanoma patients that could improve survival in future clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Educational Modules to Broaden Academic Research Cultures (EMBARC) is relevant to public health and the mission of NIH/NIGMS because it innovatively leverages cultural frameworks to train and promote transfer of underrepresented minority (URM) community college (CC) students to biobehavioral research career fields at an early and critical period of professional and scientific development. We anticipate EMBARC trainees will be equipped to succeed in biobehavioral research contexts and address the complex health needs of a rapidly diversifying U.S. population. Our approach includes rigorous testing of culturally-informed educational activities and modules through a partnership with the largest community college district within the largest system of higher education in the country (Los Angeles Community College District [LACCD], California Community Colleges Chancellor’s Office [CCCCO]) and distribution nationwide with some of the largest scientific organizations for URM students representing biobehavioral science (ABRCMS, APA, SACNAS) to maximize outreach and sustainability of our efforts to diversify the scientific workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Circadian changes in neuronal action potential activity are required to regulate the daily fluctuations in sleep/wake cycles, hormone production, cardiovascular output, metabolism, and other physiological functions essential to human health. The goal of this research is to understand the ion channel properties, interactions, and functional consequences that set these circadian changes in action potential activity in the central clock of the brain, focusing on a stereotypical set of partnerships formed between BK channels and their Ca2+ channel activators. The results will reveal how these channels work together during the action potential to control firing, and how dysregulation of their properties and interactions contribute to circadian, sleep, and seizure disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative – Project 3 Patients with high-risk Stage II melanoma have an unacceptably high mortality rate with surgical treatment alone. In this study, we will test the hypothesis that neoadjuvant immunotherapy can be used to reshape the tumor microenvironment in the draining lymph node to limit or eradicate the disseminated malignant cells, thus, increasing cure rates. We will determine the clinical and immunological impact of neoadjuvant anti-PD1 antibody therapy in high risk clinical Stage II melanoma and identify new rational combinations for high-risk Stage II melanoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Cognitive impairment is a common debilitating outcome of sepsis with an unknown mechanism. The study of brain injury in sepsis and other forms of systemic inflammation is limited by a lack of in vitro tools that model the interface between the blood and brain. This project will address this unmet need by building a human neurovascular unit chip where circulating factors are introduced on the `blood side' and a microglia report on inflammatory status on the `brain side.'

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sexual aggression is a significant public health concern and is closely linked with men’s sexual misperception. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE The human pathogen Streptococcus mutans is the major bacteria associated with dental caries. In this application, we will investigate the mechanisms utilized by S. mutans to survive under high zinc stress and determine how the use of zinc-containing dental hygiene products affects survival of bacteria associated with oral health or disease. Finally, we will explore the therapeutic potential of a S. mutans protein that confers zinc tolerance for the prevention and treatment of dental caries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it directly addresses a growing need to understand how best to deimplement entrenched practices that are not supported by the best available evidence because they are unnecessary, costly, and do not improve patient outcomes. Advancing the science of de- implementation is directly relevant to NIH’s goal to foster innovative research strategies and their applications as a basis for ultimately protecting and improving health. This project is also aligned with NHLBI Strategic Vision Objective #6, Optimize clinical and implementation research to improve health and reduce disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mislocalized and aggregated tail-anchored (TA) proteins have been linked to various human diseases such as diabetes, cancer, neurodegenerative and congenital heart diseases. The main goal of this proposal is to investigate how cells ensure efficiency and fidelity of TA-targeting to the endoplasmic-reticulum membrane. Understanding this process in molecular detail can potentially lead to novel therapeutic strategies to fight various diseases caused by defects in TA biogenesis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The proposed research examines the neurocognitive bases of treatment response to evidence-based  learning programs for reading remediation. We use pre and post treatment neuroimaging and frequent  neuroimaging during the course of treatment 1) to gain new insights into how treatment modulates brain organization for literacy, language learning, and remediation; 2) why it fails todo so for some children, and 3) what might constitute a more beneficial focus in minimal-responders. The proposed research represents a  key step towards the development of comprehensive and mechanistic models of the neural underpinnings of  typical and atypical reading development. Project Narrative

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Proposed studies address the role of paraoxonase 3 in regulating key proteins in the distal aspects of kidney nephrons that transport sodium and potassium. Dysregulation of these transporters leads to abnormal volume and blood pressure, and abnormal blood levels of potassium. This work has the potential to uncover mechanisms by which paraoxonase 3 regulates specific kidney transporters and identifies a target for novel therapeutics to treat hypertension and hyperkalemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Novel Biologic Therapies for GVHD Narrative: Every year, thousands of patients undergo hematopoietic stem cell transplant. While this procedure is potentially lifesaving for patients with hematologic malignancies and non-malignant hematologic disease, it is still plagued with complications. Of these complications, severe GI acute graft versus host disease (AGVHD) represents the major cause of early morbidity and mortality. The proposed research is highly relevant to public health because it aims to improve clinical outcomes for patients that are undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, by discovering new strategies to prevent and treat severe GI AGVHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The Biomedical Summer Institute at West Virginia University (WVU) for teachers, mentors, and students directed by Health Sciences and Technology Academy (HSTA) leadership and staff in collaboration with university faculty sets the foundation for the HSTA academic year community-based after school clubs during which specially trained HSTA teachers mentor students into research. Through the after-school club curriculum HSTA students will use validated resources, supported by HSTA TEAMS of mentors, to design science, technology, engineering, mathematics, and medicine (STEM+M) educational interventions or experiments with middle school students. The results of the STEM+M community-based research projects will be disseminated through regional and state HSTA research symposiums, as well as through national conferences and publications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Critically ill children supported by extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) receive large volumes of prophylactic platelet transfusions to prevent bleeding, although mounting evidence has demonstrated significant morbidity and mortality associated with these transfusions. The ECmo hemoSTAtic Transfusions In Children (ECSTATIC) pilot trial will test two different platelet transfusion strategies, based on two different platelet counts thresholds, one high (liberal strategy) and one low (restrictive strategy). The pilot will gather the necessary information to perform a full trial which will provide a better understanding of how to transfuse platelets to children supported by ECMO and reduce the associated morbidity.

PHR: Project Narrative The application is aimed to support cancer-related research efforts of The Wistar Institute investigators through computational expertise provided by Bioinformatics Shared Resource. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Our research aims to understand how bacterial pathogens use chemical signals to sense and adapt to the host. In this proposal, we will develop biosensor technologies that light up these chemical signals and allow us to track them in different bacteria, including pathogens that cause cholera, typhoid fever, urinary tract infections, and food poisoning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There is an extreme unmet for drugs that can prevent oral cancer in high risk patients. This clinical trial will test a combination drug, pioglitazone-metformin, in patients at high risk for developing mouth cancer. The findings from this trial can ultimately result in a treatment that would be available for use in over 250,000 patients a year who are at high risk for oral cancer development or recurrences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PREVENTABLE will evaluate the benefit and risks of moderate-intensity statin for preventing dementia and prolonging disability-free survival in a diverse population of patients 75 years and older without heart disease. We will also evaluate the benefit and risks of moderate-intensity statin use in reducing a cardiovascular outcome (myocardial infarction/acute coronary syndrome hospitalizations, stroke, heart failure, or cardiovascular-related death) or mild cognitive impairment or dementia, and collect lab specimens on 17,000 participants to advance precision health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There remains an urgent unmet need to improve our understanding of the physiological mechanisms of pulmonary injury following exposure to understudied highly toxic chemicals. This proposal will address this unmet need by characterizing dose/toxicity relationships for a broad range of highly toxic chemicals with an in vitro airway-on-a-chip model and performing analysis of the fundamental molecular, cellular, and physiological pathways involved in toxicity/pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Although the majority of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) take fall-risk increasing drugs (FRIDs) and falls are a significant source of morbidity and mortality for patients, there are to date no interventions that tailor and target deprescribing efforts for this population. This K23 application will adapt and test a novel pharmacist-led deprescribing intervention for patients with COPD, using qualitative data from patients, family caregivers and prescribers to guide the adaptation, delivery, and evaluation of a pharmacist-led deprescribing intervention. This research will provide data on how to reduce medication-related harm to improve quality of life and reduce medication-associated morbidity and mortality for patients with COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative WormBase is an international consortium of biologists and computer scientists providing the research community with accurate, current, accessible information concerning the genetics, genomics and biology of C. elegans and related nematodes. Using a combination of expert curation, machine learning, and AI-enhanced community curation, we will integrate information about the C. elegans genome and sequence features, gene function, expression and interaction, and human disease models. We will transition to using the software infrastructure of the Alliance of Genome Resources for sustainability and economies of scale.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Developing new methods for accurately capturing dietary intake is crucial for revealing true associations between diet and disease. We propose to apply the newly developed US population-based dietary biomarkers for sugars and protein quality as objective measures of intake to inform the best practices for their use in future diet validation studies and studies of diet-disease associations. Well-established biomarkers of sugars and protein quality are key for revealing the true health effect of sugars and clarifying the potentially differential health effects of animal protein and plant protein intake.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with end-stage kidney disease (ESKD), who use hemodialysis as their kidney replacement method, require vascular access in the form of an arteriovenous fistula, arteriovenous graft, or central venous catheter to receive life-sustaining hemodialysis. Increasing evidence indicates that outcomes of the different vascular access types vary widely based on patient characteristics, so much so that the recent update of the National Kidney Foundation Dialysis Outcomes Quality Initiative (KDOQI) guidelines states “…there is insufficient evidence for KDOQI to make recommendations on choice of incident vascular access type,” leaving providers and patients to select a vascular access type without adequate evidence of likely outcomes. To overcome this key barrier, the goal of this R01 proposal is to optimize the patient experience of vascular access decision- making by a) developing an interactive, evidence-based guide to vascular access outcomes that incorporates a prognostic model for short and long-term outcomes of vascular access and b) identifying best practices for utilization of the guide during the clinician-patient encounter.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD) recovery outcomes can be improved through peer-based social support but barriers to in-person support (e.g., 12-step groups) are high and became increasingly apparent through the COVID-19 pandemic. Online AUD Recovery Support (OARS) forums are growing in popularity and offer convenient access to real-time social support which can lead to improved well-being and transitions to in- person support, but effectiveness of OARS on improving AUD outcomes has not been studied in rigorous clinical trials. In order to stage the first clinical trials of OARS participation – ultimately leading toward evidence-based guidelines for their use in AUD – I will develop necessary measures of OARS behavior and conduct a pilot randomized clinical trial to assess the feasibility of a behavioral intervention for OARS participation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Androgen deprivation therapy (ADT), with an androgen signaling inhibitor, is the backbone of treatment for men with metastatic castration sensitive prostate cancer (mCSPC), but diminished muscle mass due to androgen blockade is linked with poor overall survival, and adverse changes in health outcomes important to mCSPC survivors (e.g., fatigue, physical function, independence, insulin sensitivity, and quality of life). Resistance training (RT) is an effective approach to preserve muscle mass and improve these health outcomes in non-metastatic CSPC survivors receiving ADT; however, there is a gap in our understanding of how RT impacts outcomes in mCSPC survivors, and the impact of 52-weeks of RT in a home-based setting, a setting that is more practical for sustained adherence and the reported preferred setting for exercise in mCSPC survivors receiving ADT. Furthermore, the addition of creatine monohydrate supplementation to an RT program (Cr+RT) enhances the effects of RT in cancer-free older adults and individuals with advanced head and neck cancer, and creatine supplementation has demonstrated anti-cancer effects in preclinical models including prostate cancer; as such, this 52-week, randomized, double-blind placebo-controlled trial will compare our established, effective, home-based, telehealth RT program with creatine or placebo (PLA; Cr+RT vs. PLA+RT) in order to identify the superior strategy to preserve muscle mass, improve health outcomes, and attenuate cancer progression in mCSPC survivors receiving ADT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposed research is responding to RFA-DE-22-003 and aims to better understand the epidemiology and biology of oral HPV infection, as well as its acquisition and persistence, in people living with HIV (PLWH) and elucidate mechanisms related to HPV-associated oral and oropharyngeal cancers (OOPC) in the context of HIV. We propose to study the role of epigenetic biomarkers in HPV-associated OOPC in PLWH in Nigeria, a country with high HIV prevalence, to help develop potential non-invasive screening and early detection biomarkers of OOPC in PLWH. Identifying epigenetic markers predictive of the progression of precancerous lesions into OOPC will also provide opportunities for developing future preventive and therapeutic targets for managing precancerous lesions and OOPC in PLWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: This proposal investigates neurons that transmit information related to corneal pain and determines how they are modified after corneal inflammation and nerve injury. Populations of corneal pain-activated neurons in the trigeminal ganglion and brainstem are characterized based on their gene transcription profiles, and the ability of corneal immune cells to interact and modify the properties of corneal neurons is examined. This comprehensive analysis will provide knowledge needed to develop new treatments for corneal pain and related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Hematopoietic stem cells (HSC) in the adult bone marrow are rare multipotent cells that can regenerate and sustain blood development upon transplantation. Strategies to "mobilize" HSC from the bone marrow to the peripheral blood show great promise to enhance the efficiency of stem cell transplantation. The proposed studies would address major gaps in our knowledge of basic HSC biology, and provide novel insights into the clinically relevant process of HSC mobilization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Currently, there are no effective non-surgical tools for preventing or treating corneal scarring, which is a complication often observed with advanced keratoconus (KCN) that results in possible blindness and decreased quality of life. Bioactive cargo (e.g., RNA, protein, and lipids) containing extracellular vesicles (EVs) are released by corneal cells to communicate with one another, and those released by the corneal epithelium can trigger myofibroblast differentiation, which may cause scarring and diminish vision if they persist. In this proposal, we will load-EVs with TGF-β1 or -β3 to determine a growth factor that can drive scar-free corneal wound healing, and we will examine the bioactive cargo from KCN-epithelial cell derived EVs that is contributing to KCN corneal scarring and disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osteoporosis is a serious public health problem leading to severe bone loss and increased risk of fractures in elderly subjects. The proposed study will comprehensively identify genes, gut bacterial species, their products and functional mechanisms that are associated with differential susceptibility to osteoporosis. The findings will contribute to a better and more comprehensive understanding of molecular mechanisms, and thus help prevention and treatment, of osteoporosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study is relevant to public health because it will prospectively examine the impact of disadvantageous neighborhood contextual factors (rooted in structural racism) and allostatic load (as an intermediate biological process/mechanism between neighborhood context and health) on breast cancer in a large, diverse study sample. The successful accomplishment of the proposed aims will contribute new knowledge about the impact of long-term exposures to disadvantageous neighborhoods and how chronic cumulative stress becomes biologically embedded in cells and tissues – thereby impacting breast cancer biology and etiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Driving under the influence (DUI) of alcohol remains one of the most frequently repeated offenses, with over one-third of offenders being charged with a second DUI offense within five years. Our research suggests that offenders’ awareness of risks associated alcohol use is diminished, particularly in the intoxicated state, when decisions are made to drive. The proposed research aims to reduce recidivism in offenders using experiential feedback and mindfulness-based approaches to enhance their risk awareness during states of intoxication that pose risk for DUI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: Project Narrative: Gender minority (GM; transgender and gender non-conforming) individuals experience disproportionately high rates of hazardous drinking and alcohol use disorder (AUD) and are an NIH-designated disparity population (NOT-MD-19-001). Despite marked disparities and unique alcohol risk factors, there are no evidence-based alcohol interventions for this population. This study will conduct mixed-methods formative research with an established multi-site longitudinal GM cohort to develop and assess the feasibility of the first culturally-adapted psychosocial treatment intervention for GMs with AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Colorado’s booming STEM economy requires a prepared biomedical workforce, and numerous career and professional school opportunities in biomedical research and health sciences provide excellent career paths for the diverse Rocky Mountain community. The Bridges to the Biosciences Research Training Program provides a new pathway to a baccalaureate degree in the life sciences for transfer students from Front Range Community College to the University of Colorado Boulder. The training program will promote scientific research opportunities not previously available and will fully engage B2B trainees in scientific education, research, and professional development to increase persistence and retention in biomedical fields.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative We will examine the effect of cerebrovascular plasticity in the aerobic exercise intervention leading to improvement in cognition and how these changes affect brain structural and functional changes. Dose-response effects of exercise on cerebrovascular outcomes will also be investigated. The results from this study have scientific and clinical implications and could help transform public health recommendations of physical activity and exercise for influencing cognitive and brain outcomes in older adults. It could establish more effective preventive and therapeutic strategies to reduce the burden of AD/ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Lack of adherence with the U.S. recommended immunization schedule leads to increased vaccine preventable disease risk in young children. In this study, we will quantify national and state trends in and factors associated with four novel measures of early childhood immunization services quality: (1) vaccine timeliness, (2) immunization schedule adherence, (3) undervaccination due to parental vaccine hesitancy, and (4) undervaccination due to other access barriers. We will also examine rural-urban differences in immunization services quality to determine which strategies may be most effective for achieving health equity in early childhood vaccination coverage in the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Chronic pain is a leading devastating condition that affects more than 100 million Americans annually with symptoms lasting from week to years. Mechanical allodynia (a process regulated by mechanosensory ion channels) is considered one of the most prevalence hallmarks of chronic pain, but little is known about the processes that contribute to its occurrence. We investigate the molecular and cellular pathways that regulate mechanosensory channels and try to identify the specific molecules and proteins that could potentially become drug targets to mitigate pain conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite strong epidemiological evidence indicating alcohol as a risk factor for oral cancer, the mechanisms of its carcinogenicity remain unclear. A specific role of alcohol's metabolite acetaldehyde is emerging in the carcinogenic process at this site, based on a connection between oral ethanol metabolism and levels of acetaldehyde in the mouth, leading to modifications of DNA and ultimately translating into mutations. Combining cutting edge multi-omic approaches we are dissecting the key steps in this process to provide a systematic assembly of biomarkers, directly relevant to human health, to be used to identify susceptibility, and to develop strategies for early detection and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE With the rapid emergence of highly effective modulator therapies for cystic fibrosis lung disease, new outcome measures are urgently needed to critically assess mild lung disease and to carefully assess the effectiveness of such medications. Perfluorinated gas MRI has the potential to fulfill this critical need in CF and other airways diseases by providing combined functional and structural assessment of ventilation abnormalities. Further development of this outcome measure may ensure the efficient development of novel therapeutics to provide timely access for patients in need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One of the most challenging sequelae for patients undergoing lumbar spine surgery is chronic post-surgical pain (CPSP) which is associated with poor physical function and long-term opioid use. There is a significant need for effective nonpharmacologic interventions, such as Acceptance and Commitment Therapy, to prevent CPSP and long-term opioid use. Moreover, identifying psychosocial and psychophysical phenotypes associated with treatment efficacy will allow for a cost-effective, precision medicine approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia can now be delivered digitally (dCBT-I), enabling millions of individuals access to the recommended first-line therapy for insomnia; however, overall rates of treatment completion and adherence are less than 50%, with larger disparities in those with low socioeconomic status. The proposed project will test enhancing dCBT-I with telehealth coaching to reduce disparities and improve overall engagement to digital insomnia treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Ocular pain and photophobia are debilitating conditions associated with migraine and dry eye disease (DED) and are also commonly experienced by patients following refractive surgery. The mechanisms underlying these pain conditions and photophobia are poorly understood but are likely to involve interactions between the pain-sensing neurons and light-sensing cells of the eye, as well as components of the immune system. The proposed research aims to elucidate the molecular mechanisms and neural pathways involved and to identify potential therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Basement membranes are subject to mechanical damage throughout the life of the organism. Improper repair or maintenance can lead to basement membrane diseases, including Alport Syndrome, Goodpasture Syndrome, asthma, and diabetes. Upon completing this proposal, I will have identified components required for basement membrane repair and elucidated a mechanism for detecting and repairing damaged basement membranes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly all adults after middle age display clonal hematopoiesis, a phenomenon in which mutated cells are overrepresented in the peripheral blood, increasing risk for hematological malignancy and cardiac disease. While low-frequency mutant clones are present in most adults by middle age, our understanding of the factors that promote eventual clonal expansion remains limited. The objective of this study is to determine whether mutant hematopoietic stem cells always expand with enough time and underlying mutation burden, with the ultimate goal of enhancing healthy aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the complexity of the development of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and developing and testing effective therapeutics and interventions requires the generation of animal models that faithfully recapitulate the disease. We have spent five years creating the individual components that we will now combine to produce mice that develop relevant aspects of AD. Furthermore, we will carry out deep phenotyping of these mice across their lifespans and align their pathologies and gene expression profiles with human signatures. All mice and data will be made freely available to all investigators, in academia and industry alike, so that the global research field can use these resources to develop and test therapeutics and ultimately combat AD.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative  This project will continue to advance a cognitive test battery for use as a set of outcome measures for clinical trials in intellectual and developmental disabilities (IDD), covering domains such as processing speed, memory, cognitive flexibility, attention and language. The research will improve measurement sensitivity of the NIH Toolbox Cognitive Battery (NIHTB-CB) for lower functioning individuals, expand the scope of the battery to include early numerical and conceptual reasoning, and it will detail the developmental trajectories of these domains of function in children and youth with IDD. Finally, the ability of the NIHTB-CB to detect improvement related to treatment will be evaluated in a controlled trial of a medication known to improve attention and behavior in IDD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite effective HIV viral control and longer life expectancies due to the success of combined Antiretroviral Therapy (ART), persons living with HIV continue to suffer from neurological complications including Post- traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and HIV-associated Neurocognitive Disorders (HAND). These complications are predicted to accelerate as patients age and understanding of how a loss of estrogen in the aging population of women living with HIV and PTSD is needed. We will characterize estrogen signaling as a potential endogenous targeted therapeutic avenue to the current antiretroviral arsenal to reduced neuroinflammation, in the aging population of females living with HAND and PTSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millions of Americans suffer from high blood pressure, diabetes, strokes and motor vehicle accidents due to ineffective treatment of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). Our preliminary data suggest that physiological causes of OSA such as easy arousability or unstable breathing control may influence effectiveness of OSA’s most common treatment, continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP). The NICE-PAP study will examine how the physiologic traits that cause OSA in each individual impact CPAP effectiveness and can lead to personalized OSA treatments that improve patient lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The abscission checkpoint is a cell cycle checkpoint that arrests cytokinetic abscission to ensure the upstream events of mitosis are completed properly before finally dividing. This proposal will integrate new molecular signaling pathways that contribute to maintenance of the abscission checkpoint as well as characterize cellular programs that promote faithful abscission during an abscission arrest. In the long term, our research may enable new treatments to so that we are better able to diagnose and treat diseases when this checkpoint fails.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Title: Next-generation Mass Spectrometry Technologies for Integrated Structural Proteomics Project Narrative: Knowledge linking proteoform composition to protein structure is critical for our understanding of biological functions in normal and diseased organisms, thus playing a central role in drug development. How proteoforms combine to form this very complex machinery has been a central goal in biomedical research and a host of structural biology and mass spectrometry methods have made great progress, but many complexes remain refractory to such technologies, and their proteoform compliment unknown. Here, we propose to develop a suite of new mass spectrometry strategies capable of simultaneously analyzing protein complex sequence and structure with the ability to capture structure and composition information from small amounts of unlabeled protein, present within complex mixtures that remain difficult or impossible to analyze using classical structural biology probes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The goal of this training program is to provide trainees from historically underrepresented backgrounds with the research experience and enhanced scientific training needed to be competitive for top-tier biomedical science PhD and MD/PhD programs. We anticipate that our scholars will go on to have highly successful careers in academia and the biotechnology industry. Human health and society-at-large will benefit directly as our training program produces creative, highly trained scientists who understand how to conduct rigorous and reproducible research that addresses current questions in biomedical science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative For a gene to function properly, it must be active in the right place, at the right time and in the right amount. Changes in any of these features can lead to disease. This proposal uses mathematical theory and experiment to understand how information about the appropriate place, time and amount of gene activity is encoded in the genome, to help determine the causes of disease directly from DNA sequence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The liquid-liquid phase separation of proteins to create a condensed phase is a fundamental strategy for organizing cellular contents. Improved understanding of how molecular and macromolecular changes influence these condensed compartments could enable the creation of a new platform to control protein function as well as provide insight into the dysregulation of phase separation in disease (neurodegeneration and cancer). The proposed research program plans to develop (1) orthogonal phase separated compartments with a range of molecular and materials properties and (2) methods to gain insight into how molecular parameters influence partitioning and diffusion of small and large molecules in the condensed phase.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ocular inflammatory disease represents an important and disproportionate cause of visual morbidity, yet real- world data to inform appropriate health policy regarding disparities in its development, progression, treatment patterns, and economics are lacking. Indeed, the restricted scope of prior case series and population studies render the epidemiology of uveitis to be poorly understood, particularly for vulnerable populations in the healthcare safety net setting. This project seeks to leverage the strengths of two unique databases, a national medical claims database and electronic medical record data from our local healthcare safety net, which contain large and diverse cohorts of patients, to explore health disparities in the development, progression, and treatment of ocular inflammatory diseases – a foundational step in innovating targeted interventions to mitigate these disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Rural community health workers embedded in clinical survivorship care teams—CHW-clinical survivorship care teams—is a strategy to improve fragmented rural survivorship care, adherence to follow-up, and facilitate linkages to local resources to overcome socio-economic barriers to care. This project will examine the feasibility, acceptability, and implementation of a pilot telehealth CHW-clinical survivorship care team intervention focused on resource referrals and connections, symptom management between follow-up care visits, and improving adherence to post treatment follow-up care recommendations of lung cancer survivors from rural areas. This research will contribute to the lack of literature addressing the implementation of survivorship care models to improve rural survivorship outcomes and eliminate disparities in rural-urban survival rates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individual cells experience continuous assaults due to daily wear-and-tear, accidents, trauma, or infections and diseases that can lead to a ruptured cell cortex. Their survival depends on how efficiently and effectively they can repair such injuries. The focus of the proposed research is to investigate the regulatory mechanisms that facilitate proper cell wound repair in order to guide new therapies for treating damage and to identify key molecular players for informing regenerative medicine and/or improving clinical drug delivery approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PEROJECT NARRATIVE The east and central Africa (ECA) region is a global hotspot for emerging infectious diseases (EID), associated with recurrent outbreaks of viral hemorrhagic fevers and detection of viruses emerging elsewhere that are capable of causing high morbidities and mortalities such as highly pathogenic influenza, Zika, and Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-COV). We propose to establish an Emerging Infectious Disease Research Center (EIDRC), headquartered in Nairobi but with surveillance distributed throughout the region. The Center will conduct pilot research on maintenance and transmission of RVF virus and MERS-CoV; conduct systematic pathogen discovery and development of diagnostics and research reagents; and support response to outbreaks of suspected EID the region by conducting timely clinical and socio-cultural outbreak research that enhances characterization of outbreaks, leading to implementation of prevention and control measures.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Emergency general surgery (EGS) is associated with the highest risk, acuity, complication rates, and cost in general surgery - particularly the subset of emergency laparotomy patients, which suffer the worst EGS outcomes - and is increasingly recognized as a surgical public health crisis. Despite a number of major postoperative complications occurring commonly after discharge (notably over 40% of surgical site infections), recovery for surgical patients once discharged to home remains understudied and ripe for improvement and innovation including use of novel digital solutions. Using systems engineering approaches, REST-PSLL (Re-engineering Surgical Recovery and Transitions Using Technology Patient Safety Learning Laboratory) has the end goal of enabling safe surgical recovery at home for emergency laparotomy patients.
PI_NAMEs: MARQUARD, JENNA LOUISE;MELTON-MEAUX, GENEVIEVE B (contact);WICK, ELIZABETH C

PROJECT_TITLE: REST-PSLL: Re-engineering Surgical Recovery and Transitions Using Technology Patient Safety Learning Laboratory

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The goal of my research is to develop and test healthcare delivery models in the VA health care system to improve the delivery of quality, efficient, and patient-centered care. I have led > 30 federally funded (HSR&D, QUERI) and foundation projects. I am collaborating with the Offices of Rural Health (ORH) and Connected Care. Additionally, I am the PI/Co-PI of 3 IIRs, 2 ORH funded projects, and 2 industry-funded projects occurring in the VA. I am the PI of a U01 and a K12 training grant both from NHLBI. Since 2013, I published >160 papers. More than half of these were coauthored with VA mentees. I am the primary mentor for 2 CDAs, secondary mentor on 6 other CDA/K awards. Proposed activities include: 1) develop methods for scaling and adapting interventions for veterans with comorbid conditions, 2) facilitate the evaluation of models of virtual care as they pertain to the Mission Act legislation, and 3) mentorship. The Senior RCS award will allow me to enhance my contributions to the VA HSR&D mission and improve care for Veterans with chronic conditions.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Up to 80% of high grade serous ovarian cancer (HGSC) patients succumb to their disease due to both lack of early detection and limited therapeutic options. Genomic analysis of these tumors has suggested that up to 50% may have difficulty in repairing damage to their DNA which might make them therapeutically sensitive to a variety of available drugs; and functional analyses of HGSC tumor cells has revealed that many tumor cells are defective in repairing specific damage generated when the cells duplicate their DNA. The work in this proposal will help to better understand how HGSC tumor cells with defects in repairing this type of damage interact with the surrounding normal cells, and how these interactions lead to sensitivity and resistance to certain therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myopia (nearsightedness) is a leading cause of vision impairment. It is a growing public health concern because its prevalence is increasing significantly, which increases the prevalence of several vision-threatening conditions associated with myopia and more vision loss. This project examines gene expression in the eye to identify the cellular and molecular mechanisms controlling eye growth and the development of myopia. The results will provide important insights about the causes and control of myopia in children and form the basis for new and effective treatments to reduce myopia and vision loss.

PHR: Project Narrative (max. 2-3 sentences)  The nerves on the corneal surface play roles in dry eye disease and diabetes. Their dysfunction can cause  chronic pain and contribute to photophobia and migraines and their loss leads to corneal inflammation and  keratitis. The experiments proposed will improve our understanding of how corneal sensory nerves are  maintained and how they regenerate after injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Mutations to DNA acquired during the lifetime of an organism may accumulate and result in a tendency for the groups of cells, or clones, that harbor them to grow faster and thus expand. Such clones, including those with alterations to their chromosomes such as deletions or duplications of DNA, are detected in the blood of >5% of older individuals and cause increased mortality through increased risk of cardiovascular disease, infection, cancer, kidney disease and lung disease. We will use genomics and computational approaches to estimate the rates at which these clones are expanding in 1.3 million individuals to understand the molecular causes and consequences of expanding clones on aging health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mission of our collaborative Bridges to the Baccalaureate program is to help diversify the pool of biomedical research scientists in the United States. Our program partners with American River College (ARC), a local community college, to support students as they transfer from ARC to UC Davis, a four-year baccalaureate degree granting institution and finish their degrees in normative time. We accomplish these goals by providing authentic research training experiences at both ARC and UC Davis that build our trainees’ sense of belonging in biomedical research, understanding of ethical and moral responsibilities, and rigorous technical skills required for their academic and professional success.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An expansive array of inherited retinal diseases emanate from one general etiology: mutations in Peripherin 2 (PRPH2); however, clinical manifestation of PRPH2-diseases can vary, even amongst those with the same mutation. We propose to explore the role of Rom1 in modulating Prph2-disease phenotypes by assessing the outcomes of Rom1 modulation in clinically recapitulative animal models of Prph2-associated disease. Identification of common mechanisms of Rom1 modification between differing Prph2 diseases can move the field towards exploring broader methods of treatment for this wide spectrum of diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Astrocytes, the most abundant glial cells in the central nervous system, perform a multitude of evolutionary conserved functions including, metabolic support to neurons, regulating blood-brain barrier, and modulating synapse-formation, -function and -plasticity, and are crucial in maintaining normal brain homeostasis. Dynamic crosstalk between astrocytes and neuronal synapses modulates most if not all of these functions, yet the molecular mechanism of neuron-astrocyte cross-communication at the synapse is largely untapped. Based on our preliminary studies, we propose a novel mechanism of neuron-astrocyte crosstalk at the synapse via S1P/S1PR1 signaling that regulates astrocyte function and neuronal synapse formation, function and plasticity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE BioBuilding: A traveling exhibit for future biomedical engineers Sciencenter The Sciencenter will develop a traveling exhibition on biomedical engineering for small to mid- sized museums across the nation, bringing together graduate students and faculty from Cornell University’s Meinig School of Biomedical Engineering and experts in exhibit development and reaching rural audiences from the Sciencenter and the University of Montana spectrUM Discovery Area to develop hands-on learning experiences that improve public understanding and appreciation for biomedical engineering and its impact on public health. BioBuilding will engage non-expert audiences through a hands-on exhibition and supporting interactive activities that highlight ongoing research and applications from biomedical engineering that are improving human health. This project will increase knowledge and interest in biomedical engineering amongst rural youth 6-12, with a longer-term goal of encouraging career development in this and related STEM fields by supporting a more comprehensive, diverse pipeline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE We have identified a series of novel compounds that reduce the production of Low Density Lipoprotein Cholesterol (LDL-C) from the liver, and we reason that the compounds act as irreversible inhibitors of carboxylesterase 1 in hepatocytes. They represent a new class of compounds that could potentially be used to treat homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia (hoFH), steatosis, and as a complement to statins to help the general population meet cholesterol goals. We propose to determine the compound’s mechanism of action and whether they are effective in humanized mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative A crisis in the United States is that nearly 100,000 individuals are on the list for a kidney transplant and almost half die or become too sick while waiting because of a profound shortage of kidneys. Millions of healthy Americans are potentially willing and able to donate a kidney, but due to knowledge and communication barriers, the tremendous potential of live donation to meet the need for kidneys remains unrealized. To address the problem, we developed a novel educational and communication solution for transplant candidates to increase their access to live donor kidney transplantation that, once tested, will be disseminated nationwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: This application proposes to study the role of nonsense mediated decay in nonsense mutation biology and the pharmacologic correction of nonsense mutations. This proposal uses the human genetic disorder Cystic Fibrosis as a model; however, approximately 10% of all genetic diseases are caused by nonsense mutations which historically have been difficult to treat. This work will increase the understanding of nonsense mutation heterogeneity and may lead to the development of precision medicine approaches to treat nonsense mutations thereby significantly reducing disease burden worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An emerging paradigm in cancer immunology states that the aberrant transcription of repeat RNA in cancer is a critical mechanism for engaging tumor intrinsic and extrinsic immune and regulatory factors, and an untapped source of potential therapeutic targets. Using a set of approaches from statistical physics, our team predicted repeat RNA stimulates receptors of the innate immune system, confirmed this hypothesis in a key subset of immune cells, and showed classes of repeat RNA can correlate with response to immunotherapies. Our goal is to identify the classes of structural and sequence features of repeat mediated immune activation in solid tumors and clarify their specific consequences for tumor evolution, the state of the immune microenvironment, and cancer immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Underrepresented minority (URM) scholars at predominately White institutions (PWIs) often contend with numerous challenges that impact their research success and productivity. There are empirically supported problems with recruiting and retaining URM faculty in academia and the biomedical workforce. The overarching goal of the Faculty Accomplished Community that Cultivates Equity and Success in Science (ACCESS) Program, is to provide URM early and mid-career faculty with tools and resources needed to be successful biomedical scientific leaders by centering wellness and resiliency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Within the US, ticks transmit 18 human pathogens, the most injurious being the bacteria that cause Lyme disease, for which there are an estimated 476,000 cases per year. There is a critical need for improvement in tick management products as the incidence of tick-borne diseases is rising with the changing climate and current tick-repellent and/or acaricidal products employ a pyrethroid chemical to which ticks are increasingly resistant. We aim to formulate polymeric microparticles designed to carry non-volatile acaricides into granules and fibers capable of controlled release of volatile repellents and/or toxicants; granules would be used in landscape applications to remove and repel ticks, and fibers would be incorporated into the fabric used to make outerwear garments that protect humans from acquiring and being bitten by ticks.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Virtual bioequivalence (VBE) uses mechanistic physiologically-based pharmacokinetic models to simulate realistic virtual cohorts of patients which can replace full clinical trials. However, well-defined workflows and examples of VBE applications are lacking; this study will develop an integrated VBE platform yielding optimal decisions for a matter directly related to the health and safety of patients, and their optimal treatment. Our software platform will help generic drug development and regulatory reviews, but also innovators’ drug development, enhancing drug efficacy, availability and safety for all the world’s population.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: A State-of-the-Art Virtual Bioequivalence Platform and Case Studies on Complex Formulations, Systemic and Local Concentration-based Bioequivalence

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE  Nearly half of Nigerian adults have hypertension, and Nigeria has announced a national sodium reduction program for population-level hypertension prevention and control based on the WHO’s best buy SHAKE package. Using a type 3 hybrid study design and the EPIS, CFIR, and RE-AIM frameworks, we will perform a baseline health needs assessment (UG3 phase) and follow-up assessments (UH3 phase) using stakeholder interviews, population surveys, and retail surveys. This embedded study will optimize local, regional, and national implementation and will provide generalizable knowledge about implementation strategies to lower dietary sodium intake at scale.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH This UCLA/UCSD Acne Center of Research Translation (CORT) is composed of a multidisciplinary team involving basic scientists and physician scientists engaged in translational research. Working together, leveraging innovative technologies and institution resources, the proposed research will lead to advances in understanding how the relationship of the skin microbiome in acne and healthy skin, as well as lipid metabolism, with the host immune response contributes to the pathogenesis of acne and skin homeostasis. The outcomes of this research will provide insight into strategies to alter the interaction of the microbiome, lipid metabolism and the immune response in order to change the course of acne and other inflammatory skin diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative: Worldwide, traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a leading cause of death and disability among children and adolescents. We aim to test whether pediatric TBI treatment guided by invasive intracranial pressure monitoring produces better patient outcomes than care guided by a protocol without invasive monitoring. Study findings will inform clinical practice in treating pediatric severe TBI globally. Focused didactic and experience-based learning opportunities will increase the research capacity of pediatric intensivists in Latin America.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Tissue-based gene expression classifiers (GECs) are being increasingly utilized for men with localized prostate cancer to enhance the discriminatory power of standard clinicopathologic models and improve patient risk stratification. However, there remains a lack of evidence to support the widespread implementation of any of the GECs in clinical practice, with no prospective data demonstrating clinical utility or clinical impact of GEC testing on patient outcomes such as tumor control and quality of life. This work will produce a method to compare and implement risk thresholds across multiple GECs simultaneously, test the clinical utility and clinical impact of GEC testing in a new randomized trial of men with favorable risk prostate cancer, and perform long-term follow-up of the first ever randomized trial of GEC testing after radical prostatectomy (G- MINOR trial) to comprehensively determine the clinical impact of GEC use in localized prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The extracapsular extension (ECE) of the tumor in the lymph nodes is a significantly high-risk feature in head and neck cancers, which usually require pathologic confirmation. Predicting ECE during preoperative evaluation becomes a piece of critical information for clinicians planning treatment to avoid neck dissection and potential late toxicity such as fibrosis and worse lymphedema. This proposal will develop and evaluate a novel robust machine learning approach to facilitate both 1) understanding of using robust machine learning for directly ECE diagnosis on CT scans without manually annotating the lymph node information, and 2) assisting interpretation of the CT images through deep learning for ECE identification to enable improved clinical diagnostic efficiency and accuracy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The host 16-hydroxylates progesterone as a means of Phase I metabolism to excrete progesterone from the body. Intravenous administration of 16-hydroxyprogesterone resulted in urinary excretion of 17alpha-prenanolone and 17apha-progesterone which indicates that this excretion product is significantly modified in the gut and reabsorbed. This is significant because the side-chain is inverted during this process, and likely affects physiological function particularly in colon physiology and reproductive health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This Training Program is designed to prepare the next generation of researchers who will fill workforce needs in cancer behavioral and psychosocial research. Cancer remains a leading cause of death and a major source of disability in the United States and throughout the world. The goal of the Training Program is to ensure that a talented and well-trained group of PhD and MD researchers is available in the years ahead to meet research needs to understand behavioral and psychosocial determinants and sequelae of cancer, reduce cancer risk, increase early disease detection, and improve the lives of community members who have developed cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The Center for Visual Science at the University of Rochester has a large and vibrant community of 41 scientists engaged in vision research. We seek to renew our NEI P30 Core funding that allows us to maintain a staff of 10 highly-skilled experts who are software, optical, mechanical, and electrical engineers, in addition to a histologist and a clinical imaging professional. These technical staff members meet the collective needs of CVS faculty in achieving their research goals of understanding normal vision, as well as diseases of the visual system and the therapies to treat them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative  SARS-CoV-2 infection can cause severe lung damage and death, and there are no effective medications or vaccines to treat or prevent the disease. Despite the ongoing efforts to develop antibodies against the virus’ spike protein, scientists have focused very little effort on TMPRSS2 as an alternative target. The overarching goal of this proposal is to use human pluripotent stem cell (hPSC)-derived lung organoids and air-liquid interface cultures, in combination with a SARS-CoV-2 hamster model, to identify underlying mechanism(s) blocking viral entry and to test the efficacy of AL20 (a TMPRSS2 monoclonal antibody) and serine protease inhibitors (serpins, which are endogenous inhibitors of TMPRSS2) for preventing SARS-CoV-2 infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) frequently goes undetected in rural communities or is detected late, which can impair the ability of children with ASD to thrive both mentally and socially. Lack of awareness about ASD symptoms and resources among clinicians and community members in rural areas is a significant contributor to delayed diagnosis. Expanding our Autism Spectrum Resources in Georgia webpage into an online ASD ToolKit and developing an accompanying online course for Georgia healthcare workers will provide information and guidance on providing care for patients with ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding how serotonin neuron subtypes develop is of general interest as serotonin has wide-ranging modulatory effects on central neural circuitry and altered serotonergic gene expression, brought about by either genetic or early life environmental stressors, has been implicated in several neuropsychiatric diseases including depression, stress-related anxiety disorders, autism, OCD, and schizophrenia. The objective of the proposed research is to use single cell RNAseq and ATACseq to understanding spatiotemporal dynamics of 5- HT subtype development. These single cell genomics approaches will be used to investigate previously unaddressed fundamental questions about how continuously expressed neuronal transcription factors control 5-HT neuron subtype development, which may provide fundamental knowledge about underlying mechanisms of neurodevelopmental disorders that may result from altered development of specific neuron subtypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The methyl-CpG binding protein 2 (MeCP2) is a highly abundant chromatin-binding protein, which if mutated causes Rett syndrome, a severe neurological disorder with no approved therapies that directly address the underlying defects of MeCP2 loss of function. One primary contributor to the lack of MeCP2-targeted interventions is an inadequate understanding of how MeCP2 reads methylated DNA within hierarchically organized chromosomes. This proposal will use single-molecule visualization and structural biology technologies to investigate how MeCP2 biophysically navigates the chromatin landscape to reach its canonical methyl-DNA substrate at unprecedented spatial and temporal resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH CTR AT TYLER
PHR: Narrative Respiratory viral pathogens, such as SARS-CoV-2 and RSV, can cause deadly infections in human lungs and have exerted a tremendous public health burden. The proposed program of research focuses on the viral membrane fusion mechanism of SARS-CoV-2 and RSV, a process that is a prerequisite for a virus to enter host cells. The proposed studies will employ complementary/synergetic biophysical and biochemical tools to elucidate molecular mechanisms of the fusion process, guiding the design of future vaccines and therapeutics that target virus entry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Of the millions of people who survive COVID-19, many will be affected by long-term neurologic symptoms. This study will evaluate long-term Neuropsychiatric Symptoms (NPS) and identify sex specific inflammatory profiles that contribute to this pathophysiology. Investigation of the chronic consequences of the disease is necessary as this pandemic will have consequences on public health and the economy for years to come.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative: The stratified epithelium is the most complex epithelial architecture among living systems and is most often subject to wounding and damage. Regeneration in this complex tissue requires multifaceted synchronization of several epithelial cell lineages and local tissue immune cells. My studies aim to functionally understand the epigenetic factors and pathways that regulate full tissue restoration in the stratified mammalian epithelium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Nearly all organisms require iron for growth and survival, and the few that do not require iron depend on manganese instead. Mismanagement of cellular concentrations of these metals has been implicated in a variety of human pathologies, from bacterial infections to neurodegenerative disease. This research proposal seeks to develop selective fluorescent sensors for iron and manganese in order to probe mechanisms of metal regulation in bacteria and in mammalian cells, with the goal of uncovering new and potentially unique avenues for therapeutic intervention in these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Stress is known to be one of the primary triggers for HSV recurrent disease, although surprisingly little is known about how it does so. Although most studies have focused on viral latency in sensory neurons, HSV also establishes latency in autonomic neurons, which are highly responsive to hormones and likely contribute to differential pathogenesis of HSV1 and HSV2. Results from this proposal will identify how stress hormones, a known trigger for HSV recurrent disease, regulate HSV1 and HSV2 infections in autonomic and sensory neurons, and challenge the paradigm of HSV reactivation by demonstrating that autonomic neurons are an important source of HSV recurrent disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The corneal epithelium supports and protects branches of the trigeminal nerve that provide sensation to the cornea. Dry eye and corneal abrasion disrupt the corneal barrier, cause degeneration of cornea nerves, and renders them more sensitive to environmental stimuli that may be perceived as discomfort and pain. The overall goal of this proposal is to determine the molecular changes in the corneal and nerve cells that are triggered by corneal barrier disruption and that cause corneal nerve degeneration and pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because OSA is a major health concern that is inadequately treated with existing therapies. The NHLBI 2011 Sleep Disorders Research Plan states that “studies are needed to identify clinically meaningful subtypes [of OSA], and algorithms informing the selection of optimal therapeutic strategies.” The proposed research directly addresses this important component of the NIH's mis- sion.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With technological advancements in healthcare data capture, ﬁt-for-purpose real-world data (RWD) have now been used as external controls to improve the evaluation of safety and efﬁcacy in clinical trials, but such use of external controls is inevitably subject to potential confounding or hidden biases. We will develop a novel sensitivity analysis framework for the use of hybrid external controls to assess the impact of hidden biases, as well as robust and efﬁcient analysis methods that selectively borrow and adjust for data discrepancies to mitigate the impact of hidden biases. User-friendly software packages, statistical analysis plan templates to guide the proposed methods, and applications and case studies using completed clinical trials and RWD will be disseminated to the scientiﬁc community, with the ultimate goal of facilitating a more robust use of real-world evidence in regulatory decision-making.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Methods to improve efficiency and robustness of clinical trials using information from real-world data with hidden bias

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuromodulators such as serotonin and neuropeptides are critical for the function of complex neural circuits, and defective neuromodulator signaling is linked to a host of neurological and psychiatric disorders e.g. depression and affective disorders, schizophrenia, addiction, and Parkinson's disease. We use a powerful experimental model, the nematode C. elegans, to determine molecular mechanisms required for the development and in vivo function of neuromodulatory systems. Mechanisms we find through our studies require genes that are conserved between invertebrates and humans, and discovery of these mechanisms offers new opportunities to understand how neuromodulator signaling controls behavior and to imagine new treatments for psychiatric and neurological diseases caused by defective neuromodulation.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Real-world clinical data hold tremendous potential to advance our understanding on the efficacy and safety of therapeutic interventions in broader populations, including disease modifying therapies for chronic diseases. However, these data remain underutilized due to methodological constraints and the inability to efficiently link and integrate data sources across study types and healthcare settings. We develop statistical approaches to enable use of real-world clinical data to define treatment responses in large and heterogeneous patient populations and inform product labeling for specific indications and patient groups.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Generating Reproducible Real-World Evidence with Multi-Source Data to Capture Unstructured Clinical Endpoints for Chronic Diseases

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Public Health Significance Relapse during recovery from alcohol and drugs is a common occurrence that undermines the improvements individuals make in multiple areas. Persons who relapse are prone to continue using substances and suffer additional consequences, such as psychiatric, legal, medical, and work problems. Although peer helping has been shown to have beneficial effects on alcohol outcomes, very few studies have examined the relative effects of giving and receiving different types of help (e.g., instrumental versus emotional) from different sources (e.g., recovering peers, family, and friends). The proposed study will examine the effects of helping behaviors among a sample of persons residing in peer operated sober living recovery houses (SLHs). Analyses will show the types of helping most strongly associated with sustained recovery and the pathways by which it operates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Stem cell therapy is being explored to recover the injured myocardium. Cardiac progenitor cells derived from neonatal tissue may have the greatest potential but the underlying mechanism of action is unknown. We are exploring the mechanism of how exosomes, the functional unit of cardiac progenitor cells, recovers the injured myocardium and how to detect exosomes in the serum to potentially create a potent, next generation stem cell therapeutic. In addition, the detection of plasma exosomes derived from the stem cell treatment provides an a noninvasive window into the conditional state of the transplanted cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Frontal lobe epilepsy is the second most common form of epilepsy, and seizures associated with this epilepsy are dangerous. We propose to map the neuronal circuits active during frontal lobe seizures with unprecedented spatial and temporal resolution. These studies will open novel targets for therapy by neuromodulation, resection, or drug treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Statement: The 2018 Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidelines recommend that all adults engage in at least 150 minutes of physical activity weekly; however, uptake of PA is poor among patients who undergo total knee replacement, despite substantial pain relief as a result of the surgery. We propose a randomized trial of a multimodal behavioral intervention—telephonic health coaching and financial rewards—to encourage patients with osteoarthritis who have undergone a total knee replacement surgery to become more physically active. If the intervention proves effective and cost-effective, it could lead to a fundamental change in the strategy for increasing physical activity in patients undergoing total knee replacements.
