IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Many intrinsically disordered proteins (or proteins that do not fold into stable structures) can self-associate on biological surfaces, but understanding control of this phenomenon as a function of protein and surface modifications remains experimentally intractable. Herein, we propose to apply novel tools to understand how modifications control this phenomenon in specific model systems, with an explicit focus on modifications that occur in physiology and disease. This program will benefit the scientific community by introducing novel techniques and the public health by elucidating the biophysical behavior of proteins critical to neuronal function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Both increased awareness of cancer health disparities and increased diversity within the cancer research/oncology workforce are required to fully address the problem of cancer health disparities. The proposed Meharry Cancer Summer Research Program (SuRP) will provide undergraduate and medical students an opportunity to complete short-term, cancer focused research experiences that will enhance their understanding of cancer and cancer health disparities. It will also inspire participants to pursue careers in cancer research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Evidence indicates that older cancer survivors could significantly reduce the risk of experiencing chronic pain symptoms by engaging in physical activity, however, it is unknown how and when to best deliver physical activity intervention health messaging to reduce these symptoms. The proposed study will develop and test the timing of physical activity promotion messages to increase physical activity and reduce pain symptoms among older cancer survivors who experience chronic pain symptoms in a micro-randomized trial. The results from this study will provide a robust foundation for a R01 submission to conduct a just-in-time adaptive physical activity intervention to manage pain symptoms in older cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The proposed project will develop algorithms for predicting and detecting glaucomatous progression in advanced glaucoma eyes tested longitudinally with visual field and optical imaging technologies and will make use of a very large amount of data, to do so. This proposal addresses the current NEI Glaucoma and Optic Neuropathies Program objectives of developing improved diagnostic measures to characterize and detect optic nerve disease onset and characterize glaucomatous neuro- degeneration within the visual pathways at structural and functional levels. Characterization of functional, structural, and microvascular loss in the central area of the retina and development of a clinically useful, novel, empirical system for predicting and detecting glaucomatous progression in advanced glaucoma will have a significant impact on the future of clinical care and reduce the burden of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We recently identified a lactate-derived metabolite called N-lactoyl-phenylalanine (“Lac-Phe”) as the most significantly elevated metabolite in blood plasma after an intense exercise bout, which can robustly reduce food intake and body weight in obese mice. The proposed experiments will follow upon these observations to reveal the neurobiological basis for Lac-Phe hypophagia, which may identify Lac-Phe and the associated pathways as targets for weight management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA), and California State University, Los Angeles (Cal State LA), will continue to administer the "IRACDA at UCLA" program. "IRACDA at UCLA" trains postdoctoral scholars in modern biomedical research at UCLA, and college level teaching at Cal State LA. Our goal is to train scholars how to employ modern teaching technologies to retain under-represented minorities in their majors at Cal State LA, and transition them to careers in the biosciences, to strengthen and diversify the national biomedical workforce.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE NBS has ushered in an era in which increasing numbers of parents are leaving the NBS experience with uncertain prognoses for their children. Despite lacking a comprehensive understanding of the benefits and harms of these uncertain prognoses, society has implemented mandatory public health screening for millions of newborns without the requisite appraisal of benefits and harms. The proposed project will provide a comprehensive assessment of the harms and benefits for parents of children with uncertain prognoses after NBS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Sharing large-scale functional genomics data is critical for scientific discovery, but comes with important privacy concerns related to the possible misuse of such data. This proposal will quantify and manage the rieslkasted to releasing functional genomics datasets, based on integrating inferred genotypes from the raw sequence files, signal tracks, and microbiome mapped sequences. Finally, we will develop file formats, statistical methodologies, and related software for anonymization of functional genomics data that enable open sharing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will investigate changes to the viral and bacterial communities of the gut in people who take medicine to prevent HIV infection (PrEP). I will analyze stool and blood samples from volunteers to measure what viruses and bacteria are there, how they change after 3 months of using PrEP, and how those changes affect inflammation in the intestines or the entire body. A better understanding of these changes will allow us to improve the safety and tolerability of PrEP in addition to potential probiotic, prebiotic, or anti-inflamatory interventions to increase intestinal health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Bridging the gap between biomedical discoveries and clinical practice in the United States and elsewhere is challenging. Scientists and doctors often have surprisingly distinct types of professional training in how to think and communicate about their work. We are proposing in this application to continue to train physician-scientists in both rigorous experimental science and clinical medicine, allowing them to interact with both worlds, imbue their own research programs with medically relevant themes, and push new discoveries forward to benefit public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Community-Driven Indigenous Research, Cultural Strengths & Leadership to Advance Equity in Substance Use Outcomes (CIRCLE) Center aims to address drug use related health problems and deaths in collaboration with American Indian (i.e., Indigenous) communities. The proposed CIRCLE Center will fuel a hub of Indigenous- driven research and training to understand and address drug use inequities across diverse tribal cultures and contexts. Through research, training, and outreach, we will respond to calls from Indigenous Peoples for enhanced focus on recovery and prevention, sources of strength, culture- and family-based approaches to wellness, and policy solutions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL Technology and digital media (TDM) have impact on adolescents’ behaviors, well-being and their developing brains. In this P01 program proposal, we will collect data from adolescents over time leveraging several sources, including self-report, observed social media data and functional MRI. This integrated approach to longitudinal data collection from a shared adolescent participant pool will lead to novel analyses and findings, such that this P01 program will advance conceptual models and inform new interventions to improve adolescent health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  A hallmark of cancer is the ability of malignant cells to evade various forms of cell death including ferroptosis. We postulate that activation of the MT-1G pathway limits ferroptosis in human hepatocellular carcinoma, the third leading cause of cancer-related death worldwide. Our proposal will provide new insight into understanding the mechanism of ferroptosis and guide future development of MT-1G-based novel anticancer therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE While adhesive membrane proteins are essential for maintaining tissue integrity, it is extremely challenging to map their interactions using traditional biochemical methods. The first goal of this proposal is to develop a molecular technology to discover novel membrane protein interactions in cells. The second goal of this proposal is to use this technology to resolve the assembly and organization of desmosomes, an essential adhesive structure that mediates the integrity of tissues like the epidermis and heart.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE: This project uses powerful biochemistry, pharmacology, and structural biology techniques to reveal how calcitonin family peptide hormones bind to their receptors on the surface of cells and develop novel tools for studying the receptors. The hormones regulate bone remodeling, vascular tone, blood glucose, and food intake and the receptors are drug targets for diseases including osteoporosis, migraine headache, cardiovascular disorders, and diabetes and obesity. Our studies will facilitate the development of therapeutics targeting these receptors and reveal concepts that are broadly relevant for several areas of human health and disease because the receptors are members of the large GPCR family that regulates most aspects of physiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project narrative Social memory impairment is one of the most debilitating factors in autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Understanding the circuits, cell-types and synaptic plasticity relevant for social memory will provide tangible targets for therapeutics. The proposed study will advance our basic understanding of the mechanisms underlying social memory as well as investigate potential approaches to improve social memory deficits in ASD-associated mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will conduct a mixed method study to investigate neurocognitive pathways by which neighborhood- level structural racism (i.e., socioeconomic conditions, environmental health, and educational opportunities) impacts substance use during adolescence. Findings will inform policy and interventions focused on substance use prevention among adolescents, including among Latino/a/x and Black youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and AD related dementias (ADRDs) are a major cause of disability and mortality in the United States, but there are no effective therapies to slow or reverse progressive cognitive deficits in these disorders. Moreover, we have an incomplete understanding of AD and ADRD due to insufficient recruitment and retention in understudied populations. The proposed program will add to our understanding of AD and ADRD through comprehensive social and biological assessments in understudied individuals, self-identifying as Hispanic/Latinx, Black, and Asian American/Pacific Islander in Los Angeles County.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The use of genomic data to aid diagnosis and therapeutic decisions requires electronic health records to store and manage complex genomic information. Existing technologies do not sufficiently support our current understanding of how genomics impacts health, however, so new methods must be developed. This research program will develop new approaches for managing clinical genomic information, thereby accelerating research that improves human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will determine mechanisms that control -cell and -cell Na+/K+-ATPase activity and how they regulate Ca2+ handling as well as islet hormone secretion. Results from this project are also expected to provide significant mechanistic insights into disruption of islet Ca2+ handling and hormone secretion in T2D in the context of perturbed glucose control and GPCR regulation of Na+/K+-ATPase function. Thus, the proposed research project will generate fundamental knowledge about human islet function and dysfunction that will help reduce the burden of human illness in the context of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Short-term mortality prediction is critical to optimizing healthcare quality for hospitalized older adults by identifying which patients are most likely to benefit from which healthcare services (e.g. hospice) and medications (e.g. statins). Unfortunately, we lack high-quality validated prediction tools to help clinicians determine short term mortality risk. The objective of this project is to create prediction tools for estimating short term mortality risk for hospitalized older adults with and without Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To develop Real-World Data (RWD) and Real-World Evidence (RWE) of the broad activity and benefit to society from new therapies approved by the FDA, we propose a collaborative research project to be funded under the U01 mechanism to implement novel approaches to this research. We suggest a more longitudinal approach to real-world data acquisition, starting during Phase III trial testing and feeding into a more rigorous and diverse approach to Phase IV confirmation. We will partner with Optum Life Sciences to facilitate identification of patients, especially those with rare tumors and uncommon molecular subgroups, and to build relevant cohorts to interpret community-wide treatment results.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Mastery of quantitative biology skills, through training in mathematics and statistics in high school and undergraduate laboratory courses, is crucial for the successful preparation of students for contemporary STEM careers. To address this need, we propose the continued development of the EdvoReader platform, a quantitative biology framework that combines a user-friendly instrument, a collection of hands-on educational experiments, and a citizen science curriculum to guide students through data collection and analysis. Importantly, experimentation using this platform will introduce students to quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) and colorimetry, essential laboratory techniques that have become a cornerstone of disease detection, environmental monitoring, and biotechnology research.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity-associated disease of the liver is a common and significant condition in the Mexican American Community. This study seeks to identify possible genes and their related elements that are associated with susceptibility and progression of liver disease in participants randomly chosen from the CCHC. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This study will evaluate how everyday chemicals found throughout our environment – in food packaging, medication coating, and plastics – affect mood and cognition in middle and older age women. It will also drill down to identify the biological mechanisms by which these chemicals exert their effects, exploring multiple pathways including via inflammation, sex hormones, and a brain growth factor. Understanding biological mechanisms in depression and cognitive decline is critical to developing new targets for treatment, and knowledge of the role of endocrine-disrupting chemicals in such symptoms in later life is vital to the public health, because while exposure is nearly ubiquitous, lifestyle changes can reduce such chemical exposures and may alter disease trajectories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative It is predicted that 16% of the world’s population will be older than 65 years by 2050. The proposed research project will develop new methods to assess the brain metabolism across the healthy lifespan. These techniques will contribute to our understanding of healthy aging and its link to cognitive performance, may identify biomarkers for healthy aging, and may lead to earlier identification of subject-specific abnormalities associated with a higher risk of age-related disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: RFA-HL-23-019 RMIP II-Collaborative U01. Contact PI - Gary Yam Project Narrative Millions of people suffer from corneal blindness and a low percentage of them (an estimated rate of 1 in 70) are treated by donor cornea transplantation, with limited success due to various issues like post-operative complications, graft rejection, and scarcity of donor corneas worldwide. Our team has discovered corneal stromal stem cells that can effectively reduce corneal scarring in animal models. This project aims to establish procedures to generate Good Manufacturing Practice stem cells, and confirm their safety and efficacy, leading to future clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a common genetic heart condition that causes sudden cardiac death and congestive heart failure, and for which current treatments do not slow or prevent progression of the condition. The gene that is most commonly mutated in HCM is called myosin binding protein C. The goals of this study are to understand how mutations in myosin binding protein C affect how the protein associates with other binding partners, and whether these effects can be reversed therapeutically by delivery of the normal protein using gene therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Mechanical interactions and signals provide the basis for numerous physiological processes including allowing cells to move and form multicellular structures. Misregulation of these mechanical signals has been implicated in a broad array of diseases and developmental impairments. This project investigates novel mechanisms for how proteins can sense these mechanical signals and convert them to biochemical signals, thereby uncovering new signaling pathways and potentially identifying new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Common chronic overlapping pain syndromes (COPCs), such as fibromyalgia and temporomandibular disorder, constitute one of our nation’s most significant healthcare problems, affecting nearly one in every three Americans. Despite their high prevalence, COPCs remain ineffectively treated, in large part, due to lack of valid animal models with translational relevance for discovery of safe effective therapies. Thus, the objective of this proposal is to develop and validate a novel mouse model of COPCs in which genetically predisposed mice undergo stressful and injurious events resulting in clinically-relevant behavioral and molecular phenotypes for in vivo screening of analgesic therapeutics.

PHR: Relevant statement Our proposal will identify an itch-specific brain circuit and dopamine genes influencing individual differences in itch perception. This will eventually help the many chronic itch patients regardless of the underlying etiology.

PHR: Project Narrative: The anti-tumor immunity induced by oncolytic virotherapy is blunted by numerous poorly characterized cellular pathways. For example, our preliminary data demonstrates the presence of TNF within the tumor microenvironment prevents effective oncolytic therapy by directly killing anti-tumor T cells. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early rupture of the “bag of waters”, known as the fetal membranes, often results in preterm birth with increased risk of infant mortality and morbidity. Understanding how this natural protection works may lead to therapies to prevent early rupture and preterm birth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Early identification of cognitive impairment and dementia is associated with multiple public health benefits and will become even more important if a disease-modifying treatments for Alzheimer’s disease becomes widely available. However, delayed or missed identification of dementia is common, particularly among people from racial and ethnic minority backgrounds and disadvantaged socioeconomic status. In this mixed-methods study we will identify barriers to early identification of dementia in older adults who receive healthcare in a safety net health system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Advances in Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) now support regional imaging of lung structures with CT-like contrast and high spatial resolution. The versatility of MRI data acquisition includes motion detection that can be used to track changes in lung inflation and oxygen distribution during free-breathing. This project will develop oxygen-enhanced imaging of ventilation of the lungs and high-resolution acquisition of lung anatomy in a single, free-breathing 7-minute acquisition using 3D ultra-short time to echo MRI and study multiple chronic lung diseases to establish utility and reproducibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Two of the most prominent cancers of the GI tract in the U.S. are colorectal cancer (CRC) and esophageal adenocarcinoma(EAC): CRC is the second leading cause of cancer deaths, and EAC has been the fastest increasing cause of cancer deaths over the past four decades. There is clearly unmet need for effective cancer prevention and early detection for CRC and EAC. This award will provide support for an exceptional translational cancer research scientist, Dr. Yu, to perform studies that will advance our understanding of molecular alterations in the initiation and progression of GI cancers, and accelerate the development of biomarkers for cancer prevention and early detection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This project aims to develop a lead candidate therapeutic, AAV9/AGA, as a treatment for a devastating and currently untreatable neurodegenerative disorder, Aspartylglucosaminuria (AGU). Aims are proposed to assess the safety of AAV9/AGA in preclinical models, manufacture AAV9/AGA for human use, further explore and refine clinical biomarkers relevant to assess an AGU treatment, and obtain regulatory approvals to initiate a Phase I/II clinical trial of AAV9/AGA in AGU patients. These efforts will not only lead a potentially transformative treatment for AGU, but also inform the development of similar treatments for a wide range of inherited neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Normal cognitive function requires an adequate blood supply to support neuronal activity via neurovascular coupling, and recent evidence demonstrates that age-related cognitive decline that manifests in Alzheimer’s dis- ease and related dementias (ADRD) is directly linked to reduced neurovascular coupling (NVC) responses. Caloric restriction exerts multifaceted anti-aging and lifespan-extending effects and has been demonstrated to be an effec- tive nutritional intervention that can improve vascular health and cognitive function, however, adherence to caloric restriction remains a challenge and a translational barrier as most humans may not be able, or willing, to reduce their caloric intake by 30% over extended periods of time. Based on the abundant literature in the field, our pub- lished preclinical results and preliminary data in humans, these series of studies are designed to assess a clinically relevant lifestyle intervention of time restricted eating to improve endothelial function and NVC responses in com- munity dwelling older adults to prevent and, potentially to treat, age-related cognitive decline associated with ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hepatopulmonary syndrome (HPS), the most common lung complication in cirrhosis, results in impaired transfer of oxygen into the blood, increases the risk of dying and has no effective medical treatments. The current proposal focuses on the novel hypothesis that bile acids, increased in cirrhosis, impair the function of the lung surfactant system and contribute to decreased oxygen and poor outcomes. Our goal is to develop effective treatments for HPS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Narrative Reproduction in flowering plants produces seeds thus provides for global nutritional needs, food security, and ensures ecological balance that is important for climate health. Yet the process involves complex male-female interplays and is highly sensitive to the environment, such as high and low temperatures, drought and flood, and reproductive failure devastates seed yields. Understanding the molecular mechanisms that lead to plant reproductive success will help designs of counter measures to reproductive loss and therefore relevant to NIH commitment to fundamental research in model organisms whose success ultimately protects human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anti-seizure medications (ASMs) are commonly prescribed to older adults, who often have co-occurring neurodegenerative disease. Although older adults with seizures are expected to be more sensitive to cognitive and other ASM adverse effects, knowledge gaps have resulted in a lack of medication prescribing guidance in this population. Under the guidance of my mentors, I will examine current use and comparative safety of ASMs (with special attention to cognitive decline) in older adults with and without Alzheimer’s Disease and related dementias and contribute to the evidence necessary to inform prescribing guidance by determining key decision- making factors in the context of ASM prescription in older adults with seizures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The computational and synthetic development of methods for spirocycle synthesis and alkene hydroamination provide the opportunity to access a diverse array of medicinally privileged scaffolds and new chemical structures. The establishment of a Ni-catalyzed, intramolecular addition reaction of enolates to nitriles is anticipated to generate functionalized spirocyclic lactones, which are present in various natural products and bioactive molecules. Additionally, the discovery of a strategy for the hydroamination of trisubstituted alkenes using NHC borane chemistry will produce a variety of functionalized nitrogen-containing heterocycles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE IgA vasculitis is an understudied pediatric disorder that often leads to serious complications, including kidney failure. The exact pathogenic mechanisms of IgAV remain unclear, leading to the general lack of targeted treatments and preventive strategies. This proposal aims to identify genetic determinants of IgAV to provide unbiased insights into the disease pathogenesis and enable prioritization of potential targets for new drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease is a primary competing cause of morbidity and mortality among older men diagnosed with prostate cancer, especially those treated with androgen deprivation therapy. Behavioral interventions to support the adoption and maintenance of exercise training may be a promising non-pharmacological approach to buffer the negative sequalae of treatment with ADT. Through the proposed research and training plan we will test whether a behavioral exercise training intervention, that can be remotely delivered to men across diverse settings, leads to favorable changes in exercise capacity, body composition and subclinical markers of cardiovascular function, that forecast future cardiovascular events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disparities in healthcare access, insurance coverage, and socioeconomic burdens fuel barriers to primary care especially among patients at highest risk for undiagnosed diabetes. This study seeks to identify risk factors for not being able to follow-up for a new diagnosis of diabetes in the emergency department and improve linkage of these newly diagnosed patients to appropriate outpatient care. This study will help improve diabetes surveillance by transforming the emergency department into an effective clinical setting that can help screen the millions of high-risk patients that visit emergency departments across the United States each year, thereby reducing disparities in glycemic control and the frequency of diabetic complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative. Several recently approved therapeutics have revolutionized the treatment of cystic fibrosis, which is a common genetic disease caused by a spectrum of mutations within the CFTR gene. However, the optimal combination of drugs for each patient depends on the nature of their specific genetic variations, and the optimal therapeutic combinations have yet to be determined for the hundreds of known CF mutations. The proposed investigations will utilize a combination of emerging techniques to comprehensively match current medications to these mutations and help to target new drugs as they come to market.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to apply machine learning approaches to multiple data sources including electronic health record data, high-fidelity physiological waveform data, and genomic data that have never been used together in the acute care setting to predict postoperative major complications and decrease failure-to-rescue after surgery. These inputs will be used in simulated real-time bedside management to 1) iteratively design a prototype clinical decision support tool and 2) evaluate its use in simulation upon use of postoperative continuous remote monitoring and early warning systems, accuracy and time to correct diagnosis, accuracy of intervention, and time-to-intervention. The feasibility and acceptability of this clinical decision support tool will then be assessed in a small-scale prospective, longitudinal pilot evaluation in sequential 10-weeks, 13-weeks, 10-weeks phases to help design a future, large-scale clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will provide the first evidence regarding the immediate and sustaining efficacy of an mHealth- facilitated physical activity intervention on cognitive function and sleep in low-income older adults, a population that experiences multiple social inequalities and health disparities and at high risk for Alzheimer’s disease. It will add scientific knowledge on whether physical activity impacts Amyloid/Tau/ Neurodegeneration (ATN) biomarkers and whether sleep and ATN biomarkers underline the effect of physical activity on cognitive function. If successful, the findings will support clinicians and the public to engage low-income older adults in physical activity for better sleep and cognitive health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Broadly neutralizing antibodies are a necessary component of an effective HIV vaccine, but an incomplete understanding of broadly neutralizing antibody development has impeded attempts to elicit these desirable antibody responses via vaccination. Here, I use high-throughput mutational scanning techniques to elucidate the molecular evolutionary forces and constraints that guide HIV antibody development. These detailed mutational maps will enable the design of improved HIV vaccine immunogens and therapeutic antibodies and reveal the general principles of broadly neutralizing antibody function and development with relevance for various pathogens where broad antibody responses are necessary for pathogen control.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Fragile X Syndrome (FXS) is an inherited, lifelong neurodevelopmental disorder that results in significant health and functional impairments; however, the great majority of knowledge about FXS derives from research on children, leaving adulthood a vast uncharted territory. In this proposed renewal, we will investigate FXS during adulthood and we will evaluate how the family and social contexts are associated with more favorable health and behavioral functioning during this life stage. We will leverage two distinct and rich data sources– electronic health records drawn from a racially and ethnically diverse population of 15 million patients in the Chicago area which includes 368 adults (age 18 to 80+) with FXS, and a separate longitudinal cohort of adults with FXS and their premutation carrier mothers (n=182 dyads) with up to 8 repeated measures over the 18- year period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Spectacular growth in data and scalable computing represents a tremendous opportunity to create a more diverse environmental health community trained in data science principles. We propose the creation of a short course in Data Science for Environmental Public Health that combines online learning and an in-person project-focused intensive, with special consideration for participants from institutions serving underrepresented learners. Through our experience in massively scalable education, we will create a complementary online course equivalent, interactive online community, and materials aimed at instructors who want to bring this course to other institutions, empowering a broad array of potentially thousands of environmental health scientists to improve their research with data science tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Today, approximately 15% of the adult population in the United States live with chronic kidney disease (CKD), some of which will need dialysis or transplant. Home dialysis and pre-emptive transplant, compared to in- center dialysis, may be better for patients for numerous reasons. This research seeks to understand if patients’ capacity predicts their choice of dialysis, ability to stay on that type of dialysis, or their access to transplant.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric injuries are a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in children worldwide. This K23 Career Development Award will develop and pilot test a health systems intervention to streamline the triage process (e.g. patient assessment, stabilization, and disposition), and improve time to definitive care and outcomes of pediatric injury patients. By completing the proposed research and training plans with the support of her multi- disciplinary mentorship team, Dr. Keating seeks to create a scalable intervention to address a critical public health challenge while launching an independent career as a Pediatric Emergency Medicine physician- scientist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Defects in epithelial morphology contribute to a wide range of human pathologies, including birth defects, cancer, impaired wound healing, and inflammation, so therefore, a primary focus of developmental biology has been to uncover the mechanisms that control epithelial cell shape. Studies of epithelial tissue elongation and wound healing have shown that Toll family receptors and mitochondria are critical players in the regulation of tension and adhesion at the cell membrane, although the molecular links between these processes are still being uncovered. This proposal will address how signaling by Toll receptors and mitochondrial networks interact to drive cell shape change during tissue elongation––revealing how biomechanics and bioenergetics are coordinately regulated during embryonic development and shedding light on how these processes are misregulated in disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The prevalence of HIV-associated neurocognitive disorders (HAND) remains high even with antiretroviral therapy, and there exists sex-differences in HAND; However, the underlying mechanisms remain elusive. The proposed studies are focused to determine the protective effect of 17α-estradiol, the predominant form of estrogen in brain, against brain damage resulting from combined exposure of HIV-1 viral proteins (gp120 and Tat), antiretroviral drugs, and methamphetamine. Findings are expected to provide novel insights into sex-differences in HAND and provide new targets and rationale for preventative and therapeutic interventions against HAND.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute kidney injury is a common kidney disease, often found in critically ill patients, which is induced such as by sudden cardiac arrest or by side effects from a chemotherapeutic agent. A dire consequence of acute kidney injury is progression to chronic kidney disease, which accounts for approximately 6.7% of all Medicare expenditure. This study will combine the use of cultured kidney cells with genetically modified mouse models and pharmacological approaches to investigate whether a gene termed VEGF-R2 plays an important role in acute kidney injury to chronic kidney disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is focused on the development of a novel concept of obesity and associated metabolic disorders in that a single molecule can reduce appetite, body weight and blood glucose, while protecting critical pancreatic cells from further damage, by simultaneously acting through multiple target pathways. Our group has identified several peptides that act on the receptors for glucagon-like peptide-1, neuropeptide Y1, and neuropeptide Y2, which show very promising results in pairing strong reduction of food intake and body weight with improved glucose metabolism. The goal of the proposed study is to understand the mechanisms of improved pharmacology and drug safety, to identify mechanisms leading to reduced body weight and improved glucoregulation, and to provide novel candidates including long-acting drug candidates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Adipose tissue is a critical endocrine mediator of metabolic health that is functionally altered during aging and obesity. Our preliminary data demonstrate that dietary protein restriction (DPR) improves metabolic health and remodels adipose tissue. This application tests the hypothesis that the remodeling of adipose tissue during dietary protein restriction directly improves metabolic health during aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative / Relevance Gastroparesis is a disorder of gastric function characterized by delay in gastric emptying, frequently associated with chronic nausea and vomiting, early satiety, postprandial fullness, abdominal pain, and malnutrition that may require nutritional support. There are few effective treatments available; more recently, a procedure called G-POEM (gastric peroral endoscopic myotomy) has been advocated to relieve symptoms by improving gastric emptying. However, it is not clear whether this is safe or effective. The primary aim of this pilot and feasibility, hypothesis-generating study therefore is to evaluate the effect of peroral endoscopic pyloromyotomy (G- POEM) vs. sham endoscopic surgery on symptoms in patients with diabetic or idiopathic gastroparesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE School-based health programs often provide the only access to preventive services for underserved rural children, but loss to follow-up and limited numbers of specialists are problematic. This study will prospectively  evaluate a new model of school-based, telehealth-driven preventive care (STAR) in Appalachian schools of rural  eastern Kentucky to reduce loss to follow-up from school hearing screening and improve access to specialty care in rural environments. This telehealth-driven model could be applied to a wide range of preventable health  disparities and translated to other underserved populations across rural America.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Inaccuracies in SpO2 measurement have come under scientific scrutiny during and after the pandemic. An  active public engagement discusses the consequences on people of color. The known design flaw of SpO2  measurements must be corrected to bring justice and equity. Relying on the fact that PaO2 is the primary  determinant of SaO2 in the blood and our multimodal sensor can measure the direct surrogates of these  parameters, this opportunity allows us to exploit concurrent measurements of these parameters to develop  a unique approach to mitigate racial bias in oxygenation measurements.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prevalence of mobile telephony in sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) creates an opportunity for the adoption of mobile technology for monitoring and control of hypertension, the most prevalent NCD risk factor. Capacity building initiatives include the formation of a research and education network to accelerate mHealth research in Ghana.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite remarkable clinical success of immune checkpoint blockade in a range of cancers, most colorectal cancer (CRC) patients do not respond to these treatments. Using powerful new mouse models of CRC and cutting-edge tools in immunology, I propose to deeply investigate T cell dysfunction programmed by suboptimal priming. This project aims to delineate mechanisms of efficacy and resistance to therapies targeting the T cell priming axis, with the goal of guiding clinical investigation of novel combination immunotherapies for CRC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Lipid mediators are major signaling molecule constituents in all kingdoms of life, and bacteria produce bioactive lipid mediators that are not made by mammalian cells. Inflammation in the intestine or sites of bacterial infections exemplifies the immune response to agonistic bacterial lipid mediators, but some bacteria also produce lipid countermeasures, such as hydroxy fatty acids, that can suppress the inflammatory response. This project will elucidate the immune signaling pathways that respond to hydroxy fatty acids to suppress immune responses and the biosynthetic pathways by which commensal and pathogenic bacteria release hydroxy fatty acids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Regulatory changes made during the COVID-19 public health emergency (PHE) that relaxed criteria for take- home dosing (THD) of methadone offer an opportunity to improve retention in care with a lifesaving treatment. Black/African American and Latinx clients are disproportionately affected by more restrictive THD rules than non-Latinx White clients. We will develop and test the effects of a data-informed intervention to increase THD best practices in programs that dispense methadone for treatment of opioid use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Every time cells divide, their DNA is damaged at a low level. This “endogenous” DNA damage is an important factor in normal and aberrant animal development, but because it happens at a low level over long time periods it hasn’t been possible to study in detail. I propose to develop a new tool with the resolving power to study endogenous DNA damage and other rare cellular processes over weeks to months in developing mammals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease dementia is typically associated with memory loss and accumulation of amyloid plaques, but a majority of individuals actually show mixed pathological changes in the brain, which are often associated with worse outcomes and cognitive decline than in individuals with only amyloid pathology. Unfortunately, the influence of these additional changes on disease severity and progression is poorly understood, largely because we still lack mouse models that recapitulate these additional pathologies, particularly in the presence of comorbidities relevant to human health and disease. Our objective here is to, for the first time, create models of Alzheimer’s disease and its related dementias that more accurately capture the complexity of this devastating disease in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Identification of tumor-specific T cells is critical to immunotherapy development, yet remains a challenging task. In this project we will develop a novel machine learning method to study: 1) which T cells in the tumor microenvironment are reactive to malignant cells; 2) what signature genes can be used to track the cancer- specific T cells. Outcomes from this project are expected to improve the efficacy and precision of cancer immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Abnormal vision during a childhood ‘critical period’ can cause amblyopia, also known as lazy eye, a disorder comprising several deficits in spatial vision including poor acuity and/or impaired depth perception. The proposed research is relevant to public health because knowledge of the signaling pathways that limit flexibility with neural circuitry sufficient to restore acuity and eye dominance will improve our understanding of targets for therapeutic intervention. The proposed research is relevant to the mission of the NEI/NIH to increase understanding of the critical period in order to determine how experience-dependent plasticity alters connectivity in the developing visual system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Neuroimaging methods are invaluable for managing the treatment of stroke patients in the acute phase of guiding reperfusion and salvaging tissue, and are being used more and more to understand the effect of and ultimately guide treatments in the chronic phase of functional brain recovery. However, there is a great need for studies in well-established and properly controlled preclinical stroke models to evaluate the evolution of the structural and functional aspects of chronic neurovascular recovery, for a better mechanistic understanding of these biological interactions, and to understand their prognostic value for predicting behavioral outcomes following stroke. Our aims are designed to meet these needs by using a novel combination of optical technologies and a preclinical stroke model, and will provide a solid foundation for the continued and growing use of fMRI and fNIRS for studying human brain functional recovery post-stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A novel fatty acid synthesis inhibitor, MTI-301 (aka SSI-4), sensitizes cancers to immune  checkpoint inhibitors. This new therapeutic strategy should increase the number of patients  responding to treatment and may lead to cures through prolonged activation of immune T cells in  drug resistant cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Developing accurate, cost-effective, and scalable biomarkers of aging and age-related frailty could help in assessing longevity interventions in the lab or patient outcomes in the context of clinical trials of age-related disease. This proposal describes the development of a method for high-throughput assay of DNA methylation clocks, a robust class of age predictors, which will be used to make a novel type of biomarker based on age and mouse frailty scores. Additionally, this research will probe the mechanistic underpinnings of DNA methylation clocks and epigenomic change with age in mouse muscle using the novel method for clock analysis in combination with established genomic techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The Pathogen Data Network offers a unique opportunity to support the mobilization, sharing and interpretation of pathogen- and infectious-disease data, laying the foundation for establishing data-sharing policies that tackle well-known barriers such as trust, ownership and data FAIR- ification. This ambitious project will establish a global network of engaged user communities and provide technical specifications and reference implementations for facilitating the sharing of data fairly, equitably and responsibly for the benefit of research and, above all, public health. Thanks to this international undertaking supported by NIH, countries will be better equipped to work collaboratively to deal with potential future outbreaks and advance their research on infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Most patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), a devastating inherited muscle wasting disease, die from heart failure in their second or third decade of life. We have identified a novel, subcutaneously administered drug candidate that slows the progressive damage to the heart associated with DMD. Our proposed studies will carry out safety and toxicology testing of this drug candidate, which is the final requirement before clinical trials in humans can begin.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS THE STATE UNIV OF NJ NEWARK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intestinal epithelial cell DNA methylation patterns, which can be reversed by the ten-eleven translocation (TET) enzymes, can be altered by microbiota. How TET-mediated DNA oxidation dynamics affect mucosal innate immune response and inflammatory susceptibility are unknown. This MPI project uses mouse genetics and DNA epigenetic approaches to elucidate the contribution of TET-dependent DNA oxidations for the function of intestinal epithelial cells, Paneth cell and intestinal stem cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The Bacterial and Viral Bioinformatics Center (BV-BRC), a unified knowledgebase and analysis resource, serves over 45,000 infectious disease researchers studying bacterial and viral pathogens by providing integrated access to omics data, analysis services, workspace, and extensive training material. We propose to maintain, extend, and enhance BV-BRC by building innovative tools for comprehensive bacterial, viral and metagenomic analyses, aiding development of diagnostics and therapeutics, developing a next-generation AI- driven natural language-based user interface, and honing tools and procedures for pandemic preparedness. We are strongly committed to enhancing diversity, equity, inclusion, and accessibility through our open and inclusive training and outreach program and our partnership with the University of Illinois at Chicago, a minority serving institution (MSI), to boost our outreach to the students and researchers from minority and underserved communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The opportunistic Gram-negative pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Paer) is a leading cause of serious burn wound infections that are difficult to treat and frequently lead to sepsis, resulting in a high mortality rate, even when patients are treated with appropriate antibiotics. To address the need for treatments that prevent sepsis, we will evaluate the ability of a novel class of potential drugs that inhibit the type 3 secretion system (T3SS), the major mechanism that Paer uses to establish infections and to spread throughout the host, as a novel treatment for serious burn wound infections. Successful completion of this project will result in 1-2 validated T3SS inhibitors that will be developed further as a novel drug that will be administered with an FDA-approved antibiotic to treat Paer burn wound infections and prevent sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE STATEMENT) Liver diseases caused over 51,600 deaths in the USA in 2020 (American Liver Foundation). It is estimated that 25% of the adult population in the country has liver disease, with the most common diagnosis of fatty liver that includes nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), along with viral and alcoholic chronic liver disease. The liver also experiences hepatic ischemia/reperfusion injury during major liver surgery and liver transplantation, as well as liver damage during sepsis and other inflammatory disease states. Human liver tumor cell lines or animal liver cells are not good models to mimic primary human liver cell response to pathophysiologic disease states. Our overall goal of the Human Liver Tissue & Hepatocytes Research Resource (HLTHRR) program is to provide normal human liver tissue and normal human hepatocytes (HC) and non-parenchymal cells (NPC) including NPC sub-fractions (Kupffer cells, sinusoidal endothelial cells, cholangiocytes, and stellate cells) to biomedical researchers across the USA to study acute and chronic liver diseases to improve public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE DNA methylation regulates pluripotency, differentiation and tissue-specific gene expression thus playing a key role in normal development. Dnmt3b is a critical DNA methyltransferase involved in epigenome remodeling soon after conception. Understanding molecular mechanisms utilizing various Dnmt3b activities in embryogenesis, postnatal development and in assisted reproductive technologies will provide fundamental knowledge about processes governing mammalian development and may lead to new therapeutic strategies in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sarcoidosis is a systemic immune mediated disease that has an unknown etiology, and is currently treated with broadly acting immunosuppressive therapy that can result in significant toxicity. Studies have identified independent associations between sarcoidosis and genetics, immunity, and demographics, but there have been few integrative analyses of these factors. The proposed project will: (1) help characterize immunological profiles associated with and predictive of sarcoidosis disease severity, while accounting for non-immune risk factors, (2) will provide insight that can aid in identifying high risk patients and decision making regarding appropriate use of therapeutics, and (3) will set the foundation for follow-up studies on the development of targeted therapeutics for sarcoidosis patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE IPF is a terminal lung disease causing 40,000 deaths in the US each year, with a life expectancy of three to five years. Cell replacement therapy to regenerate IPF lungs is a potential curative solution, but we cannot generate the lung cells needed in a scalable and cost-effective way. Cellforma is creating an AI/ML platform to overcome this challenge to develop curative, first-in-class, cell replacement therapy for IPF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Hepatitis B virus (HBV) chronically infects about 250 million people with annual 1 million deaths worldwide. The search for a cure of chronic hepatitis B has been hampered by the lack of small animal models of HBV infection and replication. The overall goal of this application is to develop murine models of HBV infection and replication for the study of HBV infection, replication, pathogenesis, and carcinogenesis. More importantly, murine models of HBV infection will foster discovery and development of more effective antiviral drugs towards a cure of chronic hepatitis B.

IC_NAME: National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
PHR: Project Narrative The onset of the global pandemic of coronavirus disease 2019 elevated the importance of accurate predictive modeling of disease transmission. The proposed research aims to develop a framework of pandemic predictive intelligence that can adapt over time to changing data quality and evolving behavioral and environmental characteristics that influence disease transmission. To ensure the broader impact of the proposed research, we will develop, validate, and evaluate methodology and software for pandemic forecasting, real-time monitoring, mitigation, and prevention of the spread of pathogens using national county/city-level data from the US Department of Health and Human Services, Department of Microbiology at the University of Pennsylvania, and other publicly available data resources.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Characterizing dynamics of pandemic and preparing for speedy and accurate response

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In this project we will determine the roles of specialized white blood cells, called tumor-specific T cells, in promoting an immune response against tumors in mice and determine their potential for use in cancer immunotherapy. We hypothesize that transfer of modified tumor-specific T cells will eradicate large established tumors and prevent recurrence of antigen-loss-variant tumors, due to their ability to 1) directly kill the tumor cells; 2) induce intratumor release of type I IFNs to promote host antitumor immune responses; and 3) effectively eradicate large established tumors in vivo in both mouse and human.

PHR: Project Narrative Heart Failure with Preserved Ejection Fraction (HFpEF) is the most common form of heart failure in the U.S. and is associated with high morbidity and mortality. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Endometriosis is a persistent and enigmatic gynecologic disease that affects approximately 10-15% of reproductive-aged women. The proposed research seeks to uncover mechanisms by which altered immune cell function potentially leads to uterine dysfunction and peritoneal inflammation as seen in women with endometriosis. We expect to identify an immunologic “footprint” of endometriosis which should foster the development of intervention and prevention strategies by using immune cells as diagnostic/ therapeutic tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a serious health concern that is inadequately treated with existing therapies. Falling “drive-to-breathe” during sleep is implicated as causing events in most patients (60%, i.e. “drive- dependent” subtype). The proposed mechanistic research studies will 1) critically-test the role of falling ventila- tory drive in OSA through its physiological mitigation in sleeping patients, 2) examine whether mitigating venti- latory drive reduction with acetazolamide—a promising OSA intervention for many patients—is most effica- cious in “drive-dependent” OSA, 3) providing a means to identify the drive-dependent patients who will benefit most.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE High-throughput single-cell RNA sequencing offers unprecedented opportunities for understanding the biology of cell differentiation. This project will use single-cell data in in-silico experiments to identify new drug targets and generate new hypotheses for pre-clinical investigation. Our goals are: (1) control of angiogenesis, a process involved in many ischemic, inflammatory, infectious, and immune disorders, and (2) new schemes for direct reprogramming of lymphocytes from induced pluripotent stem cells.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Veterans who suffer strokes often have disturbances in the ability to walk that reduces independence and quality of life. Alterations in gait combined with general decreased activity are associated with reduced muscle strength of the paretic leg. This leads to cardiovascular deconditioning and reduced quality of life. There is a new and novel battery powered device (Keeogo powered orthotic exoskeleton) that uses motors that assist knee movement while walking, sitting down, and standing up. The Keeogo monitors hip movement to assist the knee, making it simple to learn how to use. If successful, this project will show how this device will help improve the ability to walk and provide evidence to support larger clinical trials in a home and community setting to improve mobility, increase muscle mass and strength in the legs, as well as improve general health and quality of life. Lastly, this device could be used to increase motivation and confidence in a person to walk for longer periods of time and distance, providing the ability to walk in places that were previously inaccessible.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Cell-based therapies for cartilage injury and osteoarthritis rely largely on in vitro engineering of replacement cartilage from mesenchymal progenitors, but are plagued by the instability of the cartilage cell (chondrocyte) phenotype: mammalian stem-cell derived chondrocytes tend to either hypertrophy or dedifferentiate when implanted into a patient. However, cartilaginous fishes (sharks, skates, and rays) possess a skeleton that is composed entirely of pre-hypertrophic cartilage, and that remains cartilaginous throughout life. In this study, I will use single-cell RNA-sequencing and comparative genomics to identify gene expression correlates of permanent pre-hypertrophic cartilage in the skate (Leucoraja erinacea), and use skate-inspired molecular manipulations to achieve and optimize a stable chondrocyte cell state from mammalian mesenchymal progenitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative. The proposed research is relevant to public health because the development of novel chemistry to synthesize small molecules with new core structures is critical to the discovery of new leads for drug discovery. As such, the experiments described in this proposal are relevant to the NIH’s mission because they will enable the discovery of previously inaccessible molecules with the potential to become new medicines that will "enhance health, lengthen life, and reduce illness and disability."

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT SUMMARY  We have identified follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) as a new target for treating Alzheimer’s disease, along with three other crippling diseases of the aging population, namely osteoporosis, obesity and high cholesterol. For this, we have designed a lead therapeutic antibody to FSH, which we will take through early stage development in this proposal. This should provide us with critical pieces of information on the likely dose, route and frequency of administration, allowing it to move through the late stage development pipeline into clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is among the deadliest blood cancers, affecting 20,000 Americans per year with a 5-year survival rate of only 30%. While engineering cells of the immune system to target cancer is one of the most promising approaches in treatment today, this approach has been difficult to apply in AML due both to lack of specific targets on tumor cells as well as the fact that many tumor cells may not express a single targeted antigen. Here I aim to perform initial development of a new type of engineered cell that can specifically eliminate the relapse-driving residual tumor cells after initial chemotherapy, with the long term goal of achieving more AML cures with lower toxicity than current approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The AVRC P30 Core facility serves as a centralized vision research resource in Atlanta where faculty from Emory University, Georgia Institute of Technology, Georgia State University, Morehouse School of Medicine, and The Atlanta Veterans Administration Medical Center can undertake joint studies in vision research. The P30 Core facilitates the research of investigators holding NEI R01 grants by providing access to equipment and services that would not be possible on individual R01 grants. The P30 Core also promotes the research projects of pre- and postdoctoral fellows supported by our NEI Training Grant (T32 EY007092-34), recently renewed for five years (2020-2025) and buttresses active recruitment of new tenure-track research faculty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Hydrogenase enzymes are pervasive in bacteria and archaea, many of which inhabit the human gut and some of which are pathogenic. Elucidating the biosynthesis and mechanisms of hydrogenases underpins strategies for controlling these organisms. Pharmaceutically relevant concepts and strategies result from the study of hydrogenases, the understanding of which has revolutionized the manipulation of the simplest of all molecules, the fuel H2.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Treatments are needed to improve affective function in patients with comorbid chronic low back pain and depression. Psilocybin is a non-opioid therapeutic that has already demonstrated efficacy for the treatment of depression and holds promise for use as a pain management medicine. This project will test the effect of psilocybin on affective function in patients with comorbid chronic low back pain and depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The Functional Genomics and Proteomics (FG&P) Core supports research that increases our understanding of how biological function (e.g., vision) arises from the information encoded in an organism's genome. The Core provides expertise, personnel, training, and equipment for the design, execution, and analysis of molecular, biochemical, proteomic, and vision function and structure experiments. This support is for AVRC investigators who are NEI R01-funded but who cannot justify such services or equipment independently in a single R01- funded project or who are not experts in FG&P techniques. By removing these "barriers of entry," the FG&P Core helps these investigators increase the impact of their research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal, we aim to establish the role of a specific ribonucleic acid molecule called KMT2E-AS1 that we believe promotes the development of a deadly yet enigmatic disease of the blood vessels in the lung, pulmonary hypertension (PH). We also will pursue evidence that specific changes in our DNA control the expression of this molecule and increase the risk of PH for those individuals. If successful, our work will set the stage for a new era for medical care of PH patients, whereby therapies that target this molecular pathway can be deployed to specific individuals with the highest likelihood of a positive response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sexual minority women (SMW; e.g., lesbian, bisexual) are at disproportionately high risk of hazardous drinking (HD) and associated negative health outcomes compared to heterosexual women, likely due to their higher lifetime exposure to multiple and chronic stressors. Although there is a great deal of literature demonstrating that close, intimate relationships buffer stress among women in the general population, very little research has investigated HD within SMW's intimate relationships. This study aims to understand HD within same-sex female couples by considering both individual- and couple-level perspectives with the goal of informing the development of interventions to help couples implement healthy coping strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Phase 2 of the “Center for Translational Viral Oncology” (CTVO) will leverage success of Phase 1coupled to evolving research themes that incorporate new faculty expertise and health-disparate, cancer prone populations in our region to study virus-induced malignancies. These cancers are highly prevalent in Louisiana and occur at increased incidence in people living with HIV. The overarching goal of CTVO is to improve disease management and quality of life across the diverse spectrum of Louisiana cancer patients through responsive research activity including the following 1) sustaining the career development of talented Junior Principal Investigators (JPIs) 2) supporting existing and coalescing research between regional scientists in viral oncology and 3) reinforcing the institutionalization of productive core facilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to indoor and outdoor air pollution in India is strongly associated with the risk for cancers of the aerodigestive tract, including lung cancer and head and neck cancer. Biomarkers of air pollutant exposure and effect can serve as powerful tools in identifying individuals or populations at risk and informing the development of preventive measures. This study will develop capacity for biomarker research in India and will generate important new knowledge of the role of air pollution in the risk for aerodigestive tract cancer in nonsmokers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The intestinal epithelium plays critical roles in digestion and pathogen defense, and its integrity is maintained by a pool of proliferative intestinal stem cells. Recently a population of subepithelial mesenchymal telocytes have been identified as a critical niche population supplying cytokines to support stem cell activity. We address whether telomere dysfunction, which occurs during natural ageing and pathologically in telomeropathies, results in intestinal stem cell failure due to a loss of extrinsic niche support from the telocyte stem cell niche.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative/Public Health Relevance Regulation of gene expression is essential for cellular differentiation, development, and homeostasis. Mediator, a large and dynamic multi-protein complex conserved in all eukaryotic organisms, plays an indispensable role in gene expression regulation. We will use biochemistry, genetics, macromolecular electron microscopy and advanced image analysis techniques, to discover how Mediator performs its essential function in control of gene expression. The results of our studies are critical to public health because dysregulation of gene expression is directly connected to developmental disorders, cancer and other human pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Although chemotherapy related cardiac toxicity is associated with decreased survival outcomes in children receiving treatment for acute myeloid leukemia (AML), there are no clinical prediction models for incident cardiac toxicity or trajectories of the progression or resolution of cardiac dysfunction. The well described disparities in survival outcomes by race and ethnicity in pediatric AML have not included analyses of echo monitoring adherence or subsequently identified cardiac dysfunction. This application seeks to address these knowledge gaps with following three specific aims: (1) Develop and validate dynamic prediction models for incident early chemotherapy associated LVSD, defined as ejection fraction (EF) ≤50% or fractional shortening (SF) ≤24%, in pediatric AML patients; (2) develop and validate prediction models for latent phenotypes defined by distinct trajectories of LV function based on longitudinal echo-derived measures of LVEF in pediatric AML patients, and (3) identify disparities in off-therapy echo monitoring, early incident chemotherapy associated LVSD, and evaluate their role as intermediates in disparities in survival outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our recent multimodal brain imaging studies have shown that quantification of auditory white matter microstructure (measured via diffusion-MRI) can model, or predict, the timing of a brain’s response to a sound (measured via magnetoencephalography (MEG)), and that with this technique we can identify an “outlier” sub-population of children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) who are also deficient in a brain neurochemical called GABA, important in regulating brain function and a candidate for biological treatment targets. The present study extends this work to the scientifically and societally critical group of children with ASD with severe language and cognitive impairment, whose participation in this multimodal brain imaging study is made possible via a behavioral and technical protocol we have recently developed, called MEG-PLAN. With the inclusion of clinical control groups (children with intellectual and developmental disability without autism and children with specific language impairment but absent general cognitive impairment), we will first identify the relative associations of language impairment, cognitive impairment and ASD symptoms to a delayed auditory response, and then investigate the biophysical underpinnings of these associations with auditory cortex white matter and auditory cortex GABA levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In embryonic development, gastrulation is a pivotal process for the differentiation of all the lineages and the cells types that descent from them. Our proposed studies aim to understand how genome three-dimensional (3D) reorganization helps establish each lineage in gastrulation, how well these reorganizations are conserved within each lineage, and how they are disrupted by epigenetic perturbations that are associated with diseases. This research may reveal novel mechanisms for human development and epigenetic diseases and thus empower therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE State and federal policymakers have increasingly expanded insurance coverage for gender affirming services, which could reduce health inequities for the nearly 2 million gender minority (i.e., transgender and gender diverse) individuals in the U.S. This study will examine the implementation of gender affirming coverage policies in Medicaid to inform ongoing policy debates regarding the adoption of such policies. Through the research and training in this Mentored Research Scientist Career Development Award, the candidate will be prepared to pursue innovative research to improve health care access and outcomes for sexual and gender minority communities.

PROJECT_TITLE: Policy effects on gender minority health and evidence from the implementation of gender affirming coverage in Medicaid

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The difficulty in early, reliable prediction of drug penetration into the human brain and brain tumors makes the development of new drugs and use of existing drugs for treating brain cancer a challenging and usually unsuccessful task. This project will develop a physiologically based pharmacokinetic model platform that will improve our ability to more readily and reliably predict the levels of anticancer drugs in the human brain and brain tumors. This mechanism-based computational model platform promises to become a valuable tool to assist drug developers and health care providers in the development of more effective therapies and optimal use of current therapies to treat brain cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance to Public Health Retinal disease remains a major cause of legal blindness. Despite advances in the genetics of retinal degeneration, in many cases, the pathogenic processes have defied elucidation. The work proposed in the application will address disease mechanisms that accompany obesity and involve vitamin A and by-products of the visual cycle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Cells have implemented robust stress-responsive systems that drive gene expression to cope with environmental perturbations that cause protein damages. These systems also have broader roles in animal physiology including development and reproduction, and can be hijacked in disease, such as cancer. The mission of this research is to understand the roles of the stress responsive systems in these physiological and pathological conditions, and to provide insights on regulating their activities for organismal health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because partial restoration of hearing from a technological intervention called a bionic cochlear implant is becoming increasingly common, allowing people to obtain access to sound in both ears, but not yet providing all of the expected benefits. This research aims to maximize the benefits from implantation and two-eared hearing. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission to develop new knowledge and improve technologies to help treat disability and NIDCD’s mission to provide technological interventions for hearing loss.
