IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The National Institutes of Health (NIH) designated the sexual and gender minority (SGM) communities a health disparity population in late 2016, acknowledging the disproportionate health burdens experienced by individuals who are socially marginalized on the basis of sex, sexual orientation, and gender identity (SSOGI). However, best-practice approaches to collecting demographic data on SSOGI characteristics remain poorly defined and inconsistently used across health care, research, and practice settings, limiting the ability to accurately measure SGM health disparities and presenting a significant barrier to appropriately addressing SGM health needs. As such, the Project Recognize team proposes to use a community-engaged, mixed methods approach to: assess the current state of SSOGI measurement; iteratively develop new SSOGI assessments; test the acceptability of new versus prior measures and investigate their ability to detect the magnitude of SGM health disparities in alcohol use, substance use, and mental health within a large, diverse sample; and leverage existing connections in research, clinical, and federal surveillance settings to support systemic, multi-level advancement in SSOGI data capture.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this study is to improve our understanding of the metabolic consequences and cardiovascular risk profiles of women with a history of preterm delivery. We will achieve this by analyzing a wide panel of metabolites among 1500 women in the Nurses' Health Study (NHS) 2 and NHS3, and identifying metabolite profiles and metabolite scores (M-PTD) for women with a history of preterm delivery in NHS2/3, compared to women with term pregnancies. We will examine the association of these M-PTD scores with cardiovascular outcomes in separate populations, as well as formally test mediation of preterm delivery cardiovascular risk by the M-PTD score. Additionally, we will examine the association of different clinical phenotypes of preterm delivery with cardiovascular outcomes. These data will improve our understanding of underlying mechanisms and pathways that contribute to cardiovascular disease risk in women with a history of preterm delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Relevance to Public Health: We propose to evaluate genetic and epigenetic factors for progression to Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) in a large established cohort of Caucasian individuals who have the precursor condition called monoclonal B-cell lymphocytosis (MBL). To address the widening equity gap with respect to our understanding of MBL and progression to CLL in African American populations, we will also develop a newly formed African American cohort of MBLs in order to conduct exploratory analyses of these genetic and epigenetic factors. The results of our study may provide the development of a risk prediction tool that in turn may provide the development of new clinical recommendations for individuals with MBL; it will also provide needed initial data in African Americans with MBL.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Public Health Narrative We will establish a Diagnostic Center of Excellence focusing on decreasing diagnostic errors in medical imaging by implementing and evaluating a highly resilient system for care planning and coordination, as well as a peer learning system for clinical providers. In addition, we will seek consensus on evidence-based recommendations to enhance diagnosis of four targeted diseases – lung, prostate, pancreas and adrenal cancer. Combined, these initiatives may help reduce delayed, wrong, or missed diagnoses that contribute to poor patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Structural and functional studies of the terpenoid cyclases show how these novel enzymes generate the largest and most diverse family of natural products found on the Earth. Importantly, many terpenoids exhibit useful medicinal properties, e.g., as antibacterial, antifungal, anti-inflammatory, or anticancer agents. Therefore, understanding and engineering terpenoid cyclase function in generating complex carbon scaffolds will ultimately enable drug discovery at the interface of natural products chemistry, enzymology, structural biology, and synthetic biology.

PHR: Project Narrative We describe a training program that seeks to identify a group of highly talented predoctoral students to become the next generation of researchers in the neuroscience of aging who will provide significant advances in the understanding and treatment of age-related changes in brain function and age-related neurodegenerative conditions such as Alzheimer's disease. Predoctoral students are offered a flexible, interdisciplinary program of course work, coupled with basic and/or translational research in the neuroscience of aging, to achieve these important goals that will contribute to improved public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The promise of molecularly targeted therapy for cancer patients has largely not been realized due to heteroge- neous resistance mechanisms, where targeted monotherapy typically results in short term response not long- term cure. Unraveling the complexities of therapeutic resistance is challenging because it is a complex interplay of drug distribution and target engagement as well as multifaceted and dynamic interactions between the tumor and its microenvironment. We have developed critical new tools (i.e., Therapeutic Response Imaging through Proteomics and Optical Drug Distribution and binding, TRIPODD) to quantify therapeutic efficacy and the corre- sponding resistance mechanisms to aid in crafting effective cancer treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Transcriptional dysregulation is common characteristic of cells in disease states, but the combinatorial complexity with which non-coding elements and chromatin regulatory proteins interact to determine gene expression makes it difficult to determine how transcriptional dysregulation arises and how it can be therapeutically reversed. In the F99 phase, I improve high- throughput CRISPR methods to accurately link regulatory elements with genes and I develop high-throughput recruitment assays to systematically identify the domains within human chromatin regulators that repress gene expression. In the K00 phase, I propose to develop high- throughput approaches that dissect transcriptional dysregulation in kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Human microbiome plays a critical role in the etiology and progress of many diseases. This proposal explicitly addresses the hidden batches and biases in microbiome sequencing studies, two of the most important challenges that impede our ability to make reproducible and trustworthy microbiome discoveries in large-scale microbiome studies. The proposed methods will be applied to ongoing microbiome studies to gain a better understanding of the complex microbiome-relationship, laying the foundation toward microbiom-informed treatment and prevention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This proposal evaluates new supratherapeutic paclitaxel-loaded buttresses for tumor bed implantation to reduce locoregional recurrence rates after resection of retroperitoneal, non-GIST abdominal, and pelvic sarcomas. The current standard of care is multivisceral resection, and adjuvant therapies including radiotherapy, single-dose hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy, and systemic chemotherapy fail to improve patient outcomes. This proposed approach has the potential to reduce tumor recurrence and extend survival via local application of high-dose adjuvant chemotherapeutics at the time of resection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity is a significant risk factor for various health conditions, including metabolic syndrome, cardiovascular disease, and type 2 diabetes; several classes of prescription medication, including second generation antipsychotics (SGAs), increase obesity risk by disrupting the gut microbial community. This project focuses on microbiome shifts caused by risperidone, an SGA that causes weight gain, and reutericyclin, a specialized microbial metabolite that deflects risperidone-induced weight gain. Our findings will reveal how xenobiotic- mediated induction of bacteriophages can lead to shifts in energy flux and will inform the development of phage-targeted therapeutic strategies against the development of obesity in individuals taking prescription medications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obstructive sleep apnea is common in children and most often treated by adenotonsillectomy, but after surgery the condition may persist, which can lead to neurocognitive and cardiovascular morbidity and increased healthcare utilization. Drug-induced sleep endoscopy (DISE) is a sedated, fiber-optic assessment of the upper airway that can direct individualized surgical treatment in children with sleep apnea. This research will help to determine the ideal anesthetic protocol for DISE in children, and whether the information gained from DISE prior to adenotonsillectomy can help predict post-operative outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ColoCare Study is a cohort of recently diagnosed patients with colorectal cancer (stage I-IV) that utilizes standardized protocols for longitudinally collecting participant questionnaires, biospecimens, medical record data, and clinical and patient-reported outcomes. Over 3,000 demographically and geographically diverse participants have been recruited (with a median follow-up time of 2.1 years, contributing >8,000 questionnaires and >17,000 biospecimens), and ColoCare data and/or biospecimens have supported 79 projects involving 72 external investigators (19 projects led by external investigators and 49 from early stage investigators and trainees). In this renewal, we will extend follow-up through 5 years post-diagnosis; prioritize recruitment of patients from underserved/understudied populations and with early-onset colorectal cancer; continue repeat ascertainment of self-reported data (including patient-reported outcomes) and blood samples; and enhance our centralized data repository and biobank to support data sharing and research that will improve colorectal cancer treatment, survivorship, and clinical outcomes.

PHR: Project Narrative Numerous studies have demonstrated that TBC is an evidence-based strategy for improving blood pressure (BP) management and control, but primary care practices experience significant barriers to implementing TBC care processes, particularly in small-medium size independent primary care practices. The objective of this study is to compare the effectiveness of PF on the adoption of core TBC components, centered on improving BP management and outcomes in SIPs, to usual care. Identifying strategies that increase the adoption of TBC are important to address the high burden of hypertension in the US, a leading risk factor for cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: We seek to understand whether the observed racial disparities in monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS), the precursor to multiple myeloma, may be explained by differences in underlying immune alterations and B-cell activation as well as lifestyle factors such as obesity, diabetes, and use of anti-inflammatory medications between racial/ethnic groups. To address these research questions, we will conduct an epidemiologic study among four racially/ethnically diverse cohorts with available archived serum specimens for exposure and outcome assessment. Findings from this study will provide critical information on the determinants of the racial/ethnic disparity in MGUS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Metabolic Dysregulation and Cancer Risk Consortium (MDCRC) is being created to study the biologic mechanisms by which obesity increases the risk of cancer in humans and will bring together several research groups studying how obesity alters normal metabolic pathways leading to cancer risk. The Consortium members will work together to identify common areas of data collection, and develop of a harmonized data set to accelerate research and discovery. The MDCRC Coordinating Center will facilitate the creation of this rich research data set, as well as provide both scientific leadership and project management for the collaborative cross-Consortium activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The catalytic fixation of nitrogen to ammonia is foundational to modern society, enabling adequate fertilizer production to feed billions of people; however, the analogous catalytic transformation of N2 into amines, a highly prized motif in pharmaceuticals, through nitrogen–carbon bond formation has not been realized. New insights into proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) pathways for N2 reduction, combined with a renaissance in methods for the generation of organic radicals, offer the potential for an efficient synthesis of a wide range of amines. The goal of this proposal is to develop orthogonal approaches to N2 coupling with organic substrates driven by a PCET mediator, providing a fundamental understanding of bond-forming processes in N2 functionalization and access to a diverse set of medicinally relevant compounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pulmonary embolism (PE) remains a leading cause of death in the United States. This project aims to develop a new ensemble deep learning model and train the model in a distributed fashion on multi-institutional data to automate the risk stratification of PE by integrating diagnostic computed tomography imaging with clinical electronic medical record data. This precision-medicine approach has the potential to rapidly and accurately perform PE risk assessment at the point of care, which could help reduce adverse clinical outcomes and increase our understanding of post-PE complications.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The education and training of young MD and PhD researchers is the lifeblood of continued progress in medical care. By training young MD and PhD researchers side by side, this program also reinforces the importance of intellectual cross fertilization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: R-loops are DNA:RNA hybrids that have been shown to play parts in normal cellular physiology and in disease states, and this project is designed to investigate a novel mechanism for the resolution of R-loop structures. The successful completion of this project will contribute to the fundamental knowledge of R-loop processing as part of eukaryotic cellular physiology as well as applications to human diseases such as neurologic disorders and cancer.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The diagnostic process unfolds longitudinally across settings over time; diagnostic harm occurs with similar frequency in outpatient and in-patient settings along this journey. Communication failures underlying diagnostic errors suggests an opportunity for robust communication among teams and with children and families. Using S1 and S2 approaches, among children with multiple chronic conditions, we will characterize the diagnostic journey, focusing on patient/family-clinician communication, and adapt and test the impact of an outpatient structured family-centered communication intervention (PFC I-PASS) on diagnostic success, errors and harm.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Re-engineering Patient and Family Communication to Improve Diagnostic Safety Resilience

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE/PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal directly addresses the public health burden of the rising rates of significant falls in older adults which are the leading cause of traumatic morbidity and mortality in the elderly. Specifically, the use of an automated screening tool harnesses existing data resources and information systems to use the ED to better coordinate care between the ED and existing preventive resources in the health system. Beyond improving care for older adults with falls, this study will demonstrate the promise of using information technology to deliver public health interventions in the ED setting without diverting provider resources from the core ED mission of providing quality acute care.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Preventing Future Falls in Older Adult ED Patients: Evaluating the Implementation and Effectiveness of a Novel Automated Screening and Referral Intervention

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Coordinated beating of the heart relies on specialized heart cells known as the cardiac conduction system (CCS). Damage to this system can result in a host of diseases including life-threatening arrhythmias. The proposed research will examine the mechanisms underlying CCS development and function, creating translational opportunities aimed at the prevention and treatment of cardiac rhythm disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death globally, with 80% of the burden in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), but little is known about CVD incidence rates and associated risk factors in these settings. Our study will provide the first population-based incidence estimates of CVD risk factors and adjudicated events including heart failure, stroke, ischemic disease, and cardiac death in Haiti, and we will identify modifiable factors that can be targets for future evidence-based CVD prevention. The proposed research is the critical next step towards fighting the CVD epidemic in LMICs and will provide global insights on CVD health disparities in the 21st century.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Emphysema is a common serious co-morbidity in people living with HIV (PLWH). We will study if doxycycline slows its progression in PLWH (current or former smokers) by measuring diffusing capacity (how well oxygen transfers from air into blood) and quantifying computed tomography (CT) scans of the lungs. We will evaluate if doxycycline improves health status with patient-oriented surveys and functional status with 6 minute walk tests in a multi-center, randomized, placebo-controlled trial.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Significance) There is little research on the intersection of race, ethnicity, physical disability, and maternal and infant outcomes. The proposed study will investigate pregnancy complications and outcomes among Black women and Latinas with physical disabilities by analyzing existing state and national data from a variety of sources, conducting qualitative interviews with Black women and Latinas who have given birth, and conducting focus groups with obstetric care providers. This study will examine disparities in care and create and disseminate practice recommendations to improve perinatal care for Black women and Latinas with physical disabilities.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: We will apply synthetic biology and advanced control theory techniques to genetically program human induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSCs) that generate vascularized pancreatic organoids suitable for endocrine/exocrine and other developmental studies. Our engineered genetic circuits embedded in hiPSCs will regulate multi-step differentiation of these hiPSCs into desired population ratios of the multiple lineages comprising complex pancreatic organoid structures. Our proposed research represents a departure from current in vitro organoid synthesis protocols and will usher in a fresh perspective on organogenesis that will be germane to the precise synthesis of any organoid, as well as to other feedback regulated multi-cellular systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During the initial SARS CoV-2 (COVID-19) outbreak in the first half of 2020, epicenter areas such as New York City were particularly hard hit and traditional ambulatory care ceased entirely for several months. Older adults with multiple chronic conditions were not only at high risk for poor health outcomes due to COVID-19 infection, but also disruption of ambulatory care for this vulnerable population may have resulted in meaningful short and longer-term impacts on cardiovascular health. This study leverages two large electronic health record networks to measure the impact of care disruptions on cardiovascular health and health disparities following the acute pandemic shutdown.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cesarean delivery, when overused, is harmful to women and newborns, and raises healthcare costs without appreciable benefit; yet, despite significant efforts to reduce overuse, persistent and scalable improvement has been elusive. Organizational culture change strategies have been successful in improving outcomes in other areas of healthcare, but tend to receive little attention in statewide cesarean reduction initiatives as evidence- based tools to facilitate change are lacking. This proposal seeks to use rigorous user-centered design and implementation science principles to develop a “Culture Change Toolset” to target the most upstream causes of L&D units’ failure to adopt and sustain change in cesarean delivery rates.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Supporting Vaginal Birth in Illinois: the Role of Unit Culture

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This innovative study utilizes a technology based novel care model to provide timely care to cancer survivors with CIPN in their time of greatest need and strives to improve quality of life while reducing disability and opiate use. It seeks to fill an important gap in knowledge about CIPN care using consensus based guidelines without time consuming face to face encounters. The study has broad potential impact and relevance as this care model can be integrated into health systems encouraging telemedicine, in particular rural or resource poor areas with reduced healthcare access.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Schizophrenia is a genetic, neurodevelopmental disorder. In this project, I will use CRISPR-based technologies in induced pluripotent stem cells to examine how severe genetic mutations associated with schizophrenia disrupt gene expression and neurobiology. Findings from these experiments will improve our understanding of these cellular phenotypes of schizophrenia and may lead to new prognostic, diagnostic and treatment approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to the NIH because it is focused on fundamental biology that will impact cardiovascular disease and potentially develop a new therapeutic paradigm to treat and prevent sudden cardiac death; many heart disease states result in abnormal trafficking of proteins in the heart muscle cells. Abnormal protein trafficking is related to sudden death, but there are no therapies that address this trafficking defect. We propose to use a protein called GJA1-20k that we have shown improved trafficking of certain proteins to recover this trafficking defect in a mouse heart disease model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This K-24 application will support sub-studies which will expand the scope of an NIH-funded randomized clinical trial evaluating thiamine (vitamin B1) as a medicinal intervention to improve the exceedingly low survival rate and high incidence of injury to other organs after out-of-hospital sudden cardiac arrest. The proposed sub-studies will specifically establish if thiamine prevents post-arrest kidney injury and provide new insight into the impact of thiamine on other key components of metabolism. The K-24 application will simultaneously provide support for an accomplished investigator/mentor in maintaining a much-needed junior investigator mentoring program in resuscitation science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to determine how MYC initiates and maintains tumorigenesis. We have generated a library of conditional transgenic mouse models for MYC-driven cancer and human PDX models that we will use to identify novel vulnerabilities in MYC-driven cancers through RNAseq, ChIPseq and DESI-MSI, CRISPR synthetic lethal screens and MYC function reporter systems. Our collaborative research proposal will identify novel therapeutic targets for MYC driven cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The GABA-A α5 Positive Allosteric Modulator (PAM) program represents a novel approach to Mild Cognitive Impairment due to Alzheimer’s Disease (MCI due to AD), a patient population at high risk for dementia and, as such, would address a critical unmet need that will otherwise significantly burden patients, caregivers and the healthcare system in the decades ahead. With no current treatments for this indication, it is critical that novel Discovery and Development Programs, such as the one described in this application, advance novel chemical entities (NCEs) at therapeutically relevant targets as rapidly as possible. The GABA-A α5 PAM program benefits from clinical and regulatory paths in place for MCI due to AD along with appropriate mechanistic and therapeutic biomarkers making this a program that can advance the goals of the National Plan to Address Alzheimer’s Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is well-known that sex (e.g., male, female) matters for medical and mental health outcomes, and that some genetic contributions to health and disease depend on sex. But gender is not the same things as sex, so we developed a questionnaire that describes a person's gender identity, allowing us to investigate how gender influences genetic factors in determining health outcomes. This research will provide value to gender minority groups by seeking a better understanding of how genetic risk and resilience applies specifically to them, and not just the cisgender proportional majority.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative We have harnessed the glycan detection machinery possessed by members of the human gut microbiome to develop a new toolkit to complement current glycomics approaches. We demonstrate how these tools can be implemented to surveille crude biological samples for structurally diverse plant, animal, and microbial glycans and subsequently measure the relative abundance of individual substrates present in heterogenous glycan mixtures. Finally, we propose expand the capacity, specificity, and sensitivity of these tools to develop new affinity purification methods that can rapidly isolate individual glycans from a mixture for downstream structural analysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT High-intensity drinking (HID; consuming 8+/10+ drinks in a row for females/males) is a highly consequential form of excessive alcohol consumption. The proposed study will develop and pilot test a just-in-time adaptive intervention to address risk factors for HID within the drinking context (e.g. social setting of the drinking episode). Findings will directly inform public health practice by documenting the impact of delivering strategies to reduce HID in the time and place they are needed most.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research project will develop principled and accessible statistical frameworks toward improved and more transparent capture-recapture (C-R) methods for effective use of multiple overlapping data streams for disease surveillance. A key goal of the project is an appropriate merging of statistical with epidemiologic design and implementation principles, to fully harness the power of C-R for enhanced validity and precision in the estimation of case counts while adjusting for false positive signals. These developments draw on current surveillance initiatives and provide immediate applications to improve estimates of breast and colorectal cancer recurrence totals over defined follow-up periods among patients in US-based cancer registries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to develop, evaluate, and implement a new electronic decision aid tool for individuals referred for genetic testing for an inherited cancer syndrome. We propose that such a decision aid can facilitate quality decisions around genetic testing, reduce the dependence upon formal genetic counseling, and improve access to genetic testing. The tools will be evaluated broadly in both academic and community oncology clinics at multiple institutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC) infection is the most common cause of acquired kidney failure in children, causing acute, life-threatening complications and long-term disabilities. Although no treatment exists to date, preliminary studies have shown that early high volume intravenous fluid administration (hyperhydration) may be effective in mitigating or preventing complications. If effective, the results from this study will change clinical practice and improve the health of children by decreasing the acute morbidity and long-term complications associated with STEC infection and by providing epidemiologic, clinical, and biological data to improve our understanding and ability to combat this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck (HNSCC) comprises malignancies arising mainly from the mucosal surface of the oral cavity, pharynx, and larynx. It is a devastating, frequently disfiguring, and often fatal disease, which is expected to affect more than 53,000 people in the U.S. in 2020 and kill more than 10,000. This project will establish a profile analysis of DNA damage in oral cells of cigarette smokers and alcohol drinkers and relate this to the presence of HNSCC so that the profile can be used to identify those individuals who are at high risk for this terrible disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Depression and suicide are among the leading causes of disability and mortality, respectively, and prevalence rates for both have been increasing over the past three decades in the United States. Depression, suicidal ideation, and suicide attempts are especially prominent among young adults. This project seeks to develop a low-burden adaptive mobile intervention in which personalized feedback, informed by ecological momentary assessments and mobile/wearable technology data, can be delivered optimally and prevent the negative progression of mood symptoms into depressive episodes and suicidal behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anal cancer incidence is rapidly rising in women and preventive measures such as screening have received little study in this group. Therefore, we will conduct a prospective, longitudinal study evaluating screening modalities for anal cancer precursors women with a history of lower genital tract neoplasia or cancer to determine the performance and acceptability of different screening tests and strategies as well as define the natural history of disease. These data will be used to inform a decision analysis to assess the overall benefits, harms and costs of screening.

We will determine how these mutations cooperate with oncogenes that cause aberrant signaling and mutant chromatin regulators to drive malignancy, tumor heterogeneity and therapy resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE People living with HIV around the world have longer lives and are increasingly being diagnosed with hypertension and diabetes which increases their risk for heart disease and stroke. Although there are established guidelines for hypertension and diabetes care, in South Africa, where nearly five million people are receiving treatment for HIV, patients, providers, and health care facilities have not been equipped to address the added challenges of managing these co-morbidities. Our team has strong partnerships with and experiences of supporting clinics and other stakeholders in South Africa to identify new ways of delivering care that overcomes these challenges and addresses patients’ HIV and heart disease risk factors together; in this proposal, we will adapt, implement, and evaluate a package of these proven interventions to improve hypertension and diabetes care within HIV clinics in South Africa and see if they are appropriate and used by clinics and their staff over a 3 year period in a large project in South Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Lung cancer continues to be the leading cause of cancer-related deaths in both men and women in the United States, accounting for over 140,000 deaths per year (nearly one quarter of all cancer deaths). Bronchoscopy is currently the safest, least invasive, and least expensive diagnostic option, but yields conclusive results only 50-60% of the time, forcing many patients to consider more invasive procedures or leading to delayed diagnoses. We propose to develop computer algorithms that address localization limitations with existing bronchoscopes to improve diagnostic yield and achieve earlier lung cancer diagnosis in more patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Clinical management of interstitial cystitis/bladder pain syndrome and chronic prostatitis/chronic pelvic pain syndrome, two chronic, debilitating conditions characterized by pain and urinary symptoms, is currently hindered by a lack of consistently effective therapies. Our proposed study is thus important for public health because it will begin to test the utility of a promising new therapy for these two disabling conditions – personalized exclusion diets informed by food-specific antibody profiling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The recent development of immunotherapies that enhance T cell recognition and killing of malignant cells has been transformational for cancer care. However, these therapies are limited by the development of T cell ‘exhaustion,’ a process driven by chronic T cell stimulation that induces immune dysfunction pathways. The proposed research will use novel genome sequencing technologies to identify changes in genome organization that underlie human T cell exhaustion, which could be used to improve durable responses to immunotherapy in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Critical gaps in knowledge concerning disproportionately high incidence and mortality rates for many cancers in U.S. Black women remain. Since 1995, the Black Women's Health Study (BWHS), a follow-up study of 59,000 self-identified Black women, has contributed important information on individual, neighborhood-level, social, environmental, and genetic risk factors for cancer. With a median age of 64 and most cancers yet to occur in this cohort, and with established repositories of saliva samples, blood samples, tumor tissue samples, and mammograms, continuation of the BWHS infrastructure will further elucidate factors related to cancer incidence and survival in Black women and advance progress toward the ultimate goal of reducing racial inequities in health.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The public health significance of this study lies in its potential to develop an improved understanding of how to effectively change breast cancer survivors' physical activity behavior. These findings could result in more effective, scalable physical activity interventions for this population, and ultimately, improve health outcomes and reduce healthcare costs associated with cancer recurrence, comorbidities, and premature death in breast cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The underlying premise of this research is that, for most, back pain is characterized by fluctuating symptoms with periods of worse symptoms referred to as “flares”, and that risk factors for flare will differ from those traditionally investigated as risks for the condition to begin or become chronic. This project will study risk factors for back pain flares through an innovative study of a diverse array of candidate biological/behavioral, psychological, social and environmental factors in the “real world” using advanced wearable and online technologies and more intensive data collection for a subset of participants to identify the underlying mechanisms. New understanding of what and how factors drive flares of back pain will provide foundational knowledge for new approaches to targeted management strategies on a case-by-case basis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health and RFA-HL-20-021 because it identifies blood-derived factors that influence the blood-brain-barrier (BBB) integrity. In this multi-PI application, we determine the mechanisms by which RBCs influence the removal of cilia (deciliation), a cellular organelle projecting from the endothelial cell surface into the CNS blood, which impacts BBB integrity in vitro and in vivo. The proposed research is directly relevant to NIH’s mission of employing preventive measures to block BBB leakage and integrity, and development of better fluid-based BBB models in vitro.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance Statement)  Protein glycosylation plays an important role in all kingdoms of life by regulating cellular responses to metabolic and environmental changes. Defects in protein glycosylation have been linked with abnormal plant development, parasitic virulence and viability, and a variety of human diseases, such as cancer, diabetes, and neurodegenerative diseases. Therefore, our proposed structural and functional studies of two distinct glycosyltransferases, SPY and SEC, and their opposing effects on key transcription regulators will reveal novel molecular insights into the genetic regulation by two distinct types of intracellular protein glycosylation: O- fucosylation and O-GlcNAcylation, with profound implications in agriculture and public health.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENT This project aims to bridge the gap between assistive devices and rehabilitative tools so that stroke patients with a paretic arm can immediately return to their daily routine and use their activities of daily living as a patient-specific rehabilitation strategy. Assistive bionic exoskeletons will be intuitively controlled with residual muscle activity from the paretic arm, and artificial intelligence will elucidate underlying muscle impairment, improve the dexterity of bionic devices, and temporarily assist and rehabilitate stroke patients. This proposal is relevant to NIH’s mission because it has strong potential to improve quality of life for stroke patients and their caregivers, as well as reduce overall healthcare costs.

PHR: The NIH supports projects that educate pre-college students, teachers and the public about NIH clinical and basic research, building public understanding of and support for this research. These pre-college/public projects also play an important role in developing the biomedical research workforce, providing opportunities for students to engage in research and envision a biomedical career. The annual NIH SciEd conference enhances each project’s work through sharing of best practices and lessons learned, interactions with NIH staff, networking, and developing cross-project collaborations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will seek to develop a novel microfluidic (“organ-on-chip”) model of the human blood-brain interface. Breakdown of this interface in several neurological diseases, including Huntington’s disease, Alzheimer’s disease, stroke and traumatic brain injury is thought to contribute to disease progression. Our platform will allow testing of new therapeutic approaches in an entirely human, animal free, model system.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CAR T cell therapy for solid tumors remains challenging in part due to inhibitory tumor microenvironments (TME) that are seen even at the earliest stages of cancer. We hypothesize that targeting the TME can mitigate these immunosuppressive effects and enhance CAR T cell killing of lung tumor. Our research strategy will develop a new immunocompetent mouse model that faithfully recapitulates the immunosuppressive TME to test novel therapeutic approaches to overcome these suppressive effects to ultimately advance CAR T cell therapy for solid tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Depression remains one of the most significant challenges facing persons living with HIV infection. Neuroactive steroids are hormones produced by the body that can directly affect brain chemicals called neurotransmitters and some neuroactive steroids can affect the body’s immune system. This proposal will study the effect of neuroactive steroids on neurotransmitters and inflammation in people living with HIV on antiretroviral therapy to see if strategy helps with reducing depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: RELEVANCE The Administrative Core is essential for the efficient functioning of the Center. It is required for the Center’s fiscal management and resource sharing, and will ensure quality control and compliance with regulations and evaluation of Center activities. It will facilitate and optimize research, training, community engagement, and research translational activities of the Center, and assist in developing a new understanding of the effects of hazardous chemicals on liver disease, diabetes and heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance: We are beginning to understand that toxin exposure can initiate/exacerbate multiple adverse health outcomes, especially cardiometabolic diseases. Kentuckians are disproportionately affected by many chronic diseases, including obesity, hypertension, heart disease, diabetes, fatty liver disease, etc., which are all aspects of cardiometabolic syndrome. Certain communities are more highly impacted than others, and it is critical to understand why. We hypothesize that exposure to toxics, specifically VOCs, initiates/exacerbates these conditions. It is fundamental to our understanding of the effects of these toxics to engage the communities most deeply affected by exposure to these pollutants and to try to mitigate the effects of these exposures. Thus, determining the influence of pollutant exposures on the development/progression of these chronic conditions is vital. Also vital is examining this influence within the proposed areas within West and Southwest Louisville, Kentucky that face added social environmental health burdens, including an uneven distribution of race and ethnicity, a traumatic introduction into the racial reckoning, historic redlining, and poverty. Bidirectional research in this community will support understanding of the impacts of VOCs on cardiometabolic disease and community empowerment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Disruption of blood brain barrier (BBB) is a hallmark in traumatic and other brain injuries. However, the influences of blood on the structure and function of BBB in both resting and disease states remain poorly understood, largely due to the lack of appropriate BBB models and. In this project, we have assembled an interdisciplinary team with expertise in microvascular engineering and vascular biology, hematology and hemostasis, TBI, and cell signaling to reconstruct human BBB, and exploit roles of blood derived factors in maintaining and disrupting the BBB integrity and function, to identify intracellular signal pathways that contribute to BBB breakdown in TBI.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic testing is rapidly emerging as a cornerstone of medicine, enabling targeted therapies for patients with both common and rare disorders, and empowering patients, families and communities with knowledge about their condition. However, despite significant advances over the past decade, including the introduction of clinical whole genome sequencing, clinical genetics remains largely limited to the study of less than 1% of the genome, the exome. Here we leverage a novel approach for simultaneously mapping the genetic and epigenetic landscape of a sample to elucidate the functional impact of rare non-coding sequence and structural variants on gene regulatory patterns and monogenic human disorders.

PHR: The devastating consequences of ethanol consumption during pregnancy has reached epidemic proportions worldwide. Neurobehavioural defects and anomalies of the head and face are widely recognized consequences in children of mothers who drank alcohol during pregnancy, but at least 30-40% of the babies have serious heart defects. We will test how alcohol changes gene expression in the developing heart and then trial dietary compounds, currently available as over the counter supplements, for their efficacy in preventing the serious and costly effects of prenatal alcohol exposure on heart development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Adolescents and young adults (AYAs) who undergo hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) are at an especially high risk of developing sarcopenia (loss of skeletal muscle mass), which occurs earlier than would be expected from advancing age alone, and both doubles their risk for non-relapse mortality and leads to premature cardiovascular disease. We propose a mechanistic randomized controlled trial of home-based remotely supervised exercise (aerobic and resistance) training and supplementation with nicotinamide riboside, a precursor of NAD+, a metabolite that is critical for muscle metabolism, in AYA survivors of HCT. Our findings will lay the critical groundwork for future trials to prevent or mitigate the myriad downstream adverse effects of low muscle mass in AYA HCT survivors, an important area of shared strategic focus for the NCI and NHLBI.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal requests support to maintain the high-quality data and streamline the innovative infrastructure of the prospective California Teachers Study (CTS). During the next five years, as the CTS's 133,477 female participants pass through ages of high disease risk, we will conduct efficient linkages that capture new cancer, inpatient and outpatient hospitalization, mortality, and geospatial data. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer is a systemic disease. Cancer growth and metastasis relies not only on the intrinsic aberrant genetic and epigenetic makeup of tumor cells, but also on the tumor-induced systemic factors which impact cells in local and distant microenvironments, affecting all organ systems in the body. This proposal aims to dissect the complex interactions between the tumor and its host using multidisciplinary approaches, paving the way to rational targeted therapies that can effectively hinder metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic itch affects 13% of the population, has a profoundly negative impact on quality of life, and lacks FDA- approved treatments. A major obstacle that hinders treatment and the development of new therapeutics for chronic itch is the unavailability of an objective measure for quantifying itch, and the complete reliance on subjective measures such as patients’ self-assessment of their condition. In this proposal, we show that by analyzing the radio signals in the environment using machine learning we can infer patient scratching activity, and introduce a novel and objective measure for quantifying itch, and its impact on patients’ sleep and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Improving and maintaining durable clinical responses to cancer immunotherapy requires a detailed understanding of dynamics between tumor and immune cells, particularly in the context of checkpoint blockade. I propose to elucidate the origin of immune cells that respond to checkpoint blockade as well as how genetic alterations in tumor cells affect immune surveillance in the context of immunotherapy. This work will provide novel insights into cellular mechanisms that underlie response to immunotherapy to help inform rational therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The enclosure of the genome in the nucleus is essential for eukaryotic cell function; disruptions to nuclear integrity are associated with cancers and neurodegeneration. We propose to understand the molecular mechanisms that seal the nuclear membranes to surround and protect the genome. These efforts will inform both physiological and pathological processes that impact nuclear integrity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This application to renew an NIH funded (T32) training program focused on the epidemiology and prevention of cardiovascular disease is relevant to public health since heart disease and stroke remain the leading causes of morbidity and mortality in developed countries, and they are becoming significant public health problems in developing countries. Moreover, the causes of these diseases is multifactorial with lifestyle factors, including physical inactivity, poor diet and smoking, accounting for more than 50% of the burden of cardiovascular disease morbidity and mortality. Given this, the proposed training program will prepare pre- and post-doctoral fellows to become researchers who will explore the causes (both medical and behavioral) of cardiovascular disease so that effective prevention strategies can be developed and implemented.

PROJECT_TITLE: UCSD Integrated Cardiovascular Epidemiology Fellowship
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: NHLBI Institutional Training Mechanism Study Section[NITM(JA)]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with hematologic malignancies who are recipients of allogeneic stem cell transplantation have a high burden of psychological distress that undermines their psychological well-being, coping, health behaviors, quality of life (QOL), and overall recovery. This proposed research project aims to develop and test a novel 9- week positive psychological intervention for allogeneic transplant patients (PATH) that specifically targets psychological, behavioral, and QOL outcomes during the post-transplantation recovery period. The PATH intervention has the potential to greatly impact health outcomes and recovery in this vulnerable cancer population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with oral cavity cancers may experience extreme pain, which is induced by mediators from the cancers acting on local nerve endings. The proposed studies investigate the potential of a gene, artemin that is highly expressed in the cancers to both promote cancer and induce pain. A role for artemin in oral cancer and oral cancer pain has not been appreciated previously and a better understanding of its contribution to oral cancer and pain offers the possibility of developing new approaches to treating cancer and alleviating cancer pain through blocking function of artemin.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In partnership with Vidrio Technologies and Tufts University, we develop a fast, large area multiphoton exoscope (FLAME) for clinicians, as a powerful imaging tool for non-invasive, real-time quantitative assessment at the bedside that would not require specialized training. We integrate safety features, establish imaging stability to physiological motion and then test the performance of this device by evaluating its ability to provide in-vivo quantitative optical endpoints with sufficiently high predictive power to reliably distinguish benign from early melanoma lesions. Completion of these studies will establish the practical utility and value of FLAME as a non-invasive bedside tool for clinical skin imaging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The explosive increase in the prevalence of Alzheimer’s disease and other neurodegenerative disorders in the aging population is one of the great medical challenges of the twenty-first century. The Training Program in the Molecular Biology of Neurodegeneration and Alzheimer’s disease provides a framework within which the best training of future researchers devoted to curing neurodegenerative diseases can take place. The Program capitalizes on the extensive and concentrated effort in this area taking place at Harvard Medical School and its affiliated hospitals, and has succeeded in training some of the leading research scientists working at the frontiers of neurodegenerative disease research.
PROJECT_TERMS: Alzheimer's Disease;Molecular Biology;Nerve Degeneration;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Training in the Molecular Biology of Neurodegeneration and Alzheimer's Disease

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Difficulties with prospective memory, such as remembering to take medications, represent a signature decline in mild dementia, worsen quality of life and independence, and add burden to care partners. In this randomized controlled trial, individuals with mild cognitive impairment and mild dementia will train to use either a smartphone-based or paper-based memory strategy to compensate for daily prospective memory challenges. This work will help preserve independent functioning in persons with cognitive impairment and reduce burden on families impacted by dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We have identified a gene signature together with unique cell-surface markers that allow the purification of a subset of satellite cells in skeletal muscle that are long-term self-renewing stem cells that we term satellite stem cells. We propose to conduct experiments to establish their hierarchal relationships with their derivatives, and to investigate the molecular regulation of their identify and function. These studies will facilitate rapid advances in our understanding of the molecular mechanisms that regulate satellite stem cell homeostasis in human muscle wasting diseases and in aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Bacterial virulence is closely associated with nutrient acquisition, which is essential for growth and proliferation of pathogens; metal ions constitute essential nutrients, and thus the regulation of bacterial metal ion homeostasis within the host environment plays a pivotal role for survival. Non-essential xenometal ions with identical charge, comparable ionic radius and chemical hardness to essential metal ions can take advantage of and critically disrupt essential metal homeostasis in bacteria by to-date unknown mechanisms. Here, we seek to uncover how the high spin Fe3+ mimics Ga3+, Sc3+, and In3+ are transported to the bacterial cytoplasm and interact with the bacterial proteo- and metabolome.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Consumption of non-nutritive sweeteners (NNS) is a popular dietary approach, yet epidemiological evidence suggest that NNS promote, rather than prevent, obesity and hyperglycemia. In my graduate work I demonstrated that NNS promote weight gain and glucose intolerance by disrupting the microbiome, yet the underlying mechanisms remain unclear. This work will seek to identify the mechanisms through which NNS shape the microbiome, and the NNS-perturbed microbiome affects host metabolic health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Findings from the proposed line of research will link accelerated brain and biological aging in midlife to brain aging in older adults with cognitive impairment as well as Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD). These findings may help uncover the origins and risk factors for individual differences in brain aging that could help identify those most in need of intervention in midlife as well as help develop novel preventions to target ADRD before disease onset. The long-term goal of this line of research is to lower the global burden of ADRD by advancing our understanding of individual differences in brain aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to define the molecular mechanisms of structural plasticity (or polydispersity) that enable the lens a-crystallins to provide their critical function of maintaining life-long proteostasis and transparency of the eye lens. I will apply cutting-edge technologies centered around the use of CryoEM and CryoET to directly visualize the polydisperse state(s) of apo-state a-crystallin and decipher its mechanism of chaperone function. Ultimately, these studies will lay critical ground work required for developing a molecular understanding of how the a-crystallins contribute to the lens health and age-related cataract formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The claustrum is a central, connectional hub in the brain, and yet its functions have eluded characterization due to its narrow geometry and subcortical location. Claustral circuits are thought to influence visuomotor behavior and cognition, and disruption of those circuits may contribute to a wide range of neurological and neuropsychiatric disorders. This project examines the visuomotor roles of a specific claustral circuit using new approaches for identifying, studying, and manipulating neurons in the primate brain, with the overall goal of understanding claustral function in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: A recently approved therapy for triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) targets the PD1/PDL1 immune checkpoint pathway to reinvigorate an anti-tumor immune response, however the majority of patients do not respond. Gaining insights into the unknown barriers to an effective anti-tumor immune response is a critical unmet need that will benefit from new mouse models that more closely recapitulate the patient’s tumor microenvironment and more sophisticated genomic tools and analysis. This proposal seeks to understand which patients will benefit and how to increase the number of responders across all molecular subtypes of breast cancer using intratumoral immunotherapy that augments T cell infiltration directly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Although impressive methods and imaging techniques exist to characterize the functional networks of the human brain, clinical application of functional neuroimaging is impeded by its low sensitivity. The proposed research aims to develop and validate a novel functional neuroimaging modality, known as magnetic particle imaging (MPI) for mapping the brain’s functional networks. If the sensitivity of the new method is sufficiently improved compared to other methods, the proposed research will advance our ability to characterize functional connectivity mappings in individual patients and apply knowledge of brain network changes to the diagnosis and management of mental illnesses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative In this Program, we address shortcomings in our understanding of the pathogenesis of human cGVHD and our ability to prioritize the next generation of therapeutic strategies by defining the immune networks that characterize patients who develop cGVHD and interrogate the mechanisms of both success and failure of cGVHD treatment regimens. We explore the unique metabolic demands in cGVHD pathogenesis and lung injury repair and focus therapeutics on the most severe manifestation of cGVHD, BOS. We employ novel organoid cultures and immunogenomics to pinpoint the cellular and antigenic targets of BOS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement We will evaluate a combination targeted therapy to enhance the effectiveness of tumor specific peptide vaccine (PEPIDH1M) for mutant IDH1 glioma by reducing tumor-expressed levels of the immunosuppressive oncometabolite 2-hydroxyglutarate (2HG) using vorasidenib. Non-invasive magnetic resonance spectroscopic imaging maps of 2HG levels will permit longitudinal monitoring of vorasidenib efficacy. This study will demonstrate the feasibility of patient tolerance to this combined therapy and establish a simple tool for longitudinal assessment of 2HG changes due to vorasidenib, or other mIDH1/2 inhibitors, for future trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative: Carbon monoxide poisoning results in an estimated 50,000 emergency department visits in the United States annually and is one of the leading causes of poisoning death. In the current proposal we aim to develop a specific antidotal therapy that can be given in the field by paramedics that can remove carbon monoxide from red blood cells, tissues, and heart and brain mitochondria within minutes. The availability of an effective antidote for carbon monoxide has the potential to dramatically change the current treatment and substantially decrease death and disability caused from this common poisoning.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to establish a multiplexed imaging and synthetic biology platform to mechanistically understand chromatin regulation and its functional role in the peripheral olfactory system. Specifically, Aim 1 is to develop a high-throughput, multi-modal imaging method to directly visualize the 3D organization of DNA together with key regulatory proteins and the transcriptional output controlling the fates of single-neurons in the olfactory epithelium. Aim 2, is to deliver and image large libraries of compact viruses containing different combinations of regulatory elements and gene promoters to enable specific transgenic control of the different sub-populations of olfactory neuronal types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This renewal proposal aims to advance precision nanomedicine by combining achievements in single-particle investigations of nanoparticle-cell interactions and mechanistic insight into biological responses. Resolving these fundamental interactions at the relevant time and length scales for ligand-receptor recognition and internalization will deepen understanding of endocytosis and immunomodulatory responses, key processes for improvements in drug delivery and vaccine design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Several studies have demonstrated the ability of animals to detect disease states by olfaction alone, yet the mechanisms of odor-based disease diagnostics are unknown. We will use the olfactory system of the mouse to explore the representation of disease states in the olfactory bulb. Understanding how animals sense disease has the potential to revolutionize public health through the development of rapid, noninvasive screening technologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social networking sites (SNSs) represent both a potential barrier to alcohol use disorder (AUD) help-seeking behaviors among young adults, as well as a potentially innovative approach to facilitate AUD help-seeking among this population; however, there is little comprehensive understanding of the nature and impact of various exposures to AUD and AUD recovery-related SNS content. Pro-drinking exposures may contribute to decreases in perceived need for treatment due to the glamorization of heavy drinking behaviors, while on the other hand digital AUD recovery narratives emphasizing lived experience, strength, and hope may serve to normalize experiences of addiction and facilitate AUD help-seeking behaviors. This research career development award will provide the candidate with mentorship and hands-on training to systematically examine and characterize AUD and recovery-related exposures on Twitter in order to define prominent barriers to and facilitators of AUD recovery, as well to identify targets for later narrative-based intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative There are no effective vaccines or treatments for human parainfluenza virus (PIV) or metapneumovirus (MPV) infections; both are common causes of viral lower respiratory tract infections in children, immunocompromised adults and the elderly in the U.S., and are important causes of asthma exacerbations, bronchiolitis, and pneumonia. Here, we propose to engineer antibodies that can neutralize diverse strains of both viruses, trap them in mucus, and block their spread within the lung airways where both infections proliferate. If successful in validating their efficacy in vitro and in vivo, our work may provide a framework for developing novel treatments for other respiratory infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: OVERALL PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE  Alzheimer’s disease, dementia, and cognitive impairment will soon have a major impact on American Indian communities. The life expectancies for American Indians have increased over the last 50 years by as much as 30 years, resulting in an increased number of older adults. The Wabanaki Native American Research Center for Health is the first such Center in the northeastern US since the program was founded in 2000. It will fill striking gaps in our knowledge of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias and mild cognitive impairment among American Indian elders. It will also promote and expand the research and service capabilities of Wabanaki Public Health, a tribal public health district that is uniquely positioned to assume a leadership role in ameliorating health disparities experienced by the Wabanaki and other northeastern tribal communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) is a significant socioeconomic burden in the United States and worldwide, with few effective therapeutic interventions. Alcohol disrupts mitochondrial homeostasis and induces inflammation activation, underlying the progression of ALD. This proposal will not only uncover, for the first time, an important role of PDK4 in connecting the mitochondrial regulation of ethanol metabolism to inflammation activation, but also allow the applicant to acquire efficient knowledge and skills in the pathogenesis of ALD, which is highly relevant to NIAAA’s mission to provide support and protected time for a mentored career development experience in the biomedical science leading to research independence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Effective, cost-effective, scalable, and sustainable implementation strategies to improve care for rheumatic heart disease (RHD) in low-income countries are urgently needed. Our study will refine a contextually-adapted RHD program (ADUNU) aimed at achieving guideline-based care for RHD in Uganda through an integrated, community-centered approach. A robust mixed-methods design will evaluate the success of the program and determine the cost-effectiveness and affordability of the program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death among people living with HIV (PLWH) receiving antiretroviral therapy (ART) and there is ~2-fold greater risk for CVD events in PLWH compared to the risk among HIV- individuals. We propose to measure the transcriptional, phenotypic and functional capabilities of monocyte derived macrophages and compare them to the transcriptomic profiles of plaque derived macrophages in PLWH and in HIV negative individuals. We hypothesize that ART, directly and indirectly through alteration of the lipidome, contributes to macrophage activation in PLWH and subsequently to increased CVD risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is consistent with broader public health goals focused on improving patient end-of-life care and the College of Surgeons Commission on Cancer and Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) call for increased patient engagement in advance care planning (ACP) as part of standard care. The proposed study will address this public health issue by developing and pilot testing a mobile application (Planning Advance Care Together, PACT) designed to improve advanced cancer patients’ levels of engagement in ACP, documented ACP conversations with doctors and family members, completion of advance directives, and receipt of goal-concordant care by integrating family members/loved ones (i.e., “caregivers”) and providers into the ACP decision-making process. Therefore, this study is aligned with the NCI’s long-term goals of improving quality of care at the end of life and the CMS’s goal of improving engagement in ACP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching objective of this proposal is to identify how the policies U.S. states enacted to combat the spread and adverse effects of COVID-19 may have affected psychological health and mortality from drug overdose and suicide among working age and older adults in both the immediate and longer terms. The project will provide novel large-scale data on adult COVID-19 experiences and wellbeing and use the variation in policy responses across states to shed light on which policies and combinations of policies are consequential for adult psychological health and related mortality, the mechanisms through which policies affect those outcomes, and the population subgroups that are disproportionately affected. The overall findings will be essential for informing optimal policy responses in future pandemics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Asthma and sleep disordered breathing (SDB) are common chronic diseases that disproportionately affect Black children and those living in poor neighborhoods. The indoor environment has been shown to impact childhood asthma and it is highly plausible that bedroom environmental exposures contribute to upper airway inflammation and sleep quality but studies that include objective environmental exposure and sleep assessment are needed. This study will define the association between bedroom environmental exposures, including air quality, allergens, and microbes, and sleep quality among inner-city children with asthma, providing key foundational evidence necessary to design home environmental interventions in order to reduce sleep and asthma disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In numerous human diseases the insulating layer around nerves in the brain, called myelin, is damaged and must be efficiently cleared before tissue repair can occur. We have developed advanced methodologies for inducing, manipulating and observing myelin degeneration and repair in the live brain in real time. Using these tools this project will investigate how myelin debris are dynamically cleared by resident glial cells and the consequences of defective clearance on tissue maintenance and myelin repair.

PHR: Project Narrative The long-term goal of this work is study and reverse engineer how cells interact with their environment. Specifically, we study how ligand design features can be manipulated to facilitate a programmable response such as bone formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Recent work in human genetics has revealed much about patterns of genetic variation for genetically complex traits within the human population. However, interpreting these patterns requires that we understand the evolutionary processes that gave rise to them. Our research group will develop mathematical models of complex trait evolution and accompanying statistical inference approaches in order to learn about the forces shaping genetic variation in complex triats.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atrial fibrillation is the most common sustained arrhythmia, and is the cause of significant morbidity and mortality. This proposal aims to elucidate the role of endothelial dysfunction - a prominent feature of multiple risk factors for atrial fibrillation - in the development of an arrhythmogenic substrate leading to atrial fibrillation, which will allow the emergence of mechanism-guided therapies. Given the rapidly increasing prevalence of atrial fibrillation and the limited efficacy of current therapies for this disease, it is in the interest of public health to better understand the molecular mechanisms leading to atrial fibrillation.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Drexel FIRST initiative (Catalyzing Systemic Change at Drexel University to Support Diverse Faculty in Health Disparities Research) will create a collaborative structure involving University leaders, academic units and faculty to catalyze sustainable institutional change that supports scientific and inclusive excellence in the conduct of health disparities research. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Never in mitosis A-related kinase (NEK) family of protein kinases is an important, yet understudied, kinase family that has recently been implicated in a variety of disorders, including numerous cancers, ciliopathies, chronic inflammatory diseases, and neuronal disorders. The lack of reliable tools to study NEK function has made it difficult to determine the specific role(s) that NEK family members play in the etiology and progression of these diseases. In the proposed project, we will use a generalizable, family-based strategy to develop a suite of tools, including high quality chemical probes, that will be made freely available to the biomedical researcher community and enable researchers to build a firm understanding of how these understudied kinases contribute to health and disease and validate new druggable targets for cancer drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The immune system likely contributes to the development of pulmonary hypertension (PH) by excessive inflammation, which causes disease in the lung blood vessels. Our research investigates how dendritic cells engage with other immune cells such as T cells and monocytes, resulting in inflammation and pulmonary hypertension. Our main approach is by studying mice exposed to hypoxia, since hypoxia- induced PH affects over 140 million people worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) is the causal agent of Kaposi sarcoma, a common cancer in immunocompromised people (such as HIV/AIDS and transplant patients) and two lymphoid malignancies. We have designed a study to uncover the role of key KSHV glycoproteins in oral and systemic transmission of KSHV ex vivo and in vivo. We expect to generate critical data that will inform future design of an effective prophylactic KSHV vaccine candidate to prevent KSHV infection and its associated cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) are common blood cancers that are characterized by high rates of disease relapse. Our data show that the levels of active longer forms of IRAK4 are very high in MDS cells, are predictive of worse outcomes in patients, and can be used to target disease causing cells. In the proposed studies, we will determine the intracellular pathways activated by IRAK4 in MDS cells, and test the efficacy of novel IRAK4 inhibitors in MDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed NWIC NARCH XI has the goals to expand capacity at NWIC to allow more rapid and real- time response to tribal council and AIAN community requests to conduct research in emergent, high priority areas including addressing the consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic crisis on health, resilience and recovery. We propose our Northwest Indian College (NWIC) NARCH XI application as a hedge against the rising tide of racial inequity and social injustice impacting the lives and ultimately the health and mortality of AIAN people. Overall, the application aims to support three tribally-led research projects that address high priority health issues identified by AIAN tribes or tribal organizations, and provide opportunities for AIAN student health careers development and research training.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because identification of validated biomarker signatures in taxane-treated breast cancer patients associated with increased likelihood of developing neuropathic pain may contribute to the development of novel approaches to personalize chemotherapy in patients, including altering dosing or using a different chemotherapeutic, reducing the risk for developing neuropathic pain and the development of novel approaches to treat or slow the progression of neuropathic pain by modifying pathways prior to taxane-treatment and before initiation of symptoms. The proposed research is relevant to the NIH mission pertaining to the generation of fundamental knowledge about the nature and behavior of living systems and the application of that knowledge to enhance health, lengthen life, and reduce illness and disability.
